Majority Opinion > 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA
  

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, et al., ex rel. KEELER, Plaintiffs, v. EISAI, INC., Defendant. 
  

Case No. 09-22302-CV-WILLIAMS/Turnoff 
March 30, 2015, Filed March 30, 2015, Decided 
For United States of America, Ex Rel., Plaintiff: Joyce R. Branda, United States Department of Justice, Washington, DC; Mark Alan Lavine, United States Attorney's Office, West Palm Beach, FL.
For Michael Keeler, Plaintiff: Steven Frederick Grover, LEAD ATTORNEY, Fort Lauderdale, FL; Gary Michael Farmer, Jr., Seth Michael Lehrman, Steven R. Jaffe, Farmer Jaffe Weissing Edwards Fistos & Lehrman PL, Fort Lauderdale, FL; James Paul Gitkin, Salpeter Gitkin, LLP, Fort Lauderdale, FL.
For State of California, State of Delaware, District of Columbia, State of Florida, State of Hawaii, State of Illinois, State of Louisiana, Commonwealth of Massachusetts, State of Nevada, State of Tennessee, State of Texas, Commonwealth of Virginia, State of Georgia, State of Indiana, State of Michigan, State of Montana, State of New Hampshire, State of New Mexico, State of New York, State of New Jersey, State of Oklahoma, State of Rhode Island, State of Wisconsin, State of Connecticut, State of Minnesota, State of North Carolina, State of Colorado, State of Maryland, City of New York, City of Chicago, Plaintiffs: Gary Michael Farmer, Farmer Jaffe Weissing Edwards Fistos & Lehrman PL, Fort Lauderdale, FL. 
For Eisai, Inc., Defendant: Cheryl Zak Lardieri, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Goodell De Vries Leech & Dann LLP, Boston, MD; Eben S. Flaster, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Goodell, DeVries, Leech & Dann, LLP, Philadelphia, PA; Patricia Elaine Lowry, LEAD ATTORNEY, Squire Patton Boggs (US) LLP, West Palm Beach, FL; Thomas J. Cullen, Jr., LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Goodell DeVries Leech & Dann LLP, Baltimore, MD; Ashley C. Parrish, Jamie A. Lang, Joseph Sedwick Sollers, III, Kevin Dinan, Mark A. Jensen, PRO HAC VICE, King & Spalding, LLP, Washington, DC; Justin Daniel Jacobson, LAWCRAFT, Plantation, FL.
WILLIAM C. TURNOFF, United States Magistrate Judge.

WILLIAM C. TURNOFF 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION
THIS CAUSE is before the Court upon Defendant Eisai Inc.'s Motion to Tax Costs Against Relator Michael Keeler, and Bill of Costs (ECF No. 237), and Defendant Eisai Inc.'s Motion for Entitlement to Attorneys Fees and Costs (ECF No. 255). These motions were referred to the undersigned by the Honorable Kathleen M. Williams, United States District Judge for the Southern District of Florida. (ECF No. 242). A hearing on these motions took place before the undersigned on October 23, 2014. (ECF No. 286). The Court has considered the written and oral arguments, the record, the applicable law, and is otherwise duly advised in the premises.
Factual and Procedural Background 
The Relator, Michael Keeler, filed this qui tam action against Defendant Eisai, Inc., claiming to have specific inside information establishing that Eisai violated the False Claims Act, 31 U.S.C. § 3729 , et seq. ("FCA"), in the marketing of four of its drugs.1 The Relator alleged that he had substantial inside knowledge of these schemes from having been employed by Eisai as a pharmaceutical sales representative from 2006 through [*2] mid-2009.
The Relator sued under three different FCA liability provisions: 31 U.S.C. §§ 3729(a)(1) , (a)(2) , & (a)(3) :2 Subsection (a)(1) prohibits presentation, or the causing of presentation, of false or fraudulent claims to the government; Subsection (a)(2) prohibits use of a false or fraudulent statement or record to get the government to pay a claim; and Subsection (a)(3) prohibits a person from conspiring to get a false or fraudulent claim allowed or paid by the government. The Complaint alleged that Eisai engaged in three complex, nationwide schemes: (1) illegally failing to provide the government with the requisite "best price" for the drugs Aloxi, Fragmin, Ontak, and Dacogen; (2) off-label marketing of Ontak and Dacogen in violation of FDA laws; and (3) providing illicit kickbacks to health care providers to induce them to buy the subject drugs instead of competitors' FDA-approved drugs. The Relator noted that the off-label marketing and kickback schemes did not involve allegations that Eisai itself submitted false claims to the government; rather, it was the health care providers (e.g., doctors, hospitals, pharmacies) who submitted claims for reimbursement to Medicare and Medicaid. As such, this was a "cause to be submitted" case in which it was alleged that Eisai had caused providers to present claims for improper Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement, stemming from Eisai's schemes.
Eisai contended that its off-label marketing was legal because doctors may prescribe a drug to a patient provided that they use sound judgment, and the drug was FDA-approved for some indication, not necessarily the FDA-approved indication. The Relator argued that Eisai ignored the fact that federal law unequivocally prohibited pharmaceutical companies from off-label marketing, which is distinct from off-label use by a physician. The former was strictly prohibited by Congress, while the latter was not.
The Relator filed suit under seal on August 4, 2009. (ECF No. 1). A First Amended Complaint was filed on July 8, 2010. (ECF No. 19). On February 24, 2011, the United States declined to intervene. (ECF No. 23). Judge Ungaro dismissed the First Amended Complaint on June 21, 2011, with leave to file an amended complaint. (ECF No. 61).
The Relator filed a Second Amended Complaint on July 1, 2011. (ECF No. 62). Defendant moved to dismiss the Second Amended Complaint. (ECF No. 76). Judge Ungaro deemed moot the motion to dismiss upon the filing of the Third Amended Complaint, which was the operative pleading.3 (ECF No. 80, 81). Eisai moved to dismiss the Third Amended Complaint on the same grounds as before. (ECF No. 95). On January 31, 2013, Judge Williams entered an Order dismissing the action with prejudice. (ECF No. 232).4 She found that the Relator had the chance to litigate his assertions of fraud but had been unable to posit a sufficient link between Eisai, doctors, and government programs to sustain a claim.
On February 28, 2013, the Relator filed a Motion to Amend Order of Dismissal Under Rules 60(a) and (b) , and Rule 59(e) , and for Leave of Court to File a Fourth Amended Complaint. (ECF No. 236). On April 1, 2013, Judge Williams entered an Order denying [*3] Relator's motion to amend, which she treated as a motion for reconsideration. (ECF No. 257).
On February 26, 2013, Eisai filed a Motion to Bifurcate the Issue of Entitlement to Attorney's Fees and Costs From Amount. (ECF No. 233). On March 1, 2013, Defendant filed a Motion to Tax Costs. (ECF No. 237). That same day, Relator filed a Notice of Appeal of Judge Williams' dismissal order to the Eleventh Circuit. (ECF No. 238). The costs motion and the motion to bifurcate were referred to the undersigned. (ECF No. 235, 242). After holding a status conference on March 28, 2013 (ECF No. 243), the undersigned stayed consideration of the motion to bifurcate, the cost motion, and the motion to exceed page limits pending appeal, and allowed Eisai to file its fee motion, but Relator was not obligated to respond yet. That same day, Eisai filed a Motion for Entitlement to Attorney's Fees and Costs. (ECF No. 255). These rulings were memorialized via Omnibus Order dated April 8, 2013. (ECF No. 261).
On July 25, 2014, the appellate court issued its mandate affirming dismissal of the case. (ECF No. 276). Judge Williams entered an Order lifting the stay on August 13, 2014. (ECF No. 277). On September 25, 2014, the undersigned entered an Omnibus Order granting the motion to bifurcate entitlement to fees from amount of award; granting in part the Relator's motion to exceed page limits; providing a briefing schedule; and setting a hearing for October 23, 2014. (ECF No. 278). The order provided that no further filings would be permitted, unless requested by the court. In this connection, the Court denied Eisai's motion for leave to file a reply. (ECF No. 285).
In the instant motions, Eisai contended that it was entitled to attorney's fees and costs under the FCA ( 31 U.S.C. § 3730(d)(4) ), 28 U.S.C. § 1927 , and this Court's inherent powers. Relator denied that Eisai was entitled to any award of attorney's fees or costs.
I. Defendant Eisai Inc.'s Motion to Tax Costs Against Relator Michael Keeler, and Bill of Costs. (ECF No. 237).
A. Costs sought by Eisai.
Eisai, as the prevailing party by virtue of the Court's Order granting its motion to dismiss, sought to recover costs in the amount of $607,625.04,5 pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(d) and Local Rule 7.3 . (ECF No. 232). The costs are as follows: (a) $7,347.40 in fees for printed or electronically recorded transcripts, consisting of $433.80 in transcript costs, and $6,913.60 in deposition costs; (b) $23,885.75 in printing and copying costs, consisting of $705.80 in color imaging/copying, and $23,179.95 in printing/duplicating; (c) $576,391.89 in electronic discovery costs, consisting of $335,921.55 in technical services, which includes $324,641.68 in collection and processing, $238,524.34 in hosting costs, and $13,225.87 in professional fees.
At the hearing, Relator conceded that the following costs were taxable: (1) $433.80 in transcript costs; (2) $6,913.60 in depositions costs; (3) $20,723 in collection and processing costs spanning from February 13, 2012, through April 16, 2012; and (4) $1,946 in hard drive costs, which were included in costs for professional fees. Notwithstanding, Relator argued that no costs should be taxed in this case.
B. Standard for cost recovery.
Pursuant to Rule 54(d)(1) , "costs other than attorney'[*4] s fees shall be allowed as of course to the prevailing party unless the court otherwise directs." Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(d)(1) . Thus, Eisai, as the prevailing party, is presumptively entitled to recover costs. However, Eisai must show that the claimed costs are authorized by § 1920 , and that they were reasonably or necessarily incurred for use in the case. Univ. of Miami v. Intuitive Surgical. Inc., No. 04-20409-CIV, [2007 BL 110558], 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 18836 , 2007 WL 781912 , at *1 (S.D. Fla. Mar. 13, 2007). To meet this burden, Eisai must provide sufficient detail and documentation regarding those costs in order to permit challenges by opposing counsel and meaningful review by the Court. Lee v. American Eagle Airlines. Inc., 93 F.Supp.2d 1322 , 1335 (S.D. Fla. 2000) (finding that the movant "bears the burden of submitting a request for expenses that would enable the Court to determine what expenses were incurred and whether Plaintiff is entitled to them.").
Relator argued that the FCA imposed a higher standard for a cost award that Eisai did not meet. Pursuant to the FCA,
If the Government does not proceed with the action and the person bringing the action conducts the action, the court may award to the defendant its reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses if the defendant prevails in the action and the court finds that the claim of the person bringing the action was clearly frivolous, clearly vexatious, or brought primarily for purposes of harassment.
31 U.S.C. § 3730(d)(4) . Thus, Relator argued that costs may not be taxed against it as a losing FCA plaintiff, unless the claims were found to be frivolous. The undersigned finds this argument to be unpersuasive. In U.S. v. Degayner, the court found that the fees and expenses provision of the FCA did not displace its authority to award costs to the prevailing party pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(d) . U.S. v. DeGayner, No. 6:06-cv-1462-Orl-19KRS, [2009 BL 7371], 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 5658 , 2009 WL 111673 , at *3 (M.D. Fla. Jan. 1, 2009) (collecting cases). The Relator has not provided any authority to the contrary. Accordingly, Eisai is entitled to recover its costs as the prevailing party under Rule 54 .

C. Relator's arguments against an award of costs.
Rule 54 creates a strong presumption that the court will award costs to the prevailing party. Mathews v. Crosby, 480 F.3d 1265 , 1276 (11th Cir. 2007) (noting that "there is a strong presumption that the prevailing party will be awarded costs."); Manor Healthcare Corp. v. Lomelo, 929 F.2d 633 , 639 (11th Cir. 1991) (noting that Rule 54(d) "creates a presumption in favor of awarding costs to the prevailing party which [the opponent] must overcome."). Notwithstanding, Relator argued that the court should deny all of Eisai's costs. "[S]ince denial of costs is in the nature of a penalty for some defection on [the prevailing party's] part in the course of the litigation," Walters v. Roadway Express. Inc., 557 F.2d 521 , 526 (5th Cir. 1977) (internal marks and citation omitted), the district court's discretion not to award the full amount of costs incurred by the prevailing party is not unlimited. See Head v. Medford, 62 F.3d 351 , 354 (11th Cir. 1995). "To defeat the presumption and deny full costs, a district court must have and state a sound basis for doing so." Chapman v. AI Transp., 229 F.3d 1012 , 1039 (11th Cir. 2000).
By way of summary, Relator attacked the sufficiency of the cost motion and the supporting documentation, argued that electronic [*5] discovery and copying costs were not recoverable, and pointed to Eisai's own conduct and Relator's financial condition, in support of its position that no costs should be awarded in this case.
1. Sufficiency of the cost motion.
Relator argued that Eisai failed to meet its burden of proving that the requested costs were both reasonable and necessary under Rule 54(d) and § 1920 , because the itemization of costs was heavily redacted and lacked sufficient detail. The court's review of the exhibits attached to the cost motion and the reply confirm that many of the invoices have been heavily redacted and lack in specificity with respect to the services actually performed. Moreover, the Itemization of Costs provides scant, general information regarding the requested costs. Upon review, the undersigned finds that, generally, the invoices are lacking in specificity regarding what services were actually performed. In this connection, Relator argued that the KPMG affidavit (ECF No. 254-2) provided insufficient information to support the "Professional Fees" listed in Section II of the Bill of Costs. Also, the KPMG invoices listed charges for "Collection and Processing" and "Fees and Expenses," without further explanation. Relator argued that it was impossible to discern, from the descriptions given, which of these costs, if any, related to "exemplification" or "making copies" of electronic discovery. As noted, the undersigned agrees.
2. Electronic discovery.
Although trial courts are afforded wide latitude in ascertaining taxable costs, absent explicit statutory authorization or contractual authorization, federal courts are limited to those costs specifically enumerated in 28 U.S.C. § 1920 .6 EEOC v. W&O, Inc., 213 F.3d 600 , 620 (11th Cir. 2000) (citing Crawford Fitting Co. v. J.T. Gibbons. Inc., 482 U.S. 437 , 445 , 107 S.Ct. 2494 , 96 L.Ed.2d 385 (1987)).
In dispute is whether electronic discovery costs requested by Eisai in the amount of $576,391.89 are recoverable under § 1920 . The electronic discovery costs fall into three categories: (1) collection and processing; (2) hosting; and (3) professional fees. As noted, Relator conceded that, out of the collection and processing costs, $20,723 were taxable for the period from February through April 2012.
Relying upon Race Tires America, Inc. v. Hoosier Racing Tire Corp., 674 F.3d 158 (3d Cir. 2012), Relator argued that, as a matter of statutory construction, none of these categories constituted either "exemplification" or the "making of copies," pursuant to § 1920(4) . Eisai contended that Congress amended § 1920(4) to include all electronic discovery costs. Relator argued that many courts, including Race Tires, Country Vintner of North Carolina, LLC v. E. & J. Gallo Winery. Inc., 718 F.3d 249 , 260 (4th Cir. 2013), and Finnerty v. Stiefel Laboratories. Inc., 900 F.Supp.2d 1317 , 1322 (S.D. Fla. 2012), have rejected that argument concluding that the amended statute, though broader, did not permit the taxation of all electronic discovery costs.
In Race Tires, the Third Circuit found that decisions allowing the taxation of essentially all electronic discovery consultant charges, such as CBT Flint Partners. LLC v. Return Path. Inc., 737 F.3d 1320 (Fed. Cir. 2013), were "untethered from the statutory [*6] mooring." 674 F.3d at 169 . The appellate court went on to note that § 1920(4) did not state that all steps leading up to the production of copies of materials was taxable and did not authorize taxation merely because present-day technology required technical expertise not ordinarily possessed by the typical legal professional. Id . The Third Circuit persuasively reasoned that "only the conversion of native files to TIFF7 (the agreed-upon default format for production of electronic discovery), and the scanning of documents to create digital duplicates are generally recognized as the taxable 'making copies of material.'" Race Tires, 674 F.3d at 167 .
Eisai argued that Race Tires has not been adopted by the Eleventh Circuit, which has yet to rule on the issue of which electronic discovery costs are taxable. Although the Eleventh Circuit has not adopted Race Tires, the undersigned finds the Third Circuit's reasoning persuasive. As the Country Vintner court noted, the Third Circuit, in reaching its decision, considered the statutory history, the plain language of the statute, and the Supreme Court's narrow interpretation of taxable costs under § 1920 . 718 F.3d at 260 .
Indeed, in Finnerty, this Court noted that, although it was generally agreed that electronic discovery costs were available under § 1920 , there was scant legal authority providing guidance regarding whether they were recoverable under Rule 54(d)(1) and § 1920 . 900 F.Supp.2d at 1320 (citations omitted). The court went on to deny costs for the creation of an electronic database finding that it had been created for the convenience of the party seeking to tax the cost.  Id. at 1322-23 . The court also relied upon Race Tires to find that a holding to the contrary would be beyond the statutory confines and would muddy the distinction between costs and attorney's fees.  Id. at 1322 .
Relator argued that charges for collection and processing of electronic discovery, which included charges for gathering, preserving, processing, loading, post-processing, searching, culling, extracting electronic discovery, copying data from one database to another (from Nuix, an Early Case Assessment tool used for Eisai's convenience, to Relativity, a review platform), converting files from native format to TIFF, and configuring databases, were not taxable under § 1920(4) , pursuant to Race Tires and Finnerty, because they constituted services leading up to the actual making of copies for production. With respect to the TIFF conversion, according to Relator, Eisai rejected an electronic discovery protocol to produce files in native format that would have kept electronic discovery costs down. As such, Relator argued that it should not have to bear the cost of such conversion when it did not request same.
Relator argued that costs totaling $13,225.87, from November 2011 through April 2012, listed in Section II of the Bill of Costs should be denied because the affidavit from outside vendor KPMG (ECF No. 254-2), provided insufficient information regarding Eisai's cost of copying the produced files onto hard drives to support these "Professional Fees." No information [*7] was provided regarding the nature of the work performed, or whether any portion of these "Professional Fees" were for the "exemplification" or "making copies" of electronic discovery. Moreover, KPMG's invoices listed charges for "Collection and Processing" and "Fees and Expenses." The declaration of Brett Trizzino, director of forensic technology services for KPMG, stated that charges for copying data and for narrowing the universe of documents based upon search terms and date restrictions were included in the "Fees and Expenses" section of the invoices ($9,904), and that KPMG configured a database to extract duplicates billed under Processing/Loading ($312,344). Not only were these costs inadequately described, but they are not recoverable under § 1920 .
With respect to the outside vendor DTI, the declaration of Shawna Hull, business manager for DTI, stated that $7,394.95 represented charges for copying electronic data from Eisai's Lotus Notes email files and loading that data into the NUIX database, at a rate of $100 per gigabyte. (ECF No. 254-3). The rest of the charges were for loading data into Relativity, a review platform, applying search terms, and removing duplicate documents. None of these charges constituted making copies under § 1920 . Moreover, these charges were incurred for the convenience of the attorneys.
Next, Eisai requested $238,524.34 in charges incurred for hosting a data set of electronic discovery invoiced by KPMG, which Relator argued were not taxable under § 1920(4) , because they preceded copying done for production, or were for the hosting of a litigation database maintained purely for the party's convenience and use. See CBT Flint Partners, 737 F.3d at 1331 ("The costs of those activities are not the costs of making copies. Rather, they are part of the large body of discovery obligations, mostly related to the document-review process, that Congress has not included in section 1920(4) ."); Finnerty, 900 F.Supp.2d at 1320-21 ("When an electronic database has been built for the purpose of responding to discovery requests, some courts have deemed that a taxable cost. However, many more courts have denied such recovery."). Even if such charges were taxable, Relator argued that they were incurred after Eisai had completed its production to Relator's counsel on March 7, 2012. In this connection, on August 1, 2011, Judge Ungaro summarily denied Eisai's Motion to Stay Discovery. However, Eisai objected to every request for production. See (ECF No. 139, 159, 167). On December 15, 2011, the undersigned found that all of Relator's Requests for Production were reasonable and that Eisai had essentially imposed its own stay of discovery, thus leaving Relator "bereft in the desert of non-discovery." (ECF No. 224). The court ordered Eisai to produce documents within two months, i.e., by late February 2012. As such, Relator argued that any electronic discovery costs incurred prior to December 2011, and after February 2012 (i.e., invoices from April, 2012, through January, 2013), could only have been incurred for Eisai's own convenience and were not recoverable. The claimed electronic discovery costs [*8] from December 2011, through February 2012—the discovery period—totaled $221,071. Nevertheless, Relator argued that these costs should also be denied because of Eisai's unnecessary TIFF conversion, double-loading onto review platforms, and the unreasonable rates approved by Eisai.
Relator argued that, under Race Tires, Eisai could only recover the cost of copying the produced electronic discovery onto media, which entailed converting native digital files into other formats for production and scanning hard copies to create digital duplicates for discovery production. Race Tires, 674 F.3d at 167 ("[O]nly the conversion of native files to TIFF (the agreed-upon default format for production of [electronic discovery]), and the scanning of documents to create digital duplicates are generally recognized as the taxable 'making copies of material.'"); El Camino Resources, Ltd. v. Huntington National Bank, No. 1:07-cv-598, [2012 BL 441105], 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 146037 , 2012 WL 4808741 , at *7 (W.D. Mich. May 3, 2012) ("Under the Race Tires America approach, the only compensable costs are (a) the conversion of native digital files to the agreed-upon production format and (b) the scanning of paper documents to create digital duplicates for production in discovery."). At any rate, the costs of file scanning and file format conversion were only taxable to the extent that they were designated on the Bill of Costs as having been incurred for these purposes. According to Relator, the only costs associated therewith that were adequately described were those described as purchasing hard drives totaling $1,946. Thus, the undersigned finds that Eisai may recover this cost in the amount of $1,946.
3. Copying/Printing costs.
Eisai sought $23,885.75 in copying and printing costs. Relator argued that printing costs were not recoverable under § 1920 and that neither the Motion nor the Bill of Costs provided any information about the need for the photocopies or printing charges. See Degayner, [2009 BL 7371], 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 5658 , 2009 WL 111673 , at *4. Relator argued that this claim was suspect because Eisai produced records electronically, not as hard copies. Further, Relator argued that the claim was not adequately itemized, as Eisai failed to provide a rate per page, the number of copies, or a breakdown of why each category of copies was needed. Cullens v. Ga. Dep't of Transp., 29 F.3d 1489 , 1494 (11th Cir. 1994); Osorio v. One World Technologies, Inc., 834 F.Supp.2d 20 (D. Mass. 2011).
In reply, Eisai provided a breakdown of the number of copies and the rates charged by the outside vendors, which ranged from $0.10 to $0.30 per page. In this respect, Relator argued that a rate of $0.10 was reasonable, and that Eisai failed to show that the copies were provided to the Court or Relator. See Grady v. Bunzi Packaging Supply Co., 161 F.R.D. 477 (N.D. Ga. 1995); Duckworth v. Whisenant, 97 F.3d 1393 , 1399 (11th Cir. 1996) (general copying not recoverable under § 1920 ). In any event, $0.10, not even $0.20 per copy, is reasonable); Santana v. RCSH Op'ns, No. 10-61376-CIV, [2012 BL 237857], 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 124119 , 2012 WL 3779013 , at * 8 (S.D. Fla. Aug. 31, 2012). Eisai argued that the majority of the copy/printing charges were for discovery, research, pleadings, motions, memoranda, depositions and exhibits. Eisai's counsel copied/printed 91,244 pages at .20 per page ($18,248.80); Squire Sanders made black and [*9] white copies of 8,035 pages at .30 per page ($2,410.50); King & Spaulding made black and white copies of 35,581 pages at .10 per page ($3,558.10); and outside vendor charges for copies were $10,552.56. Acknowledging that some of the charges may not be reimbursable, Eisai reduced its requested copy costs to $23,179.95, or two-thirds of the total amount requested for black and white copying and outside vendor charges.
It is well-established that the movant must provide information regarding the purpose of the copies and whether they related to the claims at issue. See Helms v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 808 F. Supp. 1568 , 1570 (N.D. Ga. 1992), aff'd, 998 F.2d 1023 (11th Cir.1993); see also Lee, 93 F.Supp.2d at 1335-36 (declining to tax photocopy costs lacking description). Here, Eisai failed to indicate whether all of the requested copies were necessary, as opposed to convenient, particularly in light of the fact that most discovery was provided electronically. It also failed to explain the differing rates among the outside vendors for black and white copies. The copy information provided was insufficient to meet the burden of showing that all of the copies were necessarily obtained for use in the case. However, the court is aware that, undoubtedly, some of the copies were made for use in the case. As such, the undersigned finds that a substantial reduction is in order, as follows: Eisai may recover 10% of the total 134,860 copies requested, or 13,486 copies, at a rate of $0.10 per page, for a total of $1,348.60 in copy costs.
D. Recoverable Costs 
Eisai sought to recover $7,347.40 in fees for printed or electronically recorded transcripts consisting of $433.80 in transcript costs, and $6,913.60 in deposition costs. These costs are recoverable under § 1920(2) , as Relator conceded.
Eisai sought to recover $23,885.75 in printing and copying costs, consisting of $705.80 in color imaging/copying, and $23,179.95 in printing/duplicating. As noted herein, Eisai may only recover $1,348.60 in copying costs.
Finally, Eisai sought to recover $576,391.89 in electronic discovery costs, the majority of which are not recoverable under § 1920 .8 As noted herein, Relator conceded that $20,723 out of the collection and processing costs were taxable, spanning from February 13, 2012, through April 16, 2012. The hosting costs of $238,524.34 are not taxable. Out of the professional fees costs of $13,225.87, Eisai may only recover $1,946 in hard drive costs.
In summary, the undersigned finds that only the following costs requested by Eisai are taxable under § 1920: (1) Transcript costs of $433.80; (2) Deposition costs of $6,913.60; (3) Hard drive expenses of $1,946; (4) $1,348.60 in copy costs; and (5) $20,723 in electronic discovery costs. Thus, the undersigned RECOMMENDS that Eisai be awarded total costs in the amount of $31,365.00.
1. Chilling effect and Unclean Hands.
In his initial 30-page preliminary opposition memorandum, the Relator argued that costs should be denied for the following reasons: Eisai had unclean hands because the evidence in Relator's sealed motion for partial summary judgment showed that Eisai knowingly provided the Ontak Access Resource ("OAR") Program kickbacks and illegally off-label marketed [*10] Ontak; after stonewalling discovery for months, Eisai refused to enter into an electronic discovery protocol and unilaterally converted electronic discovery from native format to TIFF; and a cost award would have a chilling effect on whistleblowers.9 In the 5-page supplementary memorandum, Relator explained that he and his counsel had "lost their shirts" when Eisai prevailed on the pleadings and that a cost award in the amount sought would devastate Relator and his family. (ECF No. 279).
With respect to unclean hands, although Eisai succeeded in obtaining a dismissal with prejudice of Relator's Third Amended Complaint, Relator argued that it had produced evidence in discovery that corroborated his allegations regarding kickbacks related to Ontak and the OAR Program and the off-label marketing of Ontak. Relator argued that this evidence was a defense to the taxation of costs. However, the Court never addressed the alleged evidence substantively. In fact, Judge Williams noted that it was not known whether Relator's allegations were actually true. (ECF No. 232) at p. 37. As such, the undersigned declines to deny costs on this basis.
With respect to Relator's argument that a cost award would have a chilling effect on other qui tam plaintiffs, Relator has not shown why a potential chilling effect should overcome the presumption of a cost award to the prevailing party. See Chapman, 229 F.3d at 1039 (citing Durrett v. Jenkins Brickyard, Inc., 678 F.2d 911 , 917 (11th Cir. 1982) (finding that, in a Title VII Case, "[a] fee must be assessed [against non-prevailing plaintiffs] which will serve the deterrent purpose of the statute, and no fee will provide no deterrence")); See Degayner, [2009 BL 7371], 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 5658 , 2009 WL 111673 , at * 3, FN 2 ("[Relator] has failed to show why the potential danger of chilling future FCA claims—standing alone as a mere assertion with no support from "a federal statute, [the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure], or a court order," Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(d)(1) —should overcome the traditional presumption that a district court will award costs to a prevailing party.").
Finally, "the Court acknowledges that the good faith of unsuccessful litigants is a relevant consideration in Rule 54(d) deliberations. Good faith, without more, however, is an insufficient basis for denying costs to a prevailing party." Friends of Everglades v. S. Fla. Water Mgmt. Dist., 865 F.Supp.2d 1159 , 1168 (S.D. Fla. 2011) (quoting White & White Inc. v. Am. Hosp. Supply Corp., 786 F.2d 728 , 731 (6th Cir. 1986) (internal quotation marks omitted)); see also Pickett v. Iowa Beef Processors, 149 F. App'x 831 , 832 (11th Cir. 2005).
2. Financial Circumstances.
Relator argued that the court should take his financial status into account in calculating the amount of costs that he was required to pay. In Chapman v. AI Transp., the Eleventh Circuit held that "a non-prevailing party's financial status is a factor that a district court may, but need not, consider in its award of costs pursuant to Rule 54(d) ." 229 F.3d at 1039 . Should the court choose to consider the non-prevailing party's financial status, "substantial documentation of a true inability to pay" must be produced. Id . Thus, a non-prevailing party must provide "clear proof of [his] dire financial circumstances" to justify a decrease in costs. [*11] Id . The court has discretion to determine whether the financial circumstances provide clear proof. Id . However, the court may not take into account "the relative wealth of the parties." Id . The Chapman court went on to note that, "[e]ven in those rare circumstances where the non-prevailing party's financial circumstances are considered in determining the amount of costs to be awarded, a court may not decline to award any costs at all." Id . 
Here, Relator requested additional time to produce pertinent financial documentation regarding his financial circumstances and resulting inability to pay a cost award. The Court has awarded costs to Eisai as the prevailing party. Therefore, Relator may file substantial documentation of his inability to pay within five (5) days.
II. Defendant Eisai Inc.'s Motion for Entitlement to Attorneys Fees and Costs. (ECF No. 255).
Eisai claimed that it was entitled to attorney's fees and costs pursuant to the FCA, § 1927 , and the Court's inherent power.
A. Fees under the False Claims Act, 31 U.S.C. § 3730(d)(4) .
The FCA permits a prevailing Defendant in a qui tam action to recover attorney's fees and expenses under certain circumstances:
If the Government does not proceed with the action and the person bringing the action conducts the action, the court may award to the defendant its reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses if the defendant prevails in the action and the court finds that the claim of the person bringing the action was clearly frivolous, clearly vexatious, or brought primarily for purposes of harassment.
31 U.S.C. § 3730(d)(4) . Thus, to award attorney's fees and expenses, the Court must find that the Relator's suit falls within one of the following categories: (1) clearly frivolous; (2) clearly vexatious; or (3) brought primarily for purposes of harassment. Any one of these three conditions is sufficient for an award of attorney's fees. However, even if a plaintiff's suit falls within one of the enumerated categories, a court still maintains discretion over whether to award attorney's fees. See § 3730(d)(4) (stating "the court may award ... attorneys' fees") (emphasis added); United States ex rel. Dodge v. ACS State & Local Solutions, Inc., No. 8:03-cv-65-T-30TGW, 2009 WL 1748540 , at *1 (M.D. Fla. June 18, 2009). Imposition of fees pursuant to § 3730(d)(4) requires a showing that the relator was motivated "primarily" by an improper purpose. U.S. ex rel. Bane v. Breathe Easy Pulmonary Services, Inc., No. 8:06-cv-40-T-33MAP, [2009 BL 91256], 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 35771 , 2009 WL 1148632 , at *4 (M.D. Fla. Apr. 28, 2009). Indeed, "an award of fees [under § 3730(d)(4) ] should be reserved for rare and special circumstances." Id . 

1. Clearly frivolous.
The Eleventh Circuit has outlined three factors for district courts to consider when deciding frivolity: (1) whether the plaintiff established a prima facie case; (2) whether the defendant offered to settle; and (3) whether the trial court dismissed the case prior to trial or held a full-blown trial on the merits. Head, 62 F.3d at 356 . Eisai argued that (1) Relator's complaint was dismissed more than once, such that Relator never established a prima facie case; (2) Eisai never offered any money to settle this case and opposed going to court-imposed mediation while the motion to dismiss [*12] was pending; and (3) the Court dismissed the case with prejudice before a trial on the merits. However, "determinations regarding frivolity are to be made on a case-by-case basis." Sullivan v. School Bd., 713 F.2d 1182 (5th Cir. 1983).
Eisai argued that Relator's Second and Third Amended Complaints were frivolous, because Relator filed them knowing that he lacked the factual basis required by Judge Ungaro's June 2011 Order and the case law, because he did not have personal knowledge of a false claim having been submitted to the government as a result of any action by Eisai. In this regard, Eisai argued that the law in the Eleventh Circuit was well-established with respect to the pleading requirements under the FCA. Eisai further argued that Relator's counsel were experienced in qui tam actions, such that they should have been familiar with the pleading requirements for asserting a false claims violation. Moreover, the June 2011 Order dismissing the First Amended Complaint put Relator on notice of the deficiencies in his complaint. Relator was told that he needed to specify in his amended complaint the "who, what, where, and when" of the alleged fraud in order to state a cause of action under the FCA. Instead of pleading same, Relator argued that the court should apply a relaxed standard. However, Judge Ungaro found that, even under the relaxed standard, the "who," "when," and "how" must be plead. Relator argued that he reasonably advocated a more relaxed standard based upon both Eleventh Circuit precedent holding that Rule 9(b) may be satisfied where there is some indicia of reliability that false claims were submitted, and that Rule 9(b) may be relaxed where the relator was an insider, the scheme was nationwide, or the details of the fraud were mostly within the defendant's knowledge. Relator argued in good faith that he satisfied all of these grounds. According to Relator, he took the same position that the Justice Department and the Solicitor General have taken in other FCA cases.
In U.S. ex rel. Cullins v. Astra, Inc., No. 09-60696-CIV, [2010 BL 173523], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 87669 , 2010 WL 3008833 , at *3 (S.D. Fla. Jul. 28, 2010), this Court relied upon United States ex rel. Gross v. AIDS Research Alliance-Chicago, No. 01-C-8182, 2004 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 7302 , 2004 WL 905952 (N.D. Ill. Apr. 27, 2004), to find that the plaintiff's claims were not clearly frivolous where the court had granted leave to file an amended complaint. The court in Gross granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the plaintiff's second amended complaint with prejudice for failing to state a claim upon which relief could be granted. 2004 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 7302 , 2004 WL 905952 at *9. However, the court did not grant attorney's fees under § 3730 , because it did not find the plaintiff's suit to be vexatious or frivolous. 2004 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 7302 [ WL] at *10. Specifically, the court reasoned that granting the plaintiff leave to file the second amended complaint was evidence that the plaintiff's claims were not frivolous. Id. The Cullins court found that the plaintiff's claims were not clearly frivolous where the court granted the plaintiff leave to file her Second Amended Complaint after her Amended Complaint was dismissed without prejudice. [2010 BL 173523], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 87669 , 2010 WL 3008833 , at *3. Here, the Court granted Relator leave [*13] to amend the complaint as well.
Relator next argued that this action could not be found frivolous when the evidence supporting Relator's sealed Motion for Partial Summary Judgment showed that Eisai knowingly provided the OAR Program kickbacks, thus proving one of the main schemes alleged in the Third Amended Complaint. Relator argued that, given the stakes and the equities, it was vital for the Court to review the summary judgment motion. The court never reached the substantive arguments raised in the motion for summary judgment. Therefore, the undersigned will not rely upon those allegations in determining entitlement to costs.
The undersigned finds that the Relator's position regarding the pleading standard to be applied was not frivolous. Although Relator's claims were not ultimately successful, the undersigned finds that they were not so lacking in arguable merit so as to be clearly frivolous.
2. Vexatious/Harassment.
"[A]n action is 'clearly vexatious' or 'brought primarily for purposes of harassment' when the plaintiff pursues the litigation with an improper purpose, such as to annoy or embarrass the defendant." Bane, [2009 BL 91256], 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 35771 , 2009 WL 1148632 , at *5; Cullins, [2010 BL 173523], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 87669 , 2010 WL 3008833 , at *4. Such conduct may be evident in, inter alia, actions that deliberately delay the proceedings, that attempt to re-litigate a previously decided claim against the same defendant, the raising of new allegations in an effort to circumvent the arguments in a defendant's motion to dismiss, or where the government's undisputed prior knowledge of information alleged to constitute fraud defeated any inference of a false claim. Id. "'The distinction between vexatious conduct and harassment turns on the intentions of the plaintiff. Although the word 'harassment' suggests bad faith on the part of the plaintiff, the term 'vexatious' in no way implies that the plaintiff's subjective bad faith is a necessary prerequisite to a fee award against him.'" Id. (internal citations omitted).
Eisai argued that the Relator engaged in vexatious conduct by filing amended complaints that failed to cure the noted deficiencies, while pursuing discovery and motion practice that unnecessarily increased the cost of the litigation. Eisai also pointed to the September 28, 2012, hearing on the motion to dismiss the Third Amended Complaint wherein Relator could not identify the particulars of the alleged fraud. According to Eisai, whether under a subjective or objective standard, there was no basis to believe that the Third Amended Complaint, which suffered from the same deficiencies as the First Amended Complaint, would survive dismissal.
Relator argued that it did not pursue this action for an improper purpose. Although Eisai cast Relator as a disgruntled employee who, after settling a wrongful termination suit against Eisai, prosecuted this action to extract more money from Eisai, at no time did Relator make a settlement demand from Eisai. Relator claimed that he brought the employment law action to resolve his own claim for damages arising from his termination and brought the instant [*14] action for the Government, believing Eisai had unlawfully caused it to part with funds. Moreover, Relator noted that whistleblowers were incentivized through the FCA to file qui tarn suits that would expose such wrongdoing. Finally, Relator argued that he and his counsel "lost their shirts" in this case. As noted in Cullins, Relator's expenses can demonstrate his good faith belief in the merits of the case and belie any ulterior purposes, such as harassment of Eisai. [2010 BL 173523], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 87669 , 2010 WL 3008833 , at *4.
The undersigned finds that, based upon this record, there is insufficient evidence to establish that Relator brought this action primarily to harass Eisai or that Relator pursued the litigation with an improper purpose, such as to annoy or embarrass Eisai. Indeed, Judge Williams noted that, although Relator had failed to establish his FCA claims, there may still be allegations falling outside the purview of the FCA for which Eisai may be subject to liability under other statutes. (ECF No. 232) at 38. Clearly, the Court was not of the opinion that Relator's claims were frivolous or vexatious. See Cullins, [2010 BL 173523], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 87669 , 2010 WL 3008833 , at *4 (denying attorney's fees under the FCA upon finding that the relator's claims were neither clearly frivolous nor clearly vexation or for the primary purpose of harassment where the court had dismissed the amended complaint without prejudice with leave to re-file); Gross, 2004 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 7302 , 2004 WL 905952 , at *10 (denying attorney's fees under § 3730 because the suit was not vexatious or frivolous although the second amended complaint was dismissed with prejudice for failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted). Accordingly, on this record, the undersigned finds no evidence to support an award of attorney's fees against Relator.
B. 28 U.S.C. § 1927 .
Eisai also sought fees under § 1927 from Messrs. Grover, Lehrman, and Gitkin only-not their law firms and not Relator.
Section 1927 provides that any attorney "who so multiplies the proceedings in any case unreasonably and vexatiously may be required by the court to satisfy personally the excess costs, expenses, and attorneys' fees reasonably incurred because of such conduct." 28 U.S.C. § 1927 . Courts may impose sanctions upon finding that (1) an attorney has engaged in "unreasonable and vexatious" conduct; (2) the "unreasonable and vexatious" conduct multiplied the proceedings; and (3) the dollar amount of the sanction bears a financial nexus to the excess proceedings such that the sanction does not exceed the costs, expenses, and attorney's fees reasonably incurred because of the sanctionable conduct. Hudson v. Int'l Computer Negotiations, Inc., 499 F.3d 1252 , 1262 (11th Cir. 2007)(quoting Peterson v. BMI Refractories, 124 F.3d 1386 , 1396 (11th Cir. 1997)). However, the statute does not operate as a catch-all provision for sanctioning objectionable conduct by counsel. Peterson, 124 F.3d at 1396 . There must be a connection between counsel's objectionable conduct and multiplication of proceedings that would not have occurred otherwise. Id . 
An attorney "unreasonably and vexatiously" multiplies proceedings within the meaning of § 1927 "only when the attorney's conduct is so egregious that it is 'tantamount [*15] to bad faith.'" Amlong & Amlong P.A. v. Denny's, Inc., 500 F.3d 1230 , 1239 (11th Cir. 2007) (quoting Avirgan v. Hull, 932 F.2d 1572 , 1582 (11th Cir. 1991)). Such bad faith requires more than negligent conduct or lack of merit.  Id. at 1241-42 ; Schwartz v. Millon Air, Inc., 341 F.3d 1220 , 1225 (11th Cir. 2003) ("For sanctions under section 1927 to be appropriate, something more than a lack of merit is required) (citation omitted). "Bad faith is the touchstone. Section 1927 is not about mere negligence." Schwartz, 341 F.3d at 1225 (internal citations and quotations omitted). Bad faith is measured by the attorney's objective conduct. Amlong & Amlong, 500 F.3d at 1239-40 . Although the court may impose sanctions even if the attorney acted without the specific purpose or intent to multiply the proceedings, it is important to consider the attorney's subjective state of mind.  Id. at 1241-42 . Bad faith may be found where an attorney "knowingly or recklessly" pursues frivolous claims or needlessly obstructs the litigation of non-frivolous claims. Id. at 1242 ; Schwartz, 341 F.3d at 1225 .
Upon review, the undersigned finds that the conduct cited by Eisai, as noted herein, is insufficient to support a fee award against Relator's counsel under 28 U.S.C. § 1927 .
1. Unreasonable and vexatious conduct.
Eisai argued that courts have found unreasonable and vexatious conduct where an attorney filed and prosecuted factually or legally unsupported claims, or where an attorney failed to abandon a claim once it became apparent that the evidence would not support it. Eisai relied on Avirgan v. Hull, wherein the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the district court's award of attorney's fees and costs when the plaintiffs' attorneys refused to abandon a case after discovery made clear that no evidence existed to substantiate the complaint's allegations. 932 F.2d at 1582 . Eisai argued that the Court's June 21, 2011 Order dismissing the First Amended Complaint set forth in detail what Relator needed to plead in order to survive a motion to dismiss. However, Relator failed to do so in the subsequent amended pleadings.
The undersigned finds that there is no indication that the filing of the amended complaints or the discovery in this case were unreasonable or vexatious. Judge Williams noted that Relator had the opportunity to litigate his claims of fraud but was unable to establish a sufficient link between Eisai, doctor, and government programs. (ECF No. 232) at 38. However, she noted that it was not known whether the allegations were true or whether another insider could have pursued the case. Id. At no time did the Court intimate that Relator's counsel had engaged in any unreasonable or vexatious conduct with respect to this litigation.
2. Multiplying proceedings.
Multiplication of proceedings includes, but is not limited to, abuse of discovery tactics, reassertion of meritless claims, and any other conduct that results in lengthening the proceedings. American Honda Motor Co., Inc. v. Motorcycle Information Network, Inc., No. 5:04-cv-12-Oc-10GRJ, [2008 BL 68484], 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 97949 , 2008 WL 906739 , at * 13 (M.D. Fla. Apr. 2, 2008). Eisai argued that Relator's filing of four unsupported complaints, as well as requiring Eisai to engage in extensive and expensive discovery and motions practice was exactly the type [*16] of conduct § 1927 was designed to deter.
Eisai pointed to Relator's refusal to agree to a stay pending ruling on the motion to dismiss and insistence that discovery go forward as evidence of improper conduct. According to Eisai, between December 16, 2011, and February 29, 2012, it undertook a company-wide search of documents, ultimately resulting in the production of about 2 million pages of text-searchable documents, along with a privilege log. Because Eisai knew that complying with the discovery deadline of February 2012 would be costly, Eisai's counsel attempted unsuccessfully to reach agreement with Relator to stay discovery pending ruling on the motion to dismiss, or to narrow the discovery requests. Eisai argued further that the third-party discovery failed to produce any evidence supporting Relator's claims. Notwithstanding, Relator pressed on which forced Eisai to prepare for and defend several depositions at great expense.
Next, Eisai argued that Relator multiplied the proceedings by engaging in unnecessary motion practice. Relator filed motions requesting that the Court delay ruling on Eisai's motion to dismiss arguing, in part, that it would be prejudicial if his anticipated motion for summary judgment was not considered at the same time as Eisai's motion to dismiss. See (ECF No. 172, 216). Moreover, instead of complying with the expert disclosure deadline, Relator provided Eisai with the names and addresses of five putative experts, along with the curricula vitae for four of them, but failed to include any other information required by Rule 26. On the day his expert reports were due, Relator filed a motion seeking a nine-month extension of all pre-trial deadlines, but not the mediation deadline. (ECF No. 202).
Relator argued that he did not multiply the proceedings and that he properly engaged in court-mandated discovery. Judge Ungaro had denied Eisai's motion to stay discovery pending ruling on the motion to dismiss. Not only did the local rules provide that a motion to dismiss would not delay discovery, but discovery was ordered by the Court. Thus, it cannot be said that it was Relator's fault that discovery proceeded. Relator's argument in this regard is well-taken.
Finally, Relator argued that the court should not find bad faith where he was granted leave to amend the pleadings. Even though the Third Amended Complaint was dismissed with prejudice, Judge Williams' 39-page Order of dismissal represented a lengthy, detailed analysis of the issues presented, such that this action cannot be considered frivolous. (ECF No. 232). Moreover, the Eleventh Circuit granted oral argument on appeal tending to indicate that the case had some merit. Relator argued that he pursued this case in good faith, as evidenced by the fact that Relator's counsel spent a considerable amount of money in pursuing this FCA case. In this regard, Relator argued that the fact he was able to obtain counsel to represent him indicated that his claim was not clearly frivolous.
The undersigned is persuaded by Relator's arguments. Considering [*17] the circumstances in this case, the undersigned finds that there is no basis in this record upon which to award attorney's fees to Eisai pursuant to § 1927 . There is no indication that the filing of the amended complaints, the discovery, or the motion practice in this case were vexatious or multiplied the proceedings.
C. Court's inherent power.
Finally, Eisai argued that the Court should exercise its inherent power and sanction Relator and his attorneys and their firms for their bad faith conduct. Relator argued that a fee award against a law firm required a specific finding that the firm willfully abused judicial process by engaging in subjective bad faith conduct and no such evidence had been presented.
Courts have the inherent power to assess attorney's fees and costs as a fine when a losing party has "acted in bad faith, vexatiously, wantonly or for oppressive reasons." Chambers v. NASCO, Inc., 501 U.S. 32 , 45-46 , 111 S.Ct. 2123 , 2133 , 115 L.Ed.2d 27 (1991)(citations omitted); Kreager v. Solomon & Flanagan, P.A., 775 F.2d 1541 , 1543 (11th Cir. 1985). Grounds for a bad faith award exist when the plaintiff brings a groundless suit and forces the defendant to expend time and effort conducting its defense. Gordon v. Heimann, 715 F.2d 531 , 539 (11th Cir. 1983).
Having found no grounds to award Eisai attorney's fees under the FCA or § 1927 , the undersigned finds that there is no basis to entertain a fee award under the Court's inherent power.
The undersigned notes that, in this case, Judge Ungaro dismissed without prejudice the First Amended Complaint, with leave to file an amended complaint. (ECF No. 61). She found that Relator stated a claim under Rule 12(b)(6) , but that his claims were not pleaded with the degree of particularity required by Rule 9(b) , because Relator failed to describe specifically what Eisai did to cause false claims to be submitted, omitted critical details of claim presentation, and did not describe how the alleged kickbacks "crossed the line from legal conduct in compliance with federal statutes to illegal kickbacks." (ECF No. 61). In dismissing the Third Amended Complaint, Judge Williams found that, although Relator had expanded his pleading and raised additional arguments to support his FCA claims, the complaint failed to provide the requisite particularity to survive dismissal. (ECF No. 232). Judge Williams emphasized that her limited review of the case left many questions unanswered.  Id. at p. 37. She noted that it was not known whether Relator's allegations were actually true, or whether another insider or the government could have pursued this case. Id. Moreover, she noted that there may still be other allegations falling outside the purview of the FCA which may subject Eisai to liability under other statutes by other parties.  Id. at 3 8. Finally, Judge Williams noted that Relator had the opportunity to litigate his claims of fraud but was unable to establish a sufficient link between Eisai, doctors, and government programs. Id. Given these circumstances, there is simply no basis upon which to base a fee award to Eisai.
Conclusion 
Accordingly, it is hereby RESPECTFULLY RECOMMENDED as follows:
1. That Defendant Eisai [*18] Inc.'s Motion to Tax Costs Against Relator Michael Keeler, and Bill of Costs (ECF No. 237) be Granted-in-part and Denied-in-part, and Eisai be awarded the amount of $31,365.00 in costs. In this connection, Relator may file substantial financial documentation of his inability to pay for the Court's consideration within five (5) days. The undersigned recommends that any determination as to a cost judgment on behalf of Eisai be stayed pending consideration of any such submission by Relator.
2. That Defendant Eisai Inc.'s Motion for Entitlement to Attorneys Fees and Costs (ECF No. 255) be Denied.
Pursuant to S.D. Fla. Magistrate Rule 4(b) , the parties may serve and file written objections to this Recommendation with the Honorable Kathleen M. Williams, United States District Judge for the Southern District of Florida, within fourteen (14) days after being served with a copy of this Report and Recommendation. Failure to file timely objections shall bar the parties from attacking on appeal any factual findings contained herein. RTC v. Hallmark Builders, Inc., 996 F.2d 1144 (11th Cir. 1993); LoConte v. Dugger, 847 F.2d 745 (11th Cir. 1988).
RESPECTFULLY RECOMMENDED in Chambers, at Miami, Florida, this 30 day of March 2015.
/s/ William C. Turnoff
WILLIAM C. TURNOFF 
United States Magistrate Judge

6
Section 1920 provides, in part:
A judge or clerk of any court of the United States may tax as costs the following:
(1) Fees of the clerk and marshal;
(2) Fees of the court reporter for all or any part of the stenographic transcript necessarily obtained for use in the case;
(3) Fees and disbursements for printing and witnesses;
(4) Fees for exemplification and copies of papers necessarily obtained for use in the case;
(5) Docket fees under section 1923 of this title;
(6) Compensation of court appointed experts, compensation of interpreters, and salaries, fees, expenses, and costs of special interpretation services under section 1828 of this title.
28 U.S.C. §1920 .

FRED DEVRIES, etc. et al., individually and on behalf of others sim ilarly situated, Plaintiffs, VS. MORGAN STANLEY & CO. LLC, f/k/a Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc., etc. et al., Defendants.

Shavitz, Shavitz Law Group, Boca Raton, FL; Paolo Chagas Meireles, Shavitz Law Group, P.A., Boca Raton, FL; Susan Hilary Stern, Shavitz Law Group, P.A., Boca Raton, FL.
For Luke Alfred Carter, Michael Gerard Dietrich, David Harry Elster, Marcia Garren, Zaq Harrison, Melika Jahangiri, Katelyn Margaret Kriesel, Alexander S Rowe, Steven Scott Smith, Virgil Lee Dortch III, Andrew Lerner, Kevin Dean McLenithan, Blair Neller Jr., Christopher Anthony Paganelli, Tiffany C Saunders, Daniel Seghi, Vanessa Sergeon, Timothy John Shannon, Garrett Pierce Smith, Shaan Wadhwani, Gregory Whitehead, Alexander Kane Assaf, Alexander Steven Carter, Dennis Daniel Crowley, Alexander Love Hinson Jr, Kent Earl Kopen, Nathan Robert Logan, Gary Joseph Cwik, Agnes Yadira Aponte, Charles Cole III, Kine A Corder, Luke Dowd, Mary Ly Gilbert, Zachary Hurd, James Michael Kahn[*4] , Rawad Yasser Kassem, Alejandro Alex Pulido, Michael Paul Rutledge, Lance C Schmidt, Raymond Sosa, Bruce Andrew Van Meter, Stuart Martin Wilson, Brynn Hugh Dietz, Nicholas Stephen Jewczyn, Irma Yolanda Kallay, Robert Todd Lincoln, Ritika Malik, Jeremy Pursch, Richard Nelson Valle, Jonathon C Leib, Bernard Morris Aller, Gregory DePaul Whelan, Stephen Edward Dilanian, Adam Pierce Kelly, John B Wilson, Jessica Hawkins, Robert Leonard, Richard Albert Graney, Bradley Frank Karp, Kevin Kelly, Desi Pena, Ronni Y Reiburn, Patrick Kilts, Roberto Caudillo, Alison Nicole Wiener, Michael Gomez, Steven Dwight Baker, Eric Bardo, Amie Lorraine Cherry, Michael Chong, Alan Theodore Dehesa, Daniel Gordon Edmondson, Justin Thomas Ghiglia, Scott Bradley Janzen, Denise Shafer, Steven Douglas Woodlock, Thomas Zubrycki, Bethany E Bristow, Julie Anne Davis, Joseph James Smick, Robert Thomas Kennedy, Jeffrey Michael Whitt, Fauzia Kurjee, Gregory Wayne Beverly, Jeffrey SC Butler, Gian Frederick Giusti, Torrance Christian Holton, Gordon Stuart Rhoads, Colleen Anika Rhodd, Tawnya Christine Schwartz, David V Sokolovsky, Joanne Wagner, Rachel Louise Carlsen, James Henderson, David E Do, Shuvam Bhaumik, Phillip Womack Davis, Denise Marinacci, Ricardo C Vinagre, Raymond K. Jew, Colin Peter Figueroa, Robert Chase Lee, Mauricio Aimo, Manuel A. Quinones, Francisco Edward Acevedo, Caren Yvonne Bryant, Kevin J. Flynn, Gregg Winter, John Vandenberg, Jeryne Peterson, Lynda G. Schultz, Kate Becker, Cameron Blair, David Robbins Mack, Chance Kenneth Vogel, David Dexter Oxley, George Kritis, Robert Formisano, Robert Joseph Duffy III, Louay Antoine Elhadj, Corey David Loxen, Landon J. Weeks, Dina R Floyd, Tamara Stein, William Thomas Harper, Camilo Ramirez, Amy Gac, Kyle Kenji Yoneshige, Jeffrey Jordan Bouchard, Melissa Beth Thacker, Philip Alan Wilson, Denanne Michelle Heil, Sarah Leners, William Chung Liu Jr., Marc Ciccarelli, Hung Tran, Thaddeus Malcolm Brown, Marc Frank, Andrew Joseph Iadeluca, Travis Brandon Lancaster, Diane Renee Turnbull, Jeffrey Kenneth Corey, Whan Soo Rim, Barbara Langford Davis, Douglas Clifton Stewart, Mark Sterling Howe, Margaret Kathryn Acosta, Anthony Nicholas Picozzi, Jason Ellis, Keisha Diane Johnson, Rafik Daniel Fouad, Lori Ann Shizuko Hamano, Joshua J Caltrider, Roland C Salmi, David Bernard Reed, Emanuele Umberto Buonamici, Dino Mazzarelli, Patrick John Wymes, Robert Q Buckles, Andrea Tony Guarascio, Vera Lui, Abbe Frances Rice, Paul Hoshko, Steven James Freed, Teresa A Hill, Dustin LeRoy, Brian Jon Wiest, Gayle Goodwin, Daniel Conner, David Cummins, Jonathan Bach, Dominique Richards, Riley Clark, Plaintiffs: Paolo Chagas Meireles, Shavitz Law Group, P.A., Boca Raton, FL.
For Stephan Michael Bernarsky, Plaintiff: Gregg I. Shavitz, Shavitz Law Group, Boca Raton, FL; Paolo Chagas Meireles, Susan Hilary Stern, Shavitz Law Group, P.A., Boca Raton, FL.
For Janine Natoli, Plaintiff: Fran L. Rudich, Seth R. Lesser, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Klafter, Olsen & Lesser, LLP, Rye Brook, NY; Michael John Palitz, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Shavitz Law Group, LLP, Boca Raton, FL; Gregg I. Shavitz, LEAD ATTORNEY, [*5] Shavitz Law Group, Boca Raton, FL; Susan Hilary Stern, LEAD ATTORNEY, Paolo Chagas Meireles, Shavitz Law Group, P.A., Boca Raton, FL.
For Jason L. Kitchen, Plaintiff: Paolo Chagas Meireles, LEAD ATTORNEY, Shavitz Law Group, P.A., Boca Raton, FL. 
For Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, formerly known as Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated, Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC, Morgan Stanley, Defendants: Thomas Anton Linthorst, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, LLP, Princeton, NJ; Mark Edward Zelek, Morgan Lewis & Bockius, Miami, FL; Voula EllenAlexopoulo Liroff, Miami, FL.
WILLIAM MATTHEWMAN, UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE.

WILLIAM MATTHEWMAN 
ORDER DENYING PLAINTIFFS' MOTION TO COMPEL [DE 219]
THIS CAUSE is before the Court upon Plaintiffs' Motion to Compel. [DE 219]. Defendants, Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC, and Morgan Stanley, filed a Response. [DE 224]. These matters were referred to the undersigned by United States District Judge Kenneth A. Marra [DE 43], and they are now ripe for review.
This is an FLSA action for unpaid overtime wages. Plaintiffs are current and former pre-production Financial Analyst Assistants ("FAAs"), who assert that Defendants failed to pay them for all of their hours worked, including overtime hours.
In their Motion, Plaintiffs ask this Court to order Defendants to provide additional electronically-stored information ("ESI"). Specifically, Plaintiffs ask Defendants to perform and produce additional ESI searches on additional records custodians above the branch level and also asks Defendants to produce training records. [DE 219].
I. General Discovery Principles 
"It is well established that the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 'strongly favor full discovery whenever possible.'" Adelman v. Boy Scouts of Am., 276 F.R.D. 681 , 688 (S.D. Fla. 2011) (quoting Farnsworth v. Procter & Gamble Co., 758 F.2d 1545 , 1547 (11th Cir. 1985)). "Rule 26(b) therefore permits a party to obtain discovery of 'any matter, not privileged, that is relevant to the claim or defense of any party.'" Id . (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b) ). "The Courts have long held that relevance for discovery purposes is much broader than relevance for trial purposes." Dunkin' Donuts, Inc. v. Mary's Donuts, Inc., No. 01-0393, 2001 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 25204 , 2001 WL 34079319 , at *2 (S.D. Fla. Nov. 1, 2001). "Discovery should ordinarily be allowed under the concept of relevancy unless it is clear that the information sought has no possible bearing on the subject matter of the action." Id. 
Pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) , "a court may limit discovery of relevant material if it determines that the discovery sought is unreasonably cumulative or duplicative, or obtainable from some other source that is more convenient, less burdensome, or less expensive, or the burden or expense of the proposed discovery outweighs the likely benefit." Henderson v. Holiday CVS, L.L.C., 269 F.R.D. 682 , 686 (S.D. Fla. 2010). "The party resisting discovery has a heavy burden of showing why the requested discovery should not be permitted." Id . "To meet this burden, the party resisting discovery must demonstrate specifically how the objected-to request is unreasonable or otherwise unduly burdensome." Id . "It is settled that, electronically stored information is discoverable under Rule 34(a) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure [*6] ." Wynmoor Community Council, Inc. v. QBE Ins. Corp., 280 F.R.D. 681 , 685 (S.D. Fla. 2012).
II. Additional ESI from Additional Custodians 
Plaintiffs ask that Defendants produce additional ESI from their "human resources personnel, corporate level employees, or any management level employees of Defendants which refer or relate to hours worked, overtime or off the clock work by any Discovery Opt-In during their employment as FAAs." [DE 219, p. 2]. Plaintiffs maintain that these individuals—who are above the branch level—will have relevant and discoverable ESI pertaining to Defendants' "policies, procedures and practices regarding the off-the-clock study time by pre-production FAAs." [DE 219, p. 2]. Plaintiffs argue that "Defendants should be required to search and produce emails for human resources personnel, corporate level employees, or any management level employees of Defendants using the ESI protocols and search terms the Parties previously agreed to apply to the email searches for the branch level personnel."
Defendants oppose Plaintiffs' request for additional ESI, explaining that they are "already conducting expensive and time-consuming ESI at Plaintiff's request." [DE 224, p. 1]. Furthermore, Defendants maintain that Plaintiffs' requests are "vague and ambiguous, overbroad, and unduly burdensome." [DE 22, p.3]. Defendants argue that Plaintiffs' requests for additional ESI from "human resources personnel," "corporate level employees," and "management employees" are so vague and overbroad that they cannot determine to whom Plaintiffs are actually referring. [DE 224, p. 3]. Defendants also take issue with the fact that Plaintiffs failed to place any time limits on their requests. [DE 224, p. 3]. Moreover, Defendants take issue with the fact that Plaintiffs failed to justify their request for additional ESI; Defendants point out that Plaintiffs have not demonstrated the likelihood that individuals above the branch level would have any information relevant to their claims. [DE 224, p. 4].
The Court denies Plaintiffs' request for additional ESI from custodians above the branch level. As they point out in their Motion, Defendants are already engaged in large-scale ESI production, involving at least 166,000 documents and likely more. [DE 224, p. 2]. The Court finds that Plaintiffs' request for additional ESI is unduly burdensome, overbroad, and overly vague. The Court further finds that the considerable burden Defendants would have to bear in producing the additional ESI Plaintiffs request would far outweigh the benefits.
In support of their argument, Plaintiffs cite Martinez-Hernandez v. Butterball, LLC, [2010 BL 114309], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 50246 , 2010 WL 2089251 (E.D.N.C. May 21, 2010). However, Martinez-Hernandez does not support Plaintiffs' position and is factually inapposite from this case. In Martinez-Hernandez, the Court simply found that certain individuals may be sources of relevant ESI—the Court did not find, as a general rule, that unnamed persons above the branch level of a company should or could possess relevant ESI to support a Plaintiff's claim. Martinez-Hernandez[*7] , [2010 BL 114309], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 50246 , 2010 WL 2089251 , at *4-5. Martinez-Hernandez does not support production of additional ESI from unidentified individuals above the branch level in this case.
III. Training Records 
Additionally, Plaintiffs ask this Court to order Defendants to produce the training materials used by pre-production FAAs. [DE 219, p. 3]. According to Plaintiffs, these materials are relevant to their FLSA claims for three reasons: first, "they would likely include materials regarding the requirements for pre-production FAAs to pass certain examinations, as well as the study-time expected and required to pass such examinations;" second, the training materials' uniformity would further support Plaintiffs argument that they are similarly situated, further buttressing their position that that case should proceed as a class action under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 ; and third, "the sheer volume of the materials is relevant to the amount of time Plaintiffs were expected to study in order to pass their required exams."
Defendants oppose Plaintiffs' request for FAA "training materials." Defendants maintain that this request is unduly burdensome and overbroad, as Plaintiffs fail to specify with reasonable particularity what sorts of "training materials" they seek. [DE 224, p. 5]. Defendants also note that "training materials" is not an official or recognized term. [DE 224, p. 5]. Defendants also point out that they have already produced "Knowledge Link" records which document the classes the second-round Discovery Opt-In Plaintiffs took while training in the pre-production phase of the FAA program. Defendants maintain that providing more information would be unduly burdensome, as "they would have to track down the different materials used by each individual, including different versions of particular texts, as not all Discovery Opt-Ins went through the program in the same year." [DE 224, p. 5]. Finally, Defendants assert that having additional training records would not help support Plaintiffs' argument that the case should proceed as a class action, as not all FAAs took the same training courses. [DE 224, p. 5].
The Court denies Plaintiffs' request for "training materials." In support of their argument, Plaintiffs rely on Henderson, supra . However, that case does not support Plaintiff's position as to the relevance of the training documents generally; Henderson only made a fact-specific finding that documents relating to the training program in that case should be produced. The Court further notes that, in Henderson, Plaintiffs requested a specific batch of training documents relating to the "SMD training program." Henderson, 269 F.R.D. at 691 . In this case, Plaintiffs fail to make such a specific request, instead requesting "training documents." "Training documents" could refer to a myriad of different materials, and it would place an undue burden on Defendants to have to entertain such an overly broad and unduly burdensome discovery request. Furthermore, as Defendants note in their Motion [DE 224], Defendants have already produced the Knowledge Link records; in light of this, production of additional "training [*8] materials" would only prove to be redundant and unnecessary. Any benefit to Plaintiffs from the production of "training materials" would not outweigh the great burden Defendants would have to shoulder in producing such a voluminous amount of information.
In light of the foregoing, it is hereby
ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that Plaintiff's Motion to Compel [DE 219] is DENIED.
DONE AND ORDERED in Chambers this 7th day of April, 2015 at West Palm Beach, in the Southern District of Florida.
/s/ William Matthewman
WILLIAM MATTHEWMAN
UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE

Majority Opinion > 
U.S. District Court, Southern District of Florida
  

PRAGMATUS AV, LLC, Plaintiff, v. CITRIX SYSTEMS, INC., Defendant. 
  

0:11-cv-62484-PAS 
July 18, 2012 

ANDREA M. SIMONTON, Magistrate Judge. 
ORDER REGARDING ELECTRONICALLY STORED INFORMATION
Based upon the Parties' Joint Notice (DE # 50), and a review of the record, the Court ORDERS as follows:
1. This Order supplements all other discovery rules and orders. It streamlines Electronically Stored Information ("ESI") production to promote a "just, speedy, and inexpensive determination" of this action, as required by Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 1 .
2. This Order may be modified by stipulation of the parties for good cause. If the parties cannot resolve any disagreements regarding any modifications, the parties shall submit their competing proposals and a summary of their dispute pursuant to all applicable rules or standing orders.
3. Costs will be shifted for disproportionate ESI production requests pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26 . Likewise, a party's nonresponsive or dilatory discovery tactics will be cost-shifting considerations.
4. A party's meaningful compliance with this Order and efforts to promote efficiency and reduce costs will be considered in cost-shifting determinations.
5. General ESI production requests under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 34 and 45 shall not include metadata absent a showing of good cause. However, fields showing the date and time that the document was sent and received, as well as the complete distribution list, shall generally be included in the production.
6. General ESI production requests under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 34 and 45 shall not include email or other forms of electronic correspondence (collectively "email"). To obtain email parties must propound specific email production requests.
7. Email production requests shall only be propounded for specific issues, rather than general discovery of a product or business.
8. Email production requests shall be phased to occur after the parties have exchanged initial disclosures and basic documentation about the patents, the prior art, the accused instrumentalities, and the relevant finances. While this provision does not require the production of such information, the Court encourages prompt and early production of this information to promote efficient and economical streamlining of the case. The exception to paragraph 8 is that Citrix will produce emails related to its knowledge and/or notice of the patents-in-suit or related patents, if any such emails exist after a reasonable search, by August 14, 2012, so that Pragmatus may review these materials in advance of the September 14, 2012, deadline to amend the pleadings.
9. The parties shall cooperate to identify the proper custodians, proper search terms and proper timeframe.
10. Each requesting party shall limit its email production requests to a total of five custodians per producing party for all such requests. The parties may jointly agree to modify this limit without the Court's leave. The Court shall consider contested requests for up to five additional custodians per producing party, upon showing a distinct need based on the size, complexity, and [*2] issues of this specific case. Should a party serve email production requests for additional custodians beyond the limits agreed to by the parties or granted by the Court pursuant to this paragraph, the requesting party shall bear all reasonable costs caused by such additional discovery.
11. Each requesting party shall limit its email production requests to a reasonable set of search terms per custodian per party to be agreed upon by the parties prior to any searching being conducted. The parties may jointly agree to additional search terms without the Court's leave. The Court shall consider contested requests for additional search terms per custodian, upon showing a distinct need based on the size, complexity, and issues of this specific case. The search terms shall be narrowly tailored to particular issues. Indiscriminate terms, such as the producing company's name or its product name, are inappropriate unless combined with narrowing search criteria that sufficiently reduce the risk of overproduction. A conjunctive combination of multiple words or phrases (e.g., "computer" and "system") narrows the search and shall count as a single search term. A disjunctive combination of multiple words or phrases (e.g., "computer" or "system") broadens the search, and thus each word or phrase shall count as a separate search term unless they are variants of the same word. Use of narrowing search criteria (e.g., "and," "but not," "w/x") is encouraged to limit the production and shall be considered when determining whether to shift costs for disproportionate discovery. Should a party serve email production requests with search terms beyond the limits agreed to by the parties or granted by the Court pursuant to this paragraph, the requesting party shall bear all reasonable costs caused by such additional discovery.
12. The receiving party shall not use ESI that the producing party asserts is attorney-client privileged or work product protected to challenge the privilege or protection.
13. Pursuant to Federal Rule of Evidence 502(d) , the inadvertent production of a privileged or work product protected ESI is not a waiver in the pending case or in any other federal or state proceeding.
14. The mere production of ESI in a litigation as part of a mass production shall not itself constitute a waiver for any purpose.
15. In the event that production of an ESI document would be impracticable, the producing party shall have the option of producing such document in native format. In all other instances, after initial production of ESI, a party must demonstrate a particularized need for production of that ESI in its native format. In the event that a receiving party requests production of native format ESI, the producing party and the receiving party shall negotiate in good faith about the timing, cost and method of such production. However, nothing in this Paragraph, except pursuant to 16, is to be read as requiring any producing party, absent agreement or court order, to produce ESI in native format. No document produced in native format shall be intentionally manipulated [*3] to change the appearance or substance of the document prior to its collection.
16. Notwithstanding Paragraph 15, to the extent a producing party produces video, animation, audio files or Excel files such documents shall be produced in their native format.
17. To the extent identical copies of an ESI document (i.e., documents with identical hash values) appear in responsive documents, the producing party need only produce one such identical copy for that source.
DONE AND ORDERED.

         General Information
Judge(s)
Andrea M. Simonton
Related Docket(s)
0:11-cv-62484 (S.D. Fla.);
Date Filed
2012-07-18 00:00:00
Court
United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida
Parties
PRAGMATUS AV, LLC, Plaintiff, v. CITRIX SYSTEMS, INC., Defendant.
