Majority Opinion > 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA
  

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, and THE STATE OF FLORIDA, ex rel. MANUEL CHRISTIANSEN and BRIAN ASHTON, Relators, vs. EVERGLADES COLLEGE, INC. d/b/a KEISER UNIVERSITY, Defendant. 
  

CASE NO. 12-60185-CIV-DIMITROULEAS 
November 13, 2014, Entered on Docket November 13, 2014, Decided 
For United States of America, Plaintiff: Dale James Morgado, LEAD ATTORNEY, Morgado, PA, New York, NY; Allison Cendali, United States Department of Justice, Washington, DC; James Alan Weinkle, United States Attorney's Office, Miami, FL; Mitchell Lloyd Feldman, Feldman Law Group, PA, Tampa, FL; R Edward Rosenberg, Coral Gables, FL.
For State of Florida, Plaintiff: Dale James Morgado, LEAD ATTORNEY, Morgado, PA, New York, NY; James Alan Weinkle, United States Attorney's Office, Miami, FL; Mitchell Lloyd Feldman, Feldman Law Group, PA, Tampa, FL; R Edward Rosenberg, Coral Gables, FL.
For Manuel Christiansen, ex rel., Brian Ashton, Plaintiffs: Armando Aguirre Ortiz, LEAD ATTORNEY, Fitapelli & Schaffer LLP, New York, NY; Dale James Morgado, LEAD ATTORNEY, Morgado, PA, New York, NY; David A. Koenigsberg, LEAD ATTORNEY, Menz Bonner Komar & Koenigsberg, LLP, New York, NY; Ira B. Silverstein, LEAD ATTORNEY, The Silverstein Firm, Philadelphia, PA; James Alan Weinkle, United States Attorney's Office, Miami, FL; Mitchell Lloyd Feldman, Feldman Law Group, PA, Tampa, FL; R Edward Rosenberg, Coral Gables, FL.
For Everglades College, Inc., doing business as Keiser University, Defendant: Barry Adam Postman, Justin Canner Sorel, LEAD ATTORNEYS, Cole Scott & Kissane, West Palm Beach, FL; Daniel Marc Schwarz, Cole, Scott, Kissane, P.A., Fort Lauderdale, FL; Scott Allan Cole, Thomas E. Scott, Jr., Cole Scott & Kissane, Miami, FL.
LURANA S. SNOW, UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE.

LURANA S. SNOW 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION
THIS CAUSE is before the Court on Relator's Motion and Incorporated Memorandum of Law in Support of Their Bill of Costs Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1920 and Local Rule 7.3(c) (ECF No. 326), which was referred to United States Magistrate Judge, Lurana S. Snow, for a Report and Recommendation. The motion is fully briefed and ripe for consideration.
This was an action originally brought under the False Claims Act against the Defendant, a university which receives federal funding. In order to establish eligibility for funding, the Defendant agreed that it would not provide any commission, bonus or payment to any employee based on that employee's success in enrolling or securing aid for students. According to the Relators, the Defendant submitted 222,206 false claims, resulting in billions of dollars in damages and civil penalties. After a four-day bench trial, this Court determined that the Defendant had submitted 2 false claims, which had not resulted in any actual damages. The Court imposed a civil penalty of $5,500.00 for each false claim, for a total award of $11,000.00. (ECF No. 318)
The Relators now seek to tax costs against the Defendant in the total amount of $80,495.23, consisting of $350.00 in fees of the clerk; $1,488.36 in fees for service of summons and subpoena; $26,866.05 in fees for transcripts; $1,327,51 in fees for witnesses, and $47,801.11 in fees for exemplification [*2] and copies. The Defendant asserts that no costs should be awarded based on the nominal recovery achieved by the Relators. Alternatively, the Defendant argues that the claimed costs should be reduced by $53,448.84, for a total award of $27,046.39.1 In their Reply Memorandum, the Relators address only the Defendant's contention that no costs should be awarded.
I. DISCUSSION 
A. ENTITLEMENT TO COSTS 
Pursuant to Fed.R.Civ.P. 54(d) and 28 U.S.C. § 1920 , the Court shall award costs to the prevailing party in a lawsuit. Rule 54(d) creates a presumption in favor of awarding costs, which the opposing party must overcome. Manor Healthcare Corp. v. Lomelo, 929 F.2d 633 , 639 (11th Cir. 1991).
Rule 54(d)(1) provides, in pertinent part, "Except when express provision therefor is made either in a statute of the United States or in these rules, costs other than attorneys' fees shall be allowed as of course to the prevailing party, unless the court otherwise directs." Taxable costs are identified in 28 U.S.C. § 1920 :
(1) Fees of the clerk and marshal;
(2) Fees of the court reporter for all or any part of the stenographic transcript necessarily obtained for use in the case;
(3) Fees and disbursements for printing and witnesses;
(4) Fees for exemplification and the costs of making copies of materials where the copies are necessarily obtained for use in the case;
(5) Docket fees under section 1923 of this title;
(6) Compensation of court appointed experts, compensation of interpreters, and salaries, fees, expenses, and costs of special interpretation services under section 1828 of this title.
Rule 54(d) also grants the Court the discretion to refuse to tax costs in favor of the prevailing party. Crawford Fitting Co. v. J.T. Gibbons, Inc., 482 U.S. 437 , 442 , 107 S. Ct. 2494 , 96 L. Ed. 2d 385 (1987).

The Supreme Court has held that a prevailing party is one who prevailed on "any significant issue in the litigation which achieved some of the benefit the parties sought in bringing suit." Tex. State Teachers Ass'n v. Garland Indep. Sch. Dist., 489 U.S. 782 , 791-92 , 109 S. Ct. 1486 , 103 L. Ed. 2d 866 (1989)(internal citations and quotations omitted). In most instances, the litigant in whose favor judgment is rendered is the prevailing party for purposes of Rule 54(d) , and a party who has obtained some relief will be regarded as the prevailing party, even though he has not sustained all of his claims.
In the instant case, the Defendant argues that this Court should exercise its discretion by refusing to award costs to the Relators based on their recovery of only a tiny percentage of the damages and penalties they sought. However, courts in this Circuit consistently have approved shifting costs even if the prevailing party obtains judgment on a fraction of the claims he has advanced. Head v. Medford, 62 F.3d 351 , 355 (11th Cir. 1995); United States v. Mitchell, 580 F.2d 789 , 793-94 (5th Cir. 1978); Doria v. Class Action Services, LLC, 261 F.R.D. 678 , 682 (S.D. Fla. 2009).
It is undisputed that the Relators are the prevailing parties in this case. Although this Court has the discretion to refuse an award of costs, the only basis for such refusal advanced by the Defendant is the relatively modest amount of penalties assessed. The undersigned recommends that this argument be rejected and that costs be awarded under Rule 54(d) .
B. AMOUNT OF COSTS 
1. SERVICE [*3] OF SUMMONS AND SUBPOENA 
The Relators seek an award of $1,488.36 for service of process. The Relators utilized a private process server rather than having the marshal serve witness subpoenas, but this is permissible "provided the rate charged does not exceed the cost of having a U.S. Marshal effect service." EEOC v. W & O, Inc., 213 F. 3d 600 , 624 (11th Cir. 2000). The current rate charged by the U.S. Marshal is $65 per hour (or portion thereof) for each person served, plus travel costs and other out-of-pocket expenses. 28 C.F.R. § 0.114(a)(3) .
The Defendant's only challenge to the requested amount for service of process is the claims for service of trial subpoenas on nine witnesses, two of whom were served twice. The process server charged $80.00 for service on each witness, which included a "rush fee." (ECF No. 326-3 at 6-15) The Relator claimed that the rush was necessitated by the fact that the Defendant initially did not agree to produce these witnesses for trial. The Defendant points out that it was under no obligation to do so, and that the trial date was set more than a year in advance. The undersigned agrees that there was no reason why these witnesses could not have been served early enough to avoid the rush fee, and the claimed costs of service should be reduced by $15.00 for each witness served, for a total reduction of $165.00. Accordingly, the award of costs for service of summons and subpoena should total $1,323.36.
2. TRANSCRIPTS 
The Relators claim a total of $26,866.05 in fees for printed or electronically recorded transcripts necessarily obtained for use in the case. The Defendant contends that this amount should be reduced by $3,562.62 because the costs for expedited production and/or delivery, CD depo litigation packages, electronic delivery and video synchronization are not taxable. The Defendant does not challenge ordinary shipping and delivery costs.
Courts have held that some costs related to depositions and transcripts are not taxable because they were incurred for the convenience of counsel. Klayman v. Freedom's Watch, Inc., [2008 BL 305209], 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 118672 , 2008 WL 4194881 at *5-6 (S.D.Fla., Sept. 12, 2008) (expedited shipping, ASCII disks, e-transcripts, word index, condensed copy, CD-rom, real time hookup, additional DVDs and storage charges not recoverable); RGF Environmental Group v. Activ Tek Environmental Corp., [2010 BL 400113], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 84340 , 2010 WL 3269982 at *3 (S.D.Fla., July 21, 2010) (deposition exhibits, delivery charges, expedited fees, postage costs, condensed transcripts, ASCII disks and copies of transcripts not recoverable); Woods v. Deangelo Marine Exhaust Inc., [2010 BL 400461], 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 110293 , 2010 WL 4116571 at *8 (S.D.Fla., Sept. 27, 2010) (court reporter charges related to the delivery of transcripts, handling of exhibits and CD copies not recoverable).
The undersigned agrees with the Defendant that neither the $35.00 costs of CD depo litigation packages for eight witnesses (ECF No. 326-4 at 3, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18), the $25.00 charge for electronic delivery (ECF No. 326-4 at 6), nor the $1,625.00 for video synchronization (ECF No. 326-4 at 4, 9, 11, 13, 15, 17, 19) are taxable, resulting in a reduction in taxable transcript costs of $1,930.00. Regarding the expedited production costs, identified by the Relators as [*4] totaling $3,257.62 (ECF No. 326 at 7)2, the Relators contend that these costs were reasonably incurred because of the need to refer to these depositions in their motion for summary judgment. The Defendant points out that the deadline for filing motions for summary judgment had been set for more than a year, and two of the expedited depositions were taken after that deadline. The undersigned finds that the need for expedited depositions was created by the Relators themselves, who could have scheduled the depositions in time for ordinary production and delivery. Accordingly, the costs for expediting the depositions is not taxable, resulting in a total award for transcripts of $21,678.43 ($26,866.05 - $1,930.00 - $3,257.62).
3. EXEMPLIFICATION AND COPIES 
The Relators claim a total of $47,801.11 in fees for exemplification and the costs of making copies of materials where the copies are necessarily obtained for use in the case, consisting of $3,989.71 in photocopying charges ($1,698.37 to FedEx Kinkos and for in-house copying and $2,662.20 to third parties); $19,806.90 in litigation database costs, and $26,295.84 for trial consultants and demonstrative video evidence. The Defendant contends that the copying costs should be reduced and that the costs of the litigation database, trial consultants and demonstrative video evidence be disallowed.
A. Photocopying Charges 
The Defendant first contends that the photocopying charges of $951.73 to FedEx Kinkos should be disallowed because the Plaintiff did not provide sufficient information to determine whether these copies were necessarily obtained for use in the case. The Defendant notes that the Relators did identify $311.72 as the costs of making copies for their mediation presentation, but argues that this charge should be disallowed because these copies were obtained for the convenience of counsel and because the Relators have not supplied an invoice reflecting the charge, as required by Local Rule 7.3(c) .
In Scelta v. Delicatessen Support Services, Inc., 203 F. Supp.2d 1328 , 1340 (M.D.Fla., May 13, 2002), the Court noted that under 28U.S.C. § 1920(4) photocopying is compensable if it was necessarily obtained for use in the case. "In making this determination, 'the court should consider whether the prevailing party could have reasonably believed that it was necessary to copy the papers in issue.'" Id. at 1340 , quoting E.E.O.C. v. W & O, Inc., 213 F.3d 600 , 623 (11th Cir. 2000). The court further noted that the burden of establishing entitlement to copying costs lies with the prevailing party, citing Desisto College, Inc. V. Town of Howey-in-the Hills, 718 F.Supp. 906 , 914 (M.D.Fla., Jun. 29, 1989) (holding that the prevailing party must itemize photocopying costs to distinguish compensable copies from those made for the convenience of counsel). The Scelta court held that billing records which merely list "copies" or "photocopies" without any description of the nature or purpose of the photocopying was insufficient. The court acknowledged that while an accounting for each photocopy was implausible, the prevailing party must make some attempt to differentiate recoverable copying costs from non-recoverable [*5] general photocopying expenses. Scelta, 203 F. Supp.2d at 1340 , citing Fulton Fed. Savings & Loan Assoc. of Atlanta v. American Ins. Co., 143 F.R.D. 292 , 300 (N.D. Ga., Aug. 6, 1991).
In their Motion, the Relators state that the cost of copies made by outside vendors were incurred to prepare exhibits and impeachment materials for trial, and to prepare the mediation presentation handouts. The undersigned finds that the Relators have sufficiently identified the nature of the photocopies and have demonstrated that they were necessarily obtained for use in the case. However, the Defendant is correct that the Relators have not provided a receipt for the $311.72 charge for mediation handouts identified in their summary chart. (ECF No. 326-7 at 2) Local Rule 7.3(c) mandates that a bill of costs "shall attach copies of any documentation showing the amount of costs." Therefore, the allowable cost for copies made by FedEx Kinkos must be reduced by $311.72, for a total of $640.01.
Next, the Defendant argues that the claimed cost of $746.64 for in-house printing should be disallowed because the Relators have failed to submit actual invoices or billing records to establish that these copies actually were made. Alternatively, the Defendant suggests that the claimed rate of $.12 per page should be reduced to $.10 per page. Although prevailing parties frequently supply billing records to document charges for in-house copies, the Relators here have supplied a detailed chart listing the dates, subject matter and costs for in-house copying. (ECF No. 326-7 at 4-6). The undersigned finds that this is sufficient to comply with the Local Rule and to establish that the copies were necessarily obtained for use in the case. Accordingly, no reduction of the costs for in-house copying need be made.
Finally, the Defendant asserts that the claimed cost of $2,662.20 paid to third parties for copies should be reduced by $60.63 charged by the Department of Education for review of the documents, minus the $3.00 the Relators erroneously designated as "labor costs" (ECF No. 326-5 at 2) and by the $50.00 cost of Rhonda Fuller's academic records, which were not used at trial. The undersigned agrees that the Relators erroneously claimed $63.63 in labor charges from the Department of Education, while failing to claim $3.00 for copies. Additionally, the Relators have not stated why copies of Rhonda Fuller's academic records were necessarily obtained for use in the case. Therefore, the claimed cost of copies obtained from third parties must be reduced by $110.63, for a total of $2,551.57.
Based on these reductions, the Relators are entitled to an award of $3,938.22 ($640.01 + $746.64 + $2,551.57) for photocopies.
B. ESI Litigation and Database Costs 
The Relators seek an award of $19,806.90 paid to U.S. Legal Support for creating and maintaining a litigation database for the ESI produced in this case. The Defendant responds that there is no support in this Circuit for awarding such payments as costs under § 1920 , and that this cost was incurred for the convenience of counsel. The Defendant points out that it produced ESI as PST (Microsoft Outlook) files which could have been [*6] reviewed in email form and searched using Microsoft Outlook's search function.
The Plaintiff relies on Klayman v. Freedom's Watch, Inc., [2008 BL 305209], 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 118672 , 2008 WL 4194881 at *7 (S.D.Fla., Sept. 12, 2008), where the court stated, "Costs for creating a litigation database, trial evidence presentation, and copies are recoverable under 28 U.S.C. § 1920 where it is necessary due to the extreme complexity of the case and the organization of millions of documents." However, the court in Klayman declined to award such costs because the prevailing party had failed to demonstrate that they were necessary.
The Defendant responds by pointing out that this dicta in Klayman was specifically rejected by the court in Finnerty v. Stiefel Laboratories, Inc., 900 F.Supp.2d 1317 , 1321-22 (S.D.Fla., Oct. 16, 2012), which denied the taxation of costs for the creation and use of a searchable database. In Finnerty, the court pointed out that the magistrate judge's report in Klayman, as well as the case on which the magistrate judge relied, were decided before the 2008 amendment to 28 U.S.C. § 1920(4) enacted to authorize the taxation of the costs of copying any "materials." The Finnerty court noted that this amendment clearly permitted the taxation of costs for making digital copies, but held that
Congress's amendment of Section 1920(4) did not expand taxable costs beyond digital copying to the creation of new, modified, or enhanced digital files. A prevailing party may tax the costs of making digital copies, but "Section 1920(4) does not state that all steps that lead up to the production of copies of materials are taxable."
Id. at 1322 (quoting Race Tires America, Inc. v. Hoosier Racing Tire Corp., 674 F.3d 158 , 165 (3rd Cir. 2012)).

Other courts also have held that the costs of creating a searchable database are not taxable under § 1920 because such costs are incurred for the convenience of counsel. Akanthos Capital Management, LLC v. Compucredit Holdings Corporation, 2 F.Supp.3d 1306 , 1318 (N.D. Ga., Mar. 7, 2014); Fells v. Virginia Dept. of Transportation, 605 F.Supp.2d 740 (E.D.Va., Mar. 25, 2009). The undersigned finds the reasoning of these cases to be persuasive, particularly in the instant case where there was another means of searching ESI available to the Relators which would have obviated the cost of hiring U.S. Legal Support. Therefore, the claimed cost of $19,806.90 for the creation and maintenance of a litigation database should be disallowed.
C. Trial Consultants and Demonstrative Video Evidence 
The Relators request an award of $26,295.44 paid to Decision Quest for the creation of demonstrative exhibit evidence, as well as creating and coordinating the use of video designations for impeachment. They concede that the Eleventh Circuit has not held that such costs are recoverable. The Defendant responds by pointing out that the role of Relators' consultant was simply to play portions of video depositions and highlight portions of exhibits on video screens. The Defendant cites Akanthos, 2 F.Supp.3d at 1313 , for the proposition that the costs of graphics and technology services are not taxable, and Morrison v. Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., 97 F.3d 460 , 465-66 (11th Cir. 1996), holding that costs for equipment rental and fees charged by a videographer for playback [*7] of video depositions at trial may not be taxed.
The undersigned agrees with the Defendant that there is no basis under § 1920(4) to award the costs of fees paid to Decision Quest, and this cost should be disallowed. Therefore, the Relators total award for exemplification and copies is $3,938.22.
4. WITNESS FEES 
The Relators request an award of witness fees in the amount of $1,357.51, which includes a hotel charge of $241.98 for the Relators' expert witness. (ECF No. 326-6 at 15) The Defendant correctly points out that the allowable GSA per diem rate for Fort Lauderdale, Florida on July 14, 2014 was $108.00. (ECF No. 338-1) Therefore, the Relators' claimed witness fees must be reduced by $133.98, for a total taxable amount of $1,223.53.
II. CONCLUSION 
This Court having considered carefully the pleadings, arguments of counsel, and the applicable case law, it is hereby
RECOMMENDED that Relator's Motion and Incorporated Memorandum of Law in Support of Their Bill of Costs Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1920 and Local Rule 7.3(c) (ECF No. 326) be GRANTED, in part, and that costs be awarded to the Relators in the amount of $28,523.54 ($1,323.36 for service of process + $21,678.43 for transcripts + $3938.22 for copies + $1,233.53 for witnesses + $350.00 filing fee).
The parties will have 14 days from the date of being served with a copy of this Report and Recommendation within which to file written objections, if any, with The Honorable William P. Dimitrouleas , United States District Judge. Failure to file objections timely shall bar the parties from attacking on appeal factual findings contained herein. LoConte v. Dugger, 847 F.2d 745 (11th Cir. 1988), cert. denied, 488 U.S. 958 , 109 S. Ct. 397 , 102 L. Ed. 2d 386 (1988); RTC v. Hallmark Builders, Inc., 996 F.2d 1144 , 1149 (11th Cir. 1993).
DONE AND SUBMITTED at Fort Lauderdale, Florida, this 13th day of November, 2014.
/s/ Lurana S. Snow
LURANA S. SNOW
UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE

  
fn 
1
The Defendant does not challenge the claimed $350.00 in fees of the Clerk.

fn 
2
The Defendants contend that an additional $50.00 must be deducted for the expedited delivery fee for the deposition of Peter Crocitto (ECF No. 338 at 5). However, it appears that the Relators included this charge in their total of $3,257.62 (ECF No. 326 at 5 n.4).

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE MIDDLE DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, JACKSONVILLE DIVISION
  

PB PROPERTY MANAGEMENT, INC., JANET HELM, JIMMY JEWELL, DEBORAH L. WAGNER, and STANLEY H. WAGNER, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, Plaintiffs, vs. GOODMAN MANUFACTURING COMPANY, L.P. GOODMAN GLOBAL, INC., and GOODMAN COMPANY, L.P., Defendants. 
  

Case No. 3:12-cv-1366-HES-JBT 
May 12, 2016, Filed May 11, 2016, Decided 
For Pb Property Management, Inc., On behalf of itself and on behalf of all others similarly situated, Plaintiff: April Goodwin, LEAD ATTORNEY, Law Offices of April S. Goodwin, P.A., Largo, FL USA; Christopher Craig Casper, LEAD ATTORNEY, James, Hoyer, Newcomer & Smiljanich, PA, Tampa, FL USA; Elizabeth Lin, LEAD ATTORNEY, The Lin Law Firm, PLC, Brea, CA USA; Jay P. For Janet Helm, individually and on behalf of all similarly situated Consol, Plaintiff: April Goodwin, LEAD ATTORNEY, Law Offices of April S. For Goodman Manufacturing Company, L.P., Goodman Global, Inc., Defendants: Charles M. Trippe, Jr., David Clifford Reeves, Jeffrey Alan Yarbrough, Robert B. Parrish, LEAD ATTORNEYS, Moseley, Prichard, Parrish, Knight & Jones, Jacksonville, FL USA; Dana Baiocco, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, Boston, MA USA; Elizabeth G. Myers, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, Houston, TX USA; Louis A. Chaiten, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, North Point, Cleveland, OH USA; Richard J. Bedell, Jr., LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, Cleveland, OH USA; Sharyl A. Reisman, Theodore M. Grossman, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, New York, NY USA.
For Goodman Company, L.P., Defendant: Charles M. Trippe, Jr., David Clifford Reeves, Jeffrey Alan Yarbrough, Robert B. Parrish, LEAD ATTORNEYS, Moseley, Prichard, Parrish, Knight & Jones, Jacksonville, FL USA; Dana Baiocco, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, Boston, MA USA; Elizabeth G. Myers, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, Houston, TX USA; Louis A. Chaiten, Richard J. Bedell, Jr., LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, Cleveland, OH USA; Sharyl A. Reisman, Theodore M. Grossman, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Jones Day, New York, NY USA.
HARVEY E. SCHLESINGER, UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE.

HARVEY E. SCHLESINGER 
ORDER
THIS CAUSE is before the Court on:
1. Plaintiffs' "Motion for Class Certification" (Doc. 76, filed Mar. 2, 2015); Defendants' Response in opposition thereto (Doc. 89, filed Apr. 30, 2015); Plaintiffs' Reply in support thereof (Doc. 107, filed June 30, 2015); Defendants' Sur-Reply in opposition thereto (Doc. 115, filed Aug. 27, 2015); and Plaintiffs' Sur-Sur-Reply in support thereof (Doc. 116, filed Sept. 1, 2015).
2. Defendants' "Motion to Exclude the Opinions of Paul J. Sikorsky" (Doc. 88, filed Apr. 30, 2015); Plaintiffs' Response in opposition thereto (Doc. 101, filed May 26, 2015); and Defendants' Reply in support thereof (Doc. 105, filed June 24, 2015).
3. Defendants' "Motion to Strike Plaintiffs' Trial Expert Disclosures" (Doc. 122, filed Oct. 26, 2015); and Plaintiffs' Response in opposition thereto (Doc. 123, filed Nov. 9, 2015).
4. Defendants' "Motion to Strike the Supplemental Declaration of Paul J. Sikorsky in Further Support of Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification" (Doc. 127, filed Dec. 3, 2015); and Plaintiffs' Response in opposition thereto (Doc. 131, filed Dec. 17, 2015).

The Court conducted a hearing on the above-referenced matters on January 13, 2016, and took all issues under advisement. Upon consideration of the parties' filings, oral argument, and the applicable law, the Court determines the following.
I. FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND 
Defendants ("Defendants" or "Goodman") are in the business of designing and manufacturing the principal components of air-conditioning and heating systems under the Goodman and Amana brand names ("Goodman [*3] products"). (Doc. 48, ¶¶ 1-2). There are three key components to an air-conditioning system: (1) an evaporator coil, (2) a condenser coil, and (3) a compressor. ( Id. ¶ 31). These components are joined together in a closed, hermetic system that contains refrigerant. ( Id. ¶ 32). At all relevant times for the purposes of this lawsuit, Defendants manufactured the evaporator coil using copper. ( Id. ¶¶ 10, 35-36). Defendants primarily market and sell the component parts to contractors and dealers, who then sell Goodman products to consumers and install them in homes and businesses. (Doc. 89 at 5-6).
A. Previous Complaints and Motions to Dismiss 
On December 19, 2012, Plaintiff PB Property Management, Inc. ("PB Property") filed its first class action complaint against Defendants, alleging breach of express warranty, breach of implied warranty of merchantability, violations of the Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act ("FDUTPA"), Fla. Stat. §§ 501.201 et seq., and unjust enrichment. (Doc. 1). PB Property asserted that they purchased several Goodman products that failed during the warranty period, requiring PB Property to incur extensive out-of-pocket expenses to have technicians diagnose, repair and/or replace the defective parts, and replace the refrigerant that had leaked. ( Id. ¶ 3). Specifically, PB Property alleged that the copper evaporator coils used in Goodman products suffer from a manufacturing and/or design defect that causes the coils to prematurely corrode and fail under normal use, causing refrigerant within the system to leak out. ( Id ¶¶ 4-5). PB Property alleged that Defendants had knowledge of this defect, yet failed to disclose this defect to consumers, and represented, marketed, and warranted that Goodman products were free from defects in materials and workmanship. ( Id. ¶¶ 8, 34-38). Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the original complaint under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) on April 12, 2013, (Doc. 18), which the Court granted in part and denied in part on August 28, 2013. (Doc. 30). In that order, the Court denied Defendants' motion as to PB Property's express warranty claim under a theory of unconscionability, but it granted Defendants' motion as to PB Property's express warranty claim under a theory of failure of essential purpose. (Doc. 30 at 7-10). The Court also granted Defendants' motion as to PB Property's FDUTPA claim, dismissing said claim without prejudice to allow PB Property to re-plead the claim with particularity, as it is grounded in fraud. ( Id. at 11-14). Lastly, the Court granted Defendants' motion as to PB Property's implied warranty and unjust enrichment claims, both of which were dismissed with prejudice. ( Id. at 11, 14-16).
PB Property filed a first amended class action complaint on September 11, 2013, and Defendants filed another motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim on September 30, 2013. (Does. 31, 32). On October 21, 2013, the parties filed a joint motion to stay proceedings pending a ruling by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation ("JPML") to transfer and consolidate several related cases, which this Court granted on October 23, 2013. (Does. 35, 36). On December 13, 2013, the JPML denied PB Property's motion [*4] to transfer and consolidate, and this Court lifted the stay shortly thereafter. (Doc. 37). On January 14, 2014, PB Property filed a motion to consolidate this case with a related case also in the Middle District of Florida and requested leave to file a consolidated amended class action complaint, with no objection from Defendants. (Doc. 40). This Court granted the motion on January 30, 2014; the two cases consolidated, and Defendants' pending motion to dismiss was rendered moot. (Doc. 43).
B. Plaintiffs' First Consolidated Class Action Complaint 
Plaintiffs PB Property, Janet Helm, Jimmy Jewell, Deborah Wagner, and Stanley Wagner ("Plaintiffs" or "named Plaintiffs") filed their "First Consolidated Class Action Complaint" ("FCCAC") on February 28, 2014. (Doc. 48). The principal factual allegations are largely the same as in PB Property's original complaint. Plaintiffs assert that they are Florida residents who own property in Florida and purchased Goodman products that suffer from a manufacturing and/or design defect that causes the copper evaporator coils to corrode and prematurely fail under normal use, causing leakage of refrigerant. ( Id. ¶¶ 4-6). Plaintiffs assert that they were each forced to incur out-of-pocket expenses to diagnose, repair and/or replace the defective parts, and replace the refrigerant that had leaked. ( Id. ¶ 4). Plaintiffs allege that Defendants had knowledge of this defect, yet failed to disclose this defect to consumers, and represented, marketed, and warranted that Goodman products were free from defects in design and manufacture. ( Id. ¶ 3). The FCCAC alleges the following specific factual allegations of each named Plaintiff.
1. PB Property 
Plaintiff PB Property is a company that is involved in the business of developing construction projects and property management in the Jacksonville, Florida area. (Doc. 48, ¶ 55). In 2007, PB Property constructed an office building in Jacksonville, comprised of six separate office units, which was gradually built out through 2009. ( Id. ¶ 56). PB Property used a local certified contractor to purchase and install 14 Goodman products for the office building. ( Id.). Some of the copper evaporator coils in the installed Goodman products began leaking within 180 days of installation, and as of the date of the FCCAC, PB Property has had to replace seven coils. ( Id. ¶ 57). The coils were under Goodman warranty and the replacement parts were provided free of charge, but PB Property incurred labor costs for some of the replacements. ( Id.). In March 2012, another Goodman product at the office building stopped producing cold air, and the technician found that the system was out of refrigerant. ( Id. ¶ 58). PB Property was charged for the cost of the visit, the replacement refrigerant, and labor associated with replacing the copper evaporator coil. ( Id. ¶¶ 58-59).
PB Property also built and managed other properties that experienced coil issues. In mid-2007, PB Property purchased two Goodman products for a different property in Jacksonville. ( Id. ¶ 61). In mid-2012, one of the units stopped cooling, and repair technicians found that the [*5] system was out of refrigerant due to a leak in the evaporator coil. Plaintiff was charged for the labor associated with diagnosing the issue, replacing the refrigerant, and replacing the coil. ( Id. ¶¶ 61-62). In August 2012, PB Property's director, Mr. Safa Mansouri, notified Goodman of the problems he was experiencing with their products. ( Id. ¶ 60). Further, in October 2012, PB Property was notified that two Goodman products installed at yet another property had failed due to evaporator coil leaks. ( Id. ¶ 63).
2. Janet Helm 
Plaintiff Janet Helm ("Helm") purchased a Goodman product on June 5, 2009, after a salesman from Bayside Heating & Air Conditioning ("Bayside") came to her home and made a presentation about the superior quality of the product and the product's warranty. (Doc. 48, ¶ 67). Thereafter, in 2011, the unit stopped producing cool air, and Helm paid a technician for the labor related to diagnosing the problem and replacing the leaking evaporator coil. ( Id ¶¶ 68-69). In March 2013, Helm's unit again experienced problems, and the service technician noted that the system was very low in refrigerant. ( Id. ¶ 70). Fed up with the product, Helm chose to purchase and replace the Goodman product with another system. ( Id. ¶ 71).
3. Jimmy Jewell 
In September 2008, Plaintiff Jimmy Jewell ("Jewell") purchased a Goodman product to replace his Trane system in his home in Florida. (Doc. 48, ¶ 74). Jewell purchased the unit after a salesman from Superior Cooling and Heating Mgt., Inc. ("Superior") came to his home and made a presentation about Goodman products. ( Id. ¶ 75). Following the presentation, Jewell also reviewed Goodman's website and researched the unit further. ( Id.). Thereafter, Jewell purchased the Goodman product, and it was installed by the contractor. ( Id. ¶¶ 75-76). In May 2009, Jewell began experiencing issues; a Superior technician found the system low in refrigerant and added more. ( Id. ¶ 76). In July 2009, a Superior technician again found the system low in refrigerant and added more. ( Id.). In July 2013, after experiencing more issues, a Superior technician found the copper evaporator coil to be leaking refrigerant and replaced the coil. ( Id.). Jewell incurred out-of-pocket costs related to these services. ( Id). Jewell notified Goodman of the problems with his unit in 2010 and in 2013. ( Id. ¶¶ 77-78).
4. Deborah and Stanley Wagner 
In 2009, Plaintiffs Deborah and Stanley Wagner ("the Wagners") purchased a Goodman product to replace an older Coleman brand unit in their home in Florida. (Doc. 48, ¶ 81). Babione's Air Conditioning and Heating, Inc. ("Babione") installed the unit. ( Id.). The Wagners aver that they chose an Amana brand product (i.e., a Goodman product) because they were familiar with the Amana brand name and had confidence in the quality of the product and the product's warranty. ( Id.). They also researched the Amana brand online and asked a representative at Babione about the brand, and he assured them that Amana brand products were high quality. ( Id.).
In June 2012, the Wagners experienced problems with their unit; a Babione technician found no refrigerant in the system and recharged the unit with more refrigerant. ( Id. ¶ 82). The Wagners [*6] paid for the costs associated with this visit. ( Id.). In July 2013, they again experienced problems with the unit, and a Babione technician found a leak in the evaporator coil. ( Id.). The coil was under warranty and the replacement part was provided free of charge, yet the Wagners had to pay for the associated labor costs in diagnosing the problem, replacing the evaporator coil, and recharging the system again with more refrigerant. ( Id. ¶¶ 83-84).
In September 2013, the unit experienced a major failure, and a Babione technician again found the unit low in refrigerant. ( Id. ¶ 85). The extent of the failure caused damage elsewhere in the system, requiring replacement of the entire system. ( Id.). At this point, the Wagners chose to replace the Goodman product with a Trane product. ( Id. ¶ 86).
C. Survival of the FCCAC 
Defendants responded to Plaintiffs' FCCAC by filing another motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim (Doc. 53), which the Court granted in part and denied in part on August 14, 2014. (Doc. 60).
In the wake of the Court's order, Plaintiffs have two claims that remain standing. Count One is a claim for breach of express warranty based on the theory of unconscionability under Florida law. (Doc. 48, ¶ 111). As Goodman offers a limited, parts-only warranty on its products, when Plaintiffs' copper evaporator coils failed, they were personally required to pay out-of-pocket expenses for the costs of labor and repairs related to the problem. ( Id. ¶¶ 49, 52). Plaintiffs argue that the copper evaporator coils manufactured by Goodman were uniformly defective, that Defendants had knowledge of this defect, and, therefore, that Defendants also knew consumers would have to pay hundreds or thousands of dollars in labor and repairs related to the problem. ( Id. ¶ 50). Plaintiffs assert that the limited, parts-only warranty is unconscionable in light of Defendants' knowledge of the latent defect. ( Id.). Plaintiffs allege that they have suffered and continue to suffer actual damages and losses related to the problem.
Count Two is a claim for violation of the FDUTPA.1 Plaintiffs allege that Defendants engaged in deceptive and unfair business practices by selling Goodman products that they knew to be defective, thereby interfering with the reasonable expectations of Plaintiffs and other consumers. (Doc. 48, ¶ 117). Plaintiffs assert that Defendants made material misrepresentations by marketing Goodman products as high quality, reliable, fit for their ordinary purpose, and free from defects in materials and workmanship. ( Id. ¶¶ 40-43). Further, Plaintiffs assert that Defendants omitted material information regarding the copper evaporator coils' propensity to corrode and fail prematurely. ( Id. ¶¶ 40, 46-47). Plaintiffs allege that they have suffered damages by Defendants' conduct because they would not have purchased the products, or would have paid less for them, had they known about the defects. ( Id. ¶¶ 123-24).
Lastly, the Court declined to hold at the dismissal stage that the named Plaintiffs do not fit within the proposed class, though it also declined to certify Plaintiffs' proposed class. ([*7] Doc. 60 at 11-12, 17). The Court directed the parties to engage in discovery to more precisely define the scope of the class and to determine whether any of the named Plaintiffs fall outside of the proposed class, which would be addressed at a later date. ( Id.).
D. Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification 
Plaintiffs filed their Motion for Class Certification on March 2, 2015, seeking to certify both a damages class and an injunctive and declaratory relief class pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 . (Docs. 76, 84).2 While Plaintiffs tweaked the definition of the proposed damages class as originally set forth in the FCCAC (Cf. Doc. 48, ¶ 21), the substantive parts of the proposed damages class remain largely unchanged. The proposed damages class under Rule 23(b)(3) is defined as:
All individuals and entities in the State of Florida that own or owned real property in which a Goodman Unit (under the Goodman or Amana brand names) containing copper evaporator coil was installed from July 1, 2006 to the present and who suffered damages as a result of having to repair and/or replace their Goodman Products due to leakage of refrigerant.
(Doc. 76 at 12). The FCCAC did not propose a separate injunctive and declaratory relief class. In the Motion for Class Certification, Plaintiffs define this class under Rule 23(b)(2) as:
All individuals and entities in the State of Florida that own real property in which a Goodman Unit (under the Goodman or Amana brand names) containing copper evaporator coil was installed from July 1, 2006 to the present.
( Id.). With the benefit of discovery, Plaintiffs were able to more fully explicate their theory of liability in this case in the Motion for Class Certification. Plaintiffs originally asserted in the FCCAC that the copper evaporator coils were defective because they were generally prone to premature corrosion. Now, Plaintiffs have been able to identify the specific type of corrosion at issue: formicary corrosion.3 This type of corrosion is so named because it resembles a formicary—an ant nest—and causes tiny holes to form in the copper tube walls, which results in the leakage of refrigerant. Plaintiffs allege that Defendants had knowledge that the copper evaporator coils were defectively prone to develop formicary corrosion by July 1, 2006, yet continued to manufacture, market, and sell these coils for many years with a limited, parts-only warranty.

Defendants filed their Response in opposition on April 30, 2015 (Does. 89, 94). Defendants challenge class certification on several fronts. Specifically, Defendants argue that (1) neither class is readily ascertainable without being impermissibly overbroad; (2) individual questions overwhelm any common questions under Rule 23(a)(2) for both the breach of warranty claim and the FDUTPA claim; (3) the named Plaintiffs are not typical and cannot adequately represent the class under Rule 23(a)(3) and (a)(4) ; (4) individual questions predominate over any common questions as to the damages class under Rule 23(b)(3) ; (5) Plaintiffs' proposed damages models do not satisfactorily measure only those damages attributable [*8] to Plaintiffs' theory of liability; and (6) the injunctive and declaratory relief class is impermissibly seeking individualized monetary damages.
Plaintiffs filed their Reply on June 30, 2015 (Docs. 107, 110); Defendants filed their Sur-Reply on August 27, 2015 (Docs. 115, 119); and Plaintiffs filed their Sur-Sur-Reply on September 1, 2015 (Doc. 116). A hearing on the motion was held on January 13, 2016.
E. Defendants' Motion to Exclude the Opinions of Paul J. Sikorsky 
On the same day that Defendants filed their Response to Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification, Defendants also filed their Motion to Exclude the Opinions of Paul J. Sikorsky (Docs. 88, 93). Paul Sikorsky ("Sikorsky") is one of Plaintiffs' experts in this case, and he provided a declaration in support of Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification. (Does. 76-6, 86). Sikorsky holds a bachelor's and master's degree in metallurgical engineering and has over 30 years of experience in the heating, ventilating, and air conditioning ("HVAC") industry. He analyzed Goodman's warranty claims data and reached conclusions based thereon. He also performed testing on 25 randomly selected Goodman copper evaporator coils that had been returned under warranty as defectively leaking and reached conclusions based thereon. Defendants contend that Plaintiffs rely exclusively on Sikorsky's opinions to support certain Rule 23 requirements in their motion.
Defendants move to strike these opinions under Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 509 U.S. 579 , 113 S. Ct. 2786 , 125 L. Ed. 2d 469 (1993), and its progeny, as unreliable and unscientific. Once stricken, Defendants argue that class certification must be denied because Plaintiffs have not provided any other admissible evidence to support certain Rule 23 requirements.
In opposition, Plaintiffs argue that the Court should not undertake a full Daubert analysis at the class-certification stage, but in any event, Sikorsky's opinions are reliable and scientific. (Doc. 101). This Court, therefore, must first analyze Defendants' motion to exclude Sikorsky's opinions before considering the merits of Plaintiffs' class certification motion.
F. Defendants' Motion to Strike the Supplemental Declaration of Paul J. Sikorsky in Further Support of Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification 
Sikorsky supplemented his original declaration filed in support of Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification on November 24, 2015. (Docs. 125, 129). The supplemental declaration updates warranty claim rates for copper evaporator coils for the years 2006 through 2014. The original percentages were included in Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification, and the updated warranty-claim rate percentages are even higher with the new data. On December 3, 2015, Defendants moved to strike the supplemental declaration as untimely; the new figures are based on documents and spreadsheets that Defendants had originally produced to Plaintiffs during discovery, not on any new data or documents. (Doc. 127). Defendants argue the supplemental declaration is also unduly burdensome, prejudicial, and immaterial. ([*9] Id.).
Plaintiffs concede that the updated figures are based on documents and spreadsheets originally produced by Defendants during discovery, but that there were thousands of documents produced by Defendants, and they simply did not discover the existence of the more up-to-date data until recently. (Doc. 131). It was an oversight, but upon discovering the updated warranty claims data, they promptly asked Sikorsky to review it and file a supplemental declaration. ( Id.). Plaintiffs argue that there is no prejudice to Defendants because the supplemental declaration simply updates and reinforces Sikorsky's original opinions; the new data does not contradict Sikorsky's prior statements. ( Id.) In fact, Plaintiffs argue that Defendants should not be allowed to re-depose Sikorsky based on this update because they have already thoroughly deposed him. ( Id.) Plaintiffs assert that they were acting in good faith, and striking the supplemental declaration would be against the interests of justice because the Court would not consider the "correct" warranty claims data. ( Id.).
The Court must likewise consider this motion before reaching the merits of Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification.
G. Defendants' Motion to Strike Plaintiffs' Trial Expert Disclosures 
Defendants filed a Motion to Strike Plaintiffs' Trial Expert Disclosures on October 26, 2015. (Doc. 122). Defendants assert that Plaintiffs' disclosures are untimely and insufficient. Plaintiffs' trial expert disclosures were due on August 30, 2015; Defendants' trial expert disclosures were due on September 30, 2015; and discovery was scheduled to be completed by December 15, 2015. (Doc. 49). On August 24, 2015, Plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion for a sixty-day extension of time to submit the disclosures and to complete discovery (Doc. 113), which this Court denied without prejudice because the requested extensions would interfere with the scheduled final pre-trial conference and trial dates. (Doc. 118). Plaintiffs renewed their unopposed motion on September 18, 2015, asking for a fifty-day extension of the expert disclosure deadlines, discovery deadline, and dispositive motions deadline. (Doc. 120). This Court again denied the motion without prejudice, explaining that the proposed deadlines did not take into account the final pre-trial conference and trial dates. (Doc. 121). Plaintiffs did not file another motion seeking an extension of time.
On September 29, 2015, Plaintiffs emailed Defendants their purported trial expert disclosures, which amounted to a two-sentence letter attached to the email. (Doc. 122, Exhs. A, B). No other information accompanied this letter. Defendants responded on September 30, 2015, telling Plaintiffs that their trial expert disclosures were untimely and insufficient under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(2) . ( Id., Exh. C). Plaintiffs responded to Defendants on October 5, 2015, essentially asserting that the expert reports and documents submitted in connection with their Motion for Class Certification should be sufficient.4 ( Id., Exh. D). To date, Defendants have yet to serve their trial [*10] expert disclosures, because they assert that Plaintiffs have yet to serve their proper trial expert disclosures. ( Id. at 3 n.1).
Defendants move to strike these disclosures as untimely and insufficient, and argue that Plaintiffs cannot show their failure was substantially justified or harmless. In response, Plaintiffs argue that their expert disclosures on September 29, 2015 were sufficient because they informed Defendants that they would rely on the same two experts—Sikorsky and Bernatowicz—that they relied on in their Motion for Class Certification, both of whom have already been deposed by Defendants multiple times. (Doc. 123 at 2). They further assert that they offered to amend their disclosures, but Defendants rejected this idea. ( Id. at 4). Plaintiffs concede that their disclosures were untimely but argue that the sanctions requested by Defendants are "unreasonable, unnecessary, and unsupported given the complete lack of prejudice to Defendants." ( Id. at 3).
The Court will consider this motion last, as it concerns trial-related matters.
II. STANDARDS OF REVIEW 
A. Daubert Standard 
Federal Rule of Evidence 702 governs the admissibility of testimony by expert witnesses. The rule states that:
A witness who is qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education may testify in the form of an opinion or otherwise if:
(a) the expert's scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will help the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue;
(b) the testimony is based on sufficient facts or data;
(c) the testimony is the product of reliable principles and methods; and
(d) the expert has reliably applied the principles and methods to the facts of the case.
Id . Rule 702 was amended in response to the Supreme Court's decision in Daubert, and to the many cases applying Daubert, including Kumho Tire Co. v. Carmichael, 526 U.S. 137 , 119 S. Ct. 1167 , 143 L. Ed. 2d 238 (1999). See United States v. Frazier, 387 F.3d 1244 , 1260 (11th Cir. 2004). Pursuant to Federal Rule of Evidence 104(a) , the proponent of the testimony has the burden of establishing its admissibility by a preponderance of the evidence. See Bourjaily v. United States, 483 U.S. 171 , 175-76 , 107 S. Ct. 2775 , 97 L. Ed. 2d 144 (1987); Frazier, 387 F.3d at 1260 .

The Eleventh Circuit explained in Frazier that "experts may be qualified in various ways," but that, fundamentally, the "'proposed expert testimony must be supported by appropriate validation.'" Frazier, 387 F.3d at 1260-61 (quoting Daubert, 509 U.S. at 590 ) (alterations omitted). When the expert's proposed testimony is scientific in nature, "the trial judge must assess 'whether the reasoning or methodology underlying the testimony is scientifically valid and . . . whether that reasoning or methodology properly can be applied to the facts at issue.'"  Id. at 1261-62 (quoting Daubert, 509 U.S. at 592-93 ). The Eleventh Circuit considers the following non-exhaustive factors when evaluating the reliability of scientific expert opinion:
(1) whether the expert's theory can be and has been tested; (2) whether the theory has been subjected to peer review and publication; (3) the known or potential rate of error of the particular scientific technique; and (4) whether the technique is generally accepted in the scientific community.
Id. at 1262 (quoting Quiet [*11] Tech. DC-8, Inc. v. Hurel-Dubois UK, Ltd., 326 F.3d 1333 , 1341 (11th Cir. 2003)). The Frazier Court went on to explain that "[s]ometimes the specific Daubert factors will aid in determining reliability; sometimes other questions may be more useful." Id . The trial judge has "considerable leeway" in deciding the reliability of expert testimony, but importantly, "what remains constant is the requirement that the trial judge evaluate the reliability of the testimony before allowing its admission at trial" in every case. Id . 

B. Class Certification Standard 
"'For a district court to certify a class action, the named plaintiffs must have standing, and the putative class must meet each of the requirements specified in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(a) , as well as at least one of the requirements set forth in Rule 23(b) .'" Vega v. T-Mobile USA, Inc., 564 F.3d 1256 , 1265 (11th Cir. 2009) (quoting Klay v. Humana, Inc., 382 F.3d 1241 , 1250 (11th Cir. 2004)). "'The burden of proof to establish the propriety of class certification rests with the advocate of the class.'" Id . (quoting Valley Drug Co. v. Geneva Pharms., Inc., 350 F.3d 1181 , 1187 (11th Cir. 2003)). The plaintiff "'must affirmatively demonstrate his compliance with Rule 23' by proving that the requirements are 'in fact' satisfied." Brown v. Electrolux Home Products, Inc., 817 F.3d 1225 , 2016 WL 1085517 , at *4 (11th Cir. 2016) (quoting Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, 133 S. Ct. 1426 , 1432 , 185 L. Ed. 2d 515 (2013)).
"'A district court must conduct a rigorous analysis of the rule 23 prerequisites before certifying a class.'" Vega, 564 F.3d at 1266 (quoting Castano v. Am. Tobacco Co., 84 F.3d 734 , 740 (5th Cir. 1996)). This analysis "'will frequently entail overlap with the merits of the plaintiff's underlying claim.'" Electrolux, 817 F.3d 1225 , 2016 WL 1085517 , at *4 (quoting Comcast, 133 S. Ct. at 1432 ). "'Although the trial court should not determine the merits of the plaintiffs' claim at the class certification stage, the trial court can and should consider the merits of the case to the degree necessary to determine whether the requirements of Rule 23 will be satisfied.'" Vega, 564 F.3d at 1266 (quoting Valley Drug, 350 F.3d at 1188 n.15). Accordingly, "if a question of fact or law is relevant to that determination, then the district court has a duty to actually decide it and not accept it as true or construe it in anyone's favor." Electrolux, 817 F.3d 1225 , 2016 WL 1085517 , at *4.
III. ANALYSIS 
A. Defendants' Motion to Exclude the Opinions of Paul J. Sikorsky (Doc. 88) 
As an initial matter, Defendants ask this Court to undertake a full Daubert analysis at the class certification stage, while Plaintiffs argue that a full Daubert analysis is improper and premature at this stage.
In Sher v. Raytheon Co., 419 F. App'x 887 (11th Cir. 2011), the Eleventh Circuit held that it was error for a district court to refuse to undertake a full Daubert analysis at the class certification stage when the situation warrants it.  Id. at 890 (citing Am. Honda Motor Co. v. Allen, 600 F.3d 813 , 816 (7th Cir. 2010)). "'[W]hen an expert's report or testimony is critical to class certification, . . . a district court must conclusively rule on any challenge to the expert's qualifications or submissions prior to ruling on a class certification motion.'" Id . (quoting Am. Honda, 600 F.3d at 815-16 ). This situation arises, for example, when the information that an expert provides "'is relevant to establishing any of the Rule 23 requirements.'" Id . (quoting Am. Honda, 600 F.3d at 816 ). The Eleventh Circuit explained that the district [*12] court "must make the necessary factual and legal inquiries and decide all relevant contested issues prior to certification."  Id. at 891 .
Plaintiffs nevertheless argue that a full Daubert analysis is not proper at this stage. They point out that Sher is an unpublished decision and thus not binding precedent. They also assert that Sher does not stand for the proposition that a full Daubert analysis is necessary in every case, but only if the situation warrants. They cite to In re Zurn Pex Plumbing Products Liability Litigation, 644 F.3d 604 (8th Cir. 2011), for support. There, the Eighth Circuit noted that "[c]lass certification is inherently tentative, and may require revisiting upon completion of full discovery."  Id. at 613 (citations and internal quotation marks omitted). Because "class certification decisions are generally made before the close of merits discovery, the court's analysis is necessarily prospective and subject to change." Id . The Eighth Circuit concluded that the district court did not err in conducting a "tailored" or "focused Daubert analysis which scrutinized the reliability of the expert testimony in light of the criteria for class certification and the current state of the evidence."  Id. at 614 .
The Court finds Zurn to be readily distinguishable from this case. In Zurn, the parties conducted bifurcated discovery, which resulted in a limited record at the class certification stage. The parties had not engaged in merits discovery, so there were necessarily "gaps in the available evidence," and "expert opinions may have [had] to adapt as such gaps [were] filled by merits discovery."  Id. at 612-13 . In this case, however, the parties did not engage in bifurcated discovery; merits discovery began immediately. Thus, there are no "gaps in the available evidence," as Sikorsky was provided with all of the documents produced by Goodman for merits discovery. Indeed, Plaintiffs attempt to argue that the record is still incomplete at the class certification stage, yet as noted in Part I.G. above, Plaintiffs also assert that the expert reports prepared for class certification may be used to satisfy their trial expert disclosure requirements. Even Sikorsky's supplemental declaration is not based on newly available data; it is based on data that was already produced by Goodman at the time Plaintiffs filed their class certification motion. Thus, the reasoning behind the "tailored" Daubert analysis in Zurn is not present here.
It is true that Sher is an unpublished Eleventh Circuit opinion and is not binding on this Court. Nevertheless, the Court finds Sherpersuasive and will conduct a full Daubert analysis in this case. Sikorsky's opinions are uniquely cited by Plaintiffs to support certain Rule 23 requirements, and the Court must determine whether these opinions are reliable.
1. Qualifications 
Sikorsky is objectively well qualified; he holds a bachelor's and master's degree in metallurgical engineering and has over 30 years of experience in the HVAC industry. (Doc. 76-6, ¶¶ 4-5). Sikorsky spent the majority of his career working at one [*13] of Defendants' competitors, Trane, as an engineer. ( Id. ¶ 5). He was involved in the selection of materials and manufacturing processes for the production of evaporator coils in residential and commercial air conditioning and heat pump products, and he also visited Trane manufacturing facilities to ensure compliance with such standards. ( Id. ¶ 6). He has extensive experience performing failure analyses on evaporator coils. ( Id.). He was also a member of the American Society for Testing and Materials, where he served on committees and helped to develop and publish nationwide industrial standards related to copper tubing and castings used in evaporator coils. ( Id. ¶ 7).
Defendants do not challenge Sikorsky's qualifications relating to analysis of copper evaporator coils and testing for formicary corrosion. Rather, Defendants argue that the test Sikorsky actually performed in this case is an unscientific and unreliable method, and thus, that the conclusions he reached therefrom are also unreliable. (Doc. 88 at 9-10, 17-20). They also argue that the conclusions he reached from the unscientific testing are not even supported by his own test. ( Id.). Defendants also challenge Sikorsky's qualifications and conclusions in relation to certain opinions he made that require correlation between data. ( Id. at 11-13, 16-17).
2. Sikorsky's Testing Method 
On January 29, 2015, Sikorsky visited a metallurgical testing laboratory in Dallas, Texas, to inspect 25 randomly-selected copper evaporator coils that had been returned under warranty from Florida. (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 26). They were subjected to a pressure decay leak test wherein the coils were pressurized with nitrogen to an initial pressure of 450 psi and then pressure decay was monitored for five minutes. ( Id.). Of the 25 coils tested, 21 (84%) exhibited a pressure decay of 1 psi or greater. ( Id. ¶ 27). Based on the small size and location of the leaks in the coils, Sikorsky concluded that the failures were consistent with formicary corrosion as a potential cause. ( Id.). He further concluded from the results of the test that the warranty claims rate of copper evaporator coils is at least roughly equivalent (if not exactly equivalent) to the coil failure rate of the 25 tested coils. ( Id. ¶ 28).
Defendants challenge Sikorsky's testing method and conclusions based thereon. First, they assert that Sikorsky's pressure decay leak test is inappropriate to test for formicary corrosion and is not used by the scientific community. Formicary corrosion is normally a slowly progressing, degenerative process, and they argue that a test of five minutes is not scientific. Second, they assert that an exhibited pressure decay of 1 psi or greater means nothing standing alone and is not supported by any scientific data or research. Defendants argue that Sikorsky arbitrarily chose this number.
In response, Plaintiffs argue that Sikorsky's test is reliable and scientific. They point to Sikorsky's extensive experience in this area, and to the fact that the exhibited leaks were located within the copper evaporator coils in areas that [*14] are usually indicative of formicary corrosion. In his declaration, Sikorsky notes that Goodman documents show that Goodman engineers have utilized a similar pressure decay leak test in the past. The main difference between the two tests is that Goodman held the coils at pressure for a longer period of time. Sikorsky asserts that this enables Goodman to find even smaller leaks than the leaks he found during his testing.
Sikorsky is correct to state that Goodman has performed similar testing in the past. For example, Goodman undertook testing of 34 coils returned from Winter Haven, Florida in October 2009. (Doc. 85-2 at 6, Exh. T). In that report, the testing method was written step by step:
Step 1: Note down the Model number and serial number.
Step 2: Visually looks at the coil for obvious defects.
Step 3: Pressurize the coil to 450 psi and introduce the coil in the gross leak chamber.
Step 4: Fill the coil with tracer gas and then pass it through the Sensistor Check.
Step 5: Fill the coil with 450 psi and dunk the coils and look for air bubbles.
Step 6: Pressurize the coil with tracer gas at 450 psi and then send the coil through the Sensistor check.
Step 7: If no defect is found then attach a pressure gauge to the coil (450 PSI) and closely monitor the coil for any pressure drop for 24, 48 [hours] and further more if still no issues were found. We keep the coils for 2 weeks before we deem the coil as good.
( Id. at 8). On this occasion, Goodman, like Sikorsky, pressurized the coils to 450 psi with tracer gas. In Goodman's test, if the coils did not exhibit a leak after several tests, including a test that looked for air bubbles, then the coils were again pressurized to 450 psi and were closely monitored for 24 to 48 hours or longer for any drop in pressure. It is possible that the test classified as "leaking" only those coils exhibiting a pressure drop of a certain psi or greater, but the report is silent on the matter. On its face, Sikorsky's testing is not inconsistent with Goodman's internal testing.

In the motion, Defendants note that Sikorsky could not identify an industry standard or any company in the HVAC industry that defines a leak as a 1 to 2 psi drop from 450 psi. (Doc. 89-1 at 140:2-10). Indeed, Sikorsky states in his declaration that a leak of 1 psi or greater is an indication, in his estimation, of a significant leak. (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 27). Sikorsky also concedes that he did not control for the presence of lubricant in returned coils, even though lubricant can absorb nitrogen test gas. (Doc. 89-1 at 139:5-14; Doc. 89-7, ¶ 11). If absorption of nitrogen occurred, this could decrease the pressure from 450 psi and falsely reflect a leak in the coil. (Doc. 89-7, ¶ 11).
Defendants' expert, Michael Stevenson ("Stevenson"), is also a well-qualified metallurgical engineer who consults in the HVAC industry and has over 13 years of experience in the field of metallurgical failure analysis. (Doc. 89-7, ¶ 2). He is the President of Engineering Systems, Inc. ("ESI"), a company that specializes in the performance and analysis of engineering materials and systems and conducts complex materials and metallurgical failure analysis. ([*15]  Id. at 15). The 25 coils tested by Sikorsky at ESI Dallas on January 29,2015 were jointly tested by ESI personnel. ( Id. ¶ 8). Including these 25 coils, ESI has tested 338 returned Goodman copper evaporator coils for formicary corrosion-related leaks. ( Id.). Stevenson argues that Sikorsky's test and conclusions are unscientific, unreliable, and based on flawed assumptions. ( Id. ¶¶ 6-8, 20-22).
The testing that ESI performed is slightly different than Sikorsky's testing. Stevenson first notes that industry standard requires pneumatic leak testing of pressure vessel tubes at a test pressure not less than 250 psi for five seconds, with leaks visually identified in conjunction with a pressure differential. ( Id. ¶ 6). In this case, ESI initially pressure tested each coil with nitrogen at 225 psi and held for a minimum of 15 seconds. ( Id.). If no gross leaks were discovered, the pressure was increased to 450 psi and held for five minutes. ( Id.). Stevenson states that this higher test pressure is conservative since it is approximately four to five times the operating pressure of an evaporator coil in cooling mode. ( Id.). Further, ESI classified as leaking only those coils exhibiting a pressure decay of 2 psi or greater due to (1) the duration of the test, (2) the higher test pressure relative to industry standards, and (3) potential, known causes of minor pressure fluctuations associated with the testing of used systems, such as mechanical damage or the presence of lubricants. ( Id.). This is different than Sikorsky's test, which classified as leaking an exhibited pressure decay of 1 psi or greater. Thus, the experts disagree on whether pressure drops between 1 and 2 psi should be classified as leaking or non-leaking.
Unfortunately, Stevenson's declaration does not provide ESI's results of the jointly-held testing of the 25 coils, and the Court is unable to determine whether classifying a leak at 1 or 2 psi makes a material difference in the test results. Stevenson's declaration does provide overall data for the 338 coils ESI tested, using the 2 psi or greater figure. ( Id. ¶ 8). Based on this criteria, ESI found that 224 of the 338 submitted coils tested, or 66%, did not exhibit a leak, and 47 of the coils, or 14%, exhibited no pressure decay at all. ( Id.). In other words, only 67 of the coils, or 20%, exhibited a leak of 2 psi or greater.
As noted above, lubricants on used coils can absorb nitrogen gas and lead to a drop in pressure unrelated to any leaks. ESI performed a secondary pressure test on selected copper coils that had exhibited a pressure decay during the first test to control for this possibility. ( Id. ¶ 11). Stevenson notes that in each instance where a second test was performed using the same criteria as the first test, the updated final pressure was always equal to or greater than the original final pressure. ( Id.). While this supports the conclusion that lubricant absorption of nitrogen accounted for the drop in pressure exhibited by some coils during the first test, Stevenson provides no figures or data related to the second test results. He does not state how many coils were subjected [*16] to a second test, and of these coils, how many exhibited an updated final pressure that was equal to the original final pressure and how many exhibited an updated final pressure that was greater than—and how much greater than—the original final pressure.
As previously noted, relevant factors in the Court's analysis of the reliability of scientific expert opinion consider whether the expert's theory can be and has been tested, whether it has been subjected to peer review and publication, the error rate of a particular scientific technique, and whether the technique is generally accepted in the scientific community. Frazier, 387 F.3d at 1262 .
The first test parameter that Defendants challenge is Sikorsky's decision to test the coils at 450 psi for five minutes. (Doc. 93 at 18-19). The Court does not have before it any scientific data or publications to support or refute testing at 450 psi for any specific length of time. It may be the case that this subject has not yet been subjected to peer review and publication. It is unclear whether testing at 450 psi is generally accepted in the scientific community based solely on the three anecdotal tests in this case (indeed, the industry standard simply states that testing should be performed at no less than 250 psi for five seconds). What the Court does know is that Sikorsky's test pressure level of 450 psi was also used by Goodman during internal testing, as well as by Defendants' expert Stevenson in this case. In Sikorsky's declaration, he notes that Goodman documentation shows that Goodman has utilized a similar pressure decay leak test in the past, and that Goodman's test is even more sensitive than Sikorsky's test because it is performed for a longer period of time at the same pressure level. (Doc. 76-6, ¶¶ 29-30). Thus, while it is true that objective scientific data or publications to support testing at 450 psi for five minutes is unavailable, the Court holds that there is sufficient anecdotal scientific evidence to support Sikorsky's test pressure level and duration. Sikorsky was, in essence, following test protocol Goodman has used in the past (and indeed, that Goodman also used in this litigation) by choosing to test for leaks at 450 psi. Sikorsky held the coils at pressure for five minutes, while Goodman would hold coils at pressure for 24 to 48 hours, or in some cases, up to two weeks. From this fact, Sikorsky makes the logical conclusion that Goodman has the capacity to find even smaller leaks. The Court finds this portion of Sikorsky's test reliable, as it is modeled on scientific testing that was previously performed by Goodman itself.
The other main parameter of Sikorsky's test that Defendants challenge relates to the classification of leaks. (Doc. 93 at 18-19). Sikorsky states that he personally chose to classify leaks at 1 psi or greater, based on his experience in the industry. (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 27). Defendants assert that this number is arbitrary and unscientific. While this may be true, it is worth noting that their expert likewise provides no independent scientific data or support for classifying a [*17] leak at 2 psi or greater. Stevenson describes various causes and factors in support of his conclusion that leaks should only qualify at 2 psi or greater, but the conclusion ultimately reached is his own. For example, the "correct" conservative figure that controls for all other causes may be at 3 psi or greater, or perhaps Sikorsky's metric sufficiently controls for all other causes. In theory this issue could be tested, but there is no evidence in the record that the theory has been tested or subjected to peer review and publication. Likewise, the error rate of this technique is unknown, as is whether the technique is generally accepted in the scientific community. What the Court is left with, then, is conflicting anecdotal evidence from Plaintiffs' expert and Defendants' expert, as well as evidence from Goodman's internal testing.
The question of whether this test parameter is scientific and reliable is a difficult one. As it is Plaintiffs' expert being challenged, Plaintiffs have the burden of establishing the admissibility of Sikorsky's expert opinion by a preponderance of the evidence; the burden is not on Defendants to disprove the admissibility of his opinion. Frazier, 387 F.3d at 1260 . The fact that the evidence submitted by the parties' competing experts is essentially in equipoise, therefore, does not act to undermine Sikorsky's opinion, but neither does it save Sikorsky's opinion.
Sikorsky's leak-classification test parameter is not based on established scientific principles, either objective or anecdotal. Sikorsky's opinion is based on his experience, and thus, the Court must evaluate whether his experience is enough. The Eleventh Circuit has approvingly cited the Advisory Committee's Note to the 2000 Amendments of Rule 702, which states:
"If the witness is relying solely or primarily on experience, then the witness must explain how that experience leads to the conclusion reached, why that experience is a sufficient basis for the opinion, and how that experience is reliably applied to the facts. The trial court's gatekeeping function requires more than simply taking the expert's word for it."
Frazier, 387 F.3d at 1261 (quoting Fed. R. Evid. 702 advisory committee's note (2000 amends.)). The Frazier court went on to explain that "[i]f admissibility could be established merely by the ipse dixit of an admittedly qualified expert, the reliability prong would be, for all practical purposes, subsumed by the qualification prong." Id . Expert testimony must be supported by "appropriate validation" that "'rests on a reliable foundation.'" Id . (quoting Daubert, 509 U.S. at 597 ).

Upon review of his declaration and his deposition, the Court finds that Sikorsky has not satisfied Frazier'sexperienced-based inquiry. Sikorsky states in his declaration that "21 [of the 25 coils tested] (84%) exhibited a pressure decay of 1 psi or greater, an indication, in my estimation, of a significant leak." (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 27). He provides no explanation in his declaration as to how his experience led him to choose this metric, let alone why his experience is a sufficient basis for choosing this metric and how his experience [*18] is reliably applied to the facts of this case. In his deposition, he conceded that he does not know of any company in the HVAC industry that classifies a one to two psi drop at 450 psi as a leak. (Doc. 89-1 at 140:2-10). He also conceded that it is possible to test the amount of absorption of nitrogen due to the presence of oils inside the coils, but he did not perform this test or control for this factor. ( Id. at 141:13-142:18). Sikorsky chose to classify leaks at 1 psi or greater not based on scientific testing, but rather, based on his experience. Sikorsky has failed to establish that his experience renders this portion of his opinion reliable. See, e.g., Lord v. Fairway Elec. Corp., 223 F. Supp. 2d 1270 , 1283-84 (M.D. Fla. 2002).
The fact that Sikorsky's leak-classification test metric is unscientific and unreliable further renders the test results obtained from this method unreliable. See Lord, 223 F. Supp. 2d at 1284 ("[T]his premise is not based upon sufficient facts or data, and the testimony is not the produce of reliable principles."). Using this unreliable parameter, Sikorsky found that 21 of the 25 coils (84%) exhibited a "significant leak." (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 27). This data is, therefore, unscientific and unreliable, as it is the result of an unreliable testing method.
3. Sikorsky's Conclusions and Opinions Based on the Test Results 
Defendants also take issue with the conclusions and opinions Sikorsky reached based on the test results. The Court finds that these conclusions and opinions are likewise unscientific and unreliable, as they are based on faulty data. Moreover, even if the testing method and results were reliable, Sikorsky's opinions and conclusions based thereon would still fail because they are not supported by Sikorsky's own data. After concluding that 84 percent of the tested coils had a significant leak, Sikorsky then concluded that "[t]he location of these leaks within the fin pack and the small size of these leaks is consistent with formicary corrosion as a potential cause." (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 27). Building on this assumption, Sikorsky further extrapolated the results from his test to Goodman's overall warranty claims data. He stated, "From these pressure tests it is clear the warranty claims rate is at least roughly equivalent (if not exactly equivalent) to the coil failure rate for these evaporator coils." ( Id. ¶ 28).
In a similar vein, Sikorsky also concluded that the warranty claims rate reflects coils that leaked due to formicary corrosion because (1) "the overwhelming failure mode reported for [returned] coils is refrigerant leakage;" (2) it appears from Goodman internal documentation that the primary cause of coil warranty claims was formicary corrosion; and (3) the "lengthy average time" between installation and warranty claim "suggests . . . failure due to a slowly progressing, degenerative process," and formicary corrosion "is such a process." ( Id. ¶¶ 16, 19). From there, Sikorsky infers that virtually all coils that were returned under warranty in fact leaked, and that all of these coils leaked due to formicary corrosion.
Sikorsky's opinion, then, is that (1) based on his testing of 25 coils, 84 percent exhibited leaks of 1 [*19] psi or greater, which qualifies as a significant leak; (2) the location of the leaks in the tested coils is consistent with formicary corrosion as the cause; (3) the results of his testing, when considered in conjunction with (a) internal Goodman documentation showing concern over formicary corrosion, (b) the main warranty claims rate failure mode being reported as refrigerant leakage, and (c) the average length of time between installation and warranty claim, support the conclusion that virtually all of the returned coils actually manifested a leak; and (4) the leaks in returned coils can be uniformly attributed to formicary corrosion.
This conclusion is important, because Defendants vehemently argue that the warranty claims rate cannot be used as a viable figure to determine the actual leakage rate of returned coils. Goodman does not independently test the vast majority of returned coils to verify that they leak; rather, it chooses to honor the warranty and send a new coil on nearly all claims. Goodman honors the warranty without independent verification as a method of doing business, even though it is undisputed that different repairmen have different diagnoses of the same problem and sometimes misdiagnose the problem, which Sikorsky conceded during his deposition. (Doc. 89-1 at 161:5-8). Marshall Blackham, Vice President of Quality for Goodman, explained in his declaration that Goodman undertakes an independent analysis of approximately three percent of all evaporator coil claims, and the most common result of this evaluation is that there is nothing wrong with the coil. (Doc. 89-2, ¶ 14). Thus, Defendants argue that it is impossible to determine the actual leakage rate of the copper evaporator coils, likewise making it impossible to tie the warranty claims rate to the leakage rate of coils caused by formicary corrosion. (Doc. 88 at 20).
The assumptions Sikorsky was required to make to form his opinion are unsupported by any available evidence. Furthermore, Sikorsky admitted during his deposition that he did not actually observe formicary corrosion in any of the coils that failed his leak test. (Doc. 89-1 at 31:14-24). He also could not testify to a reasonable degree of engineering certainty that the failure of the coils he tested was due to formicary corrosion as opposed to a different type of corrosion, such as pitting corrosion. ( Id. at 32:14-33:2). Even if Sikorsky's test and test results were reliable, Sikorsky's opinions based thereon are still unfounded.
