He provides no explanation apart from his experience in the HVAC industry to support the several assumptions he had to make in order to reach his ultimate conclusion: Goodman's warranty claims data may be used as evidence to demonstrate that Goodman's copper evaporator coils are uniformly defective due to a propensity to develop formicary corrosion and fail prematurely. These opinions must be excluded. See Gen. Elec. Co. v. Joiner, 522 U.S. 136 , 146 , 118 S. Ct. 512 , 139 L. Ed. 2d 508 (1997) ("Trained experts commonly extrapolate from existing data. But nothing in either Daubert or the Federal Rules of Evidence [*20] requires a district court to admit opinion evidence that is connected to existing data only by the ipse dixit of the expert. A court may conclude that there is simply too great an analytical gap between the data and the opinion proffered.").
4. Warranty Claims Rate Correlation 
Lastly, Defendants take issue with Sikorsky's opinion regarding the "correlation" between the warranty claims rate in any given year and evidence of a defect. (Doc. 88 at 11-13). Sikorsky opined in his declaration that, based on his experience in the industry, "warranty claims rates exceeding 1% for any year are excessive. The warranty claims rate of Goodman's copper evaporator coils shipped to Florida during the time frame of 2006 through 2014 is, in my opinion, high, and evidence of a defect in the design and/or manufacture of the product." (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 18).
Sikorsky offered no objective scientific documentation to support the one-percent figure, and he could not do so during his deposition. Indeed, he testified that he is "not aware of a particular standard" in the industry. (Doc. 89-1 at 161:23-162:8). The most he could say was that Trane would undertake a study if its warranty claims rate exceeded one percent; he could not say that Trane considered a rate exceeding one percent as evidence of a defect. ( Id. at 161:14-22). He also conceded that "corrosion failures were more ubiquitous in Florida than elsewhere." ( Id. at 163:1-4). When asked, "Yes, and that's largely because of the Florida environment; correct?" Sikorsky responded, "Yes." ( Id. at 163:5-8).
Sikorsky's opinion is again based solely on his experience. As the Eleventh Circuit made clear in Frazier, if a witness is relying solely or primarily on experience, the witness must come forward with an explanation of how his experience leads to the conclusion reached and why that experience is sufficient. Frazier, 387 F.3d at 1261 . The expert must also explain how his experience is reliably applied to the facts. Id . Sikorsky did not do so here; he rests his opinion on the conclusory reference to his experience and nothing more. Accordingly, Sikorsky's opinion on this issue must be excluded.5 
5. Conclusion 
Sikorsky's expert opinions in this case are based solely or primarily on his experience. While he is undoubtedly well qualified to testify as an expert in metallurgical engineering, his testing method and conclusions based thereon are not supported by objective scientific data or analysis. In addition, Sikorsky's opinion regarding the correlation between the warranty claims rate for each year and evidence of a defect is unsupported by either reference to established industry standards or scientific analysis. Sikorsky's opinions are unreliable and must be excluded at the present time.
That being said, the Court recognizes that Sikorsky's opinions were not prepared for trial; they were prepared in support of Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification. It is also worth noting that the Court did not conduct a Daubert hearing before ruling on the motion. It is implausible, yet theoretically possible, that Sikorsky could revise his declaration and [*21] correct its deficiencies in preparation for trial. Therefore, the Court will proceed to analyze the merits of Plaintiffs' motion for class certification, leaving the original arguments and evidence of the parties intact, while recognizing that class certification could likely be denied based on the exclusion of Sikorsky's opinions.
B. Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification (Doc. 76) 
For a district court to certify a class action, the party seeking certification must demonstrate compliance with the requirements of Rule 23(a) , as well as at least one of the requirements of Rule 23(b) . Vega, 564 F.3d at 1265 . Rule 23(a) requires:
(1) the class is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable;
(2) there are questions of law or fact common to the class;
(3) the claims or defenses of the representative parties are typical of the claims or defenses of the class; and
(4) the representative parties will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class.
Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a) . These requirements are routinely referenced as "numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy of representation." Valley Drug, 350 F.3d at 1188 . The plaintiff must also establish at least one of the requirements of Rule 23(b) . See id . Failure to establish any one of the four requirements of Rule 23(a) and at least one of the alternative requirements of Rule 23(b) precludes class certification. Id . 

Plaintiffs seek to certify two classes: a damages class ("the damages class") pursuant to Rule 23(b)(3) , and an injunctive and declaratory relief class ("the injunctive relief class") pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2) . Rule 23(b)(3) permits class certification if "the court finds that the questions of law or fact common to class members predominate over any questions affecting only individual members, and that a class action is superior to other available methods for fairly and efficiently adjudicating the controversy." Id . Rule 23(b)(2) permits class certification if "the party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on grounds that apply generally to the class, so that final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief is appropriate respecting the class as a whole." Id . Plaintiffs' proposed damages class under Rule 23(b)(3) is defined as:
All individuals and entities in the State of Florida that own or owned real property in which a Goodman Unit (under the Goodman or Amana brand names) containing copper evaporator coil was installed from July 1, 2006 to the present and who suffered damages as a result of having to repair and/or replace their Goodman Products due to leakage of refrigerant.
(Doc. 76 at 12). Plaintiffs' proposed injunctive relief class under Rule 23(b)(2) is defined as:
All individuals and entities in the State of Florida that own real property in which a Goodman Unit (under the Goodman or Amana brand names) containing copper evaporator coil was installed from July 1, 2006 to the present.
( Id.). In order to analyze the sufficiency of Plaintiffs' proposed classes, it is first necessary to clearly articulate Plaintiffs' claims and their elements. Two causes of action remain from the FCCAC, and Plaintiffs' proposed [*22] classes seek to encompass those individuals who would be able to assert the same claims if brought individually. Count One is a breach of express warranty claim based on the theory of unconscionability, and Count Two is an FDUTPA claim.

As a condition precedent to recovery for breach of express warranty, a buyer must notify the seller of the breach "within a reasonable time after he or she discovers or should have discovered any breach." Fla. Stat. § 672.607(3)(a) . "Where the buyer gives some notice of the breach, the issues of timeliness and sufficiency are questions of fact." Royal Typewriter Co., a Div. of Litton Bus. Sys., Inc. v. Xerographic Supplies Corp., 719 F.2d 1092 , 1102 (11th Cir. 1983). If the notice requirement has been met, the plaintiff (buyer) must then demonstrate that the warranty limitation is unconscionable and, therefore, unenforceable. Under Florida law, a warranty limitation may be unconscionable when a defect is latent and the manufacturer knows that the product's effectiveness is questionable. See Monsanto Agric. Prods. Co. v. Edenfield, 426 So. 2d 574 , 579 (Fla. 1st DCA 1982); Barnext Offshore, Ltd. v. Ferretti Grp. USA, Inc., No. 10-23869-CIV, 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 61710 , [2012 BL 109064], 2012 WL 1570057 , at *10 (S.D. Fla. May 2, 2012) ("[I]f a product contains a known latent defect then any warranty limits may be unconscionable."). A plaintiff must prove both substantive and procedural unconscionability. Pendergast v. Sprint Nextel Corp., 592 F.3d 1119 , 1134 (11th Cir. 2010).
To determine substantive unconscionability, Florida courts asks whether the terms of the warranty are "unreasonable and unfair." Pendergast, 592 F.3d at 1139 . This analysis "focuses 'directly on those terms of the contract itself which amount to an outrageous degree of unfairness to the same contracting party.'" Id . (quoting Steinhardt v. Rudolph, 422 So. 2d 884 , 889 (Fla. 3d DCA 1982)). Substantive unconscionability is generally defined "in reference to an agreement no man in his senses and not under delusion would make on the one hand, and as no honest and fair man would accept on the other.'" Id . (quoting Belcher v. Kier, 558 So. 2d 1039 , 1044 (Fla. 2d DCA 1990)). Procedural unconscionability asks "whether the consumer has an absence of meaningful choice in whether to accept the contract terms."  Id. at 1135 . Florida courts consider:
(1) the manner in which the contract was entered into; (2) the relative bargaining power of the parties and whether the complaining party had a meaningful choice at the time the contract was entered into; (3) whether the terms were merely presented on a "take-it-or-leave-it" basis; and (4) the complaining party's ability and opportunity to understand the disputed terms of the contract.
Id . (citing Powertel, Inc. v. Bexley, 743 So. 2d 570 , 574 (Fla. 1st DCA 1999)). The last element of a claim for breach of express warranty is injury; the plaintiff must demonstrate that the defect has manifested in the product and thereby caused the plaintiff to suffer an injury. See, e.g., Kia Motors Am. Corp. v. Butler, 985 So. 2d 1133 , 1138-39 (Fla. 3d DCA 2008) (holding, as an independent reason to reverse the trial court and deny class certification in an automobile brake defect case asserting breach of express warranty and FDUTPA claims, that the class representative improperly sought "compensation not only for class members whose brakes [*23] have manifested a deficiency, but also for those whose brakes have performed satisfactorily").

The FDUTPA allows "civil private causes of action for both declaratory and injunctive relief and for damages." Rollins, Inc. v. Butland, 951 So. 2d 860 , 869 (Fla. 2d DCA 2006); see Fla. Stat. § 501.211 . To state a claim for damages under the FDUTPA, a plaintiff must show: "(1) a deceptive act or unfair practice; (2) causation; and (3) actual damages." Kia Motors, 985 So. 2d at 1140 . "A deceptive practice is one that is 'likely to mislead' consumers." Rollins, 951 So. 2d at 869 (quoting Davis v. Powertel, Inc., 776 So. 2d 971 , 974 (Fla. 1st DCA 2000)). Courts have described an unfair practice as "'one that offends established public policy and one that is immoral, unethical, oppressive, unscrupulous or substantially injurious to consumers.'" Id . (quoting Samuels v. King Motor Co. of Fort Lauderdale, 782 So. 2d 489 , 499 (Fla. 4th DCA 2001)). To demonstrate causation, a plaintiff need not plead actual, subjective reliance on the alleged misrepresentation or omission. See, e.g., Fitzpatrick v. Gen. Mills, Inc., 635 F.3d 1279 , 1282-83 (11th Cir. 2011) (reviewing FDUTPA claim); State, Office of Att'y Gen., Dep't of Legal Affairs v. Commerce Commercial, LLC, 946 So. 2d 1253 , 1258 (Fla. 1st DCA 2007) ("A deceptive or unfair trade practice constitutes a somewhat unique tortious act because, although it is similar to a claim of fraud, it is different in that, unlike fraud, a party asserting a deceptive trade practice claim need not show actual reliance on the representation or omission at issue." (citation omitted)). Rather, causation under the FDUTPA considers "whether the alleged practice was likely to deceive a consumer acting reasonably in the same circumstances." Commerce Commercial, 946 So. 2d at 1258 (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).
Lastly, the FDUTPA limits damages to "actual damages," which do not include consequential damages. Rollins, 951 So. 2d at 869 . "The measure of actual damages is the difference in the market value of the product or service in the condition in which it was delivered and its market value in the condition in which it should have been delivered according to the contract of the parties." Id . (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).
Defendants raise various challenges to Plaintiffs' proposed classes. Specifically, Defendants argue that (1) neither class is readily ascertainable without being impermissibly overbroad; (2) individual questions overwhelm any common questions under Rule 23(a)(2) for both the breach of warranty claim and the FDUTPA claim; (3) the named Plaintiffs are not typical and cannot adequately represent the class under Rule 23(a)(3) and (a)(4) ; (4) individual questions predominate over any common questions as to the damages class under Rule 23(b)(3) ; (5) Plaintiffs' proposed damages models do not satisfactorily measure only those damages attributable to Plaintiffs' theory of liability; and (6) the injunctive relief class is impermissibly seeking individualized damages. (Doc. 89). The Court will consider each argument in turn.
1. Adequacy of Proposed Class Definitions 
An implied prerequisite of Rule 23 is that the proposed class must be "adequately defined and clearly ascertainable." Little v. T-Mobile USA, Inc., 691 F.3d 1302 , 1304 (11th Cir. 2012) (citation and internal [*24] quotation marks omitted). A proposed class that is overbroad is impermissible. See, e.g., Bussey v. Macon Cty. Greyhound Park, Inc., 562 F. App'x 782 , 788 (11th Cir. 2014); Walewski v. Zenimax Media, Inc., 502 F. App'x 857 , 861 (11th Cir. 2012). "An identifiable class exists if its members can be ascertained by reference to objective criteria." Bussey, 562 F. App'x at 787 (citation omitted). This should be an "administratively feasible" task, meaning "that identifying class members is a manageable process that does not require much, if any, individual inquiry."  Id. at 787-88 (citation omitted).
In this case, Plaintiffs define the damages class as including all individuals who own or owned real property in Florida in which a Goodman product containing a copper evaporator coil was installed from July 1, 2006 to present and who subsequently suffered damages from the leakage of refrigerant. Defendants argue that this class is impermissibly overbroad because it encompasses all individuals whose Goodman product experienced refrigerant leaks for any reason; it is not limited to those individuals whose systems experienced refrigerant leaks due to formicary corrosion in the copper evaporator coil. (Doc. 89 at 20). Further, Defendants argue there is no evidence in existence that could limit the class to only those who experienced leaks due to formicary corrosion, so the proposed class cannot be objectively ascertained.
In response, Plaintiffs point out that ascertainability at the class certification stage does not require that a plaintiff actually identify all class members, but rather, it only requires a plaintiff to demonstrate that class members can be identified in reference to objective criteria. See, e.g., Bush v. Calloway Consol. Grp. River City, Inc., No. 3:10-CV-841-J-37MCR, 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 40450 , [2012 BL 85128], 2012 WL 1016871 , at *4 (M.D. Fla. Mar. 26, 2012) (citations omitted). And, in contrast to Defendants' assertion, Plaintiffs believe that class members can be readily ascertained. Plaintiffs cite to Goodman's warranty database, which contains information concerning model numbers, serial numbers, and dates of installation for consumers. Goodman maintains records when it provides a replacement coil to consumers, and the consumers' identities can be obtained from Goodman's contractors and dealers. Plaintiffs assert that class members can also submit invoices or other evidence showing they paid to have their coil replaced. (Doc. 110 at 7).
In Plaintiffs' reply brief, they reinforce the argument that the class definition is properly composed of all those who suffered damages due to leakage of refrigerant. Plaintiffs make no attempt to narrow the class to those who suffered damages due to formicary corrosion-related leaks. Indeed, Plaintiffs assert that they need not determine why each potential class member's coil leaked, because the reason why each coil leaked is neither relevant to the FDUTPA claim nor to the breach of express warranty claim. (Doc. 110 at 8).
Plaintiffs' exclusive theory of liability in this case is that Goodman's copper evaporator coils possess a design and/or manufacturing defect that causes the coils to develop formicary corrosion [*25] and fail prematurely. The class definitions must match Plaintiffs' theory of liability for each cause of action. See, e.g., Fitzpatrick v. Gen. Mills, Inc., 635 F.3d 1279 , 1283 (11th Cir. 2011) ("While we agree with the legal analysis of the district court, because the definition of the class it certified was in conflict with that analysis, we are uncertain of exactly what class it intended to certify."). Contrary to Plaintiffs' assertion, the breach of express warranty claim requires Plaintiffs to (1) demonstrate that each class member's coil actually experienced a leakage of refrigerant, and (2) that this leak was due to the alleged defect—formicary corrosion. In other words, this claim requires the defect to manifest. If the defect has not manifested or a consumer has experienced refrigerant leakage for another reason, then a consumer has suffered no injury based on the theory of liability in this case and is not entitled to recovery as a member of the class. See, e.g., Kia Motors, 985 So. 2d at 1140 ("Without individual inquiry, there is no way in adjudicating this case to determine whether the need for a particular repair was based on normal wear, a defective original part, . . . environmental factors, such as weather . . ., the presence of foreign objects in the braking system, the failure of parts other than the braking system, poor workmanship by a third party, or individual . . . habits.").
Defendants take great issue with Plaintiffs' attempt to equate the "number of warranty claims on copper coils" to the "actual leakage of refrigerant" to the "actual leakage of refrigerant due to formicary corrosion." Defendants argue that this conclusion is entirely unsupported by the evidence, which results in an impermissibly overbroad class that cannot be narrowed. Defendants assert that (1) contractors regularly misdiagnose problems, so not all returned coils even exhibited a leak, and (2) many of the returned coils that did exhibit leaks had leaks that were not caused by formicary corrosion, but were caused by other issues. Indeed, even Plaintiffs' expert notes that copper evaporator coils can and do fail for a wide variety of reasons. (Doc. 76-6, ¶ 19). Sikorsky does state that problems due to installation errors or mechanical failures are typically manifested a short time after installation, but he also did not review Goodman warranty claims data to support this statement. (Doc. 89-1 at 147:9-152:3).
Further, Goodman has a policy and practice of accepting nearly all warranty claims without conducting independent testing to verify each claim's validity. Goodman says it tested a small subset (3%) of the returned coils, and even within this subset, not all coils exhibited leaks, and those coils that did exhibit leaks did not uniformly do so due to formicary corrosion. (Doc. 89-2, ¶ 14). For example, in October 2009, Goodman undertook internal testing of 34 copper evaporator coils that were returned from Winter Haven, Florida. (Doc. 85-2 at 3, Exh. S). Testing demonstrated that 19 of the 34 coils (56%) had leaks indicative of formicary corrosion; 11 of the 34 coils (32%) contained no leaks and were considered good coils; 2 of the 34 coils ([*26] 6%) were damaged possibly by the installer; and 2 of the 34 coils (6%) had leaks that were not indicative of formicary corrosion. ( Id.). Thus, while all of the warranty claims in this testing group were submitted as "leaking evaporator coils" and new replacement coils were sent to customers, 38 percent of the returned coils were found not defective or were damaged by improper handling. ( Id.). The official report on this particular test notes that "formicary corrosion has been the major reason for failure on the returned coils." (Doc. 85-2 at 6, Exh. T). This may be true, as demonstrated by the fact that 56 percent of the coils tested on this occasion exhibited formicary corrosion. However, it also demonstrates that a substantial number of coils returned with a reported failure mode of "leaking refrigerant" either did not contain any leaks or exhibited leaks caused by other issues.
In response, Plaintiffs assert that "the argument that some members did not experience the problem is no reason to deny class certification." (Doc. 110 at 12). They cite to Butler v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 727 F.3d 796 , 799 (7th Cir. 2013), to support this assertion. In Butler, Sears argued that most of the members of the damages class had not experienced any mold problems in their washing machines, and the court held that this was not an impediment to class certification. Id . Whatever the reasoning of the Butler court, it is not applicable here. Florida courts have clearly held that manifestation of a defect is required to maintain a claim for breach of warranty, either privately or on behalf of a class, and the Court must apply Florida law. See, e.g., Kia Motors, 985 So. 2d at 1138-39 . The class must be limited to those individuals who suffered damages caused by the leakage of refrigerant caused by Goodman's allegedly defective copper evaporator coils, and the leaks in the coils must be caused by formicary corrosion.
It is impossible to see how Plaintiffs can identify class members in reference to objective criteria. Even if the Court were to conclude that the class is properly defined as including instances of all refrigerant leaks (which it does not), the class definition would still be overbroad because Plaintiffs attempt to equate warranty claims rates to actual leakage rates. The Winter Haven testing sample described above demonstrates the overbreadth of this definition, as 32 percent of those coils tested did not exhibit any leaks. At this stage, ascertainability does not require a plaintiff to actually identify all class members, yet it does require a plaintiff to demonstrate that class members can be identified in reference to objective criteria. See, e.g., Bush, 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 40450 , [2012 BL 85128], 2012 WL 1016871 , at *4. In this case, Plaintiffs have not demonstrated, and the Court has not independently discovered, any objective criteria that would make it possible for class members to be properly identified for purposes of Plaintiffs' breach of express warranty claim for both the proposed damages class and the injunctive relief class.
As to Plaintiffs' FDUTPA claim, Defendants assert that the proposed classes are overbroad because they could include [*27] persons who were not exposed to Defendants' alleged deception and/or who did not rely on such deception. (Doc. 89 at 28). Throughout their filings, Defendants assert that actual reliance is a necessary element of an FDUTPA claim, while Plaintiffs assert that actual reliance is not. The Court explained above that Plaintiffs are correct and Florida law does not require a plaintiff to demonstrate actual, subjective reliance to assert a violation of the FDUTPA. See, e.g., Zlotnick v. Premier Sales Grp., 480 F.3d 1281 , 1284 (11th Cir. 2007) ("The Florida Supreme Court has noted that 'deception occurs if there is a representation, omission, or practice that is likely to mislead the consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances, to the consumer's detriment.'"). To prove deception on a classwide basis, Plaintiffs must still demonstrate exposure to the same misrepresentations or omissions, however, and they wholly fail to explain how they would be able to narrow both the damages class and the injunctive relief class to account for this. See, e.g., James D. Hinson Elec. Contracting Co. v. BellSouth Telecommunications, Inc., 275 F.R.D. 638 , 645-46 (M.D. Fla. 2011); Egwuatu v. South Lubes, Inc., 976 So. 2d 50 , 52-54 (Fla. 1st DCA 2008).
The damages class definition is untenable for purposes of Plaintiffs' FDUTPA claim for an additional reason, as well. The damages class limits membership to consumers who were damaged by having to pay to repair or replace their Goodman products due to leakage of refrigerant. However, FDUTPA claims are limited to "actual damages," and actual damages "do not include consequential damages, such as repair damages or resale damages." Kia Motors, 985 So. 2d at 1140 .
The proposed damages class and the proposed injunctive relief class are not ascertainable for purposes of the either the breach of warranty claim or the FDUTPA claim. Rather than undertake to redefine the class definitions, however, the Court will proceed to analyze the remaining requirements of Rule 23(a) and (b) . As will be seen below, any amendment to the class definition would be futile.
2. Rule 23(a) Requirements 
Plaintiffs must also satisfy the four requirements of Rule 23(a) . "Under Rule 23(a), every putative class first must satisfy the prerequisites of 'numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy of representation.'" Vega, 564 F.3d at 1265 (citing Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a) ).
a. Numerosity 
Plaintiffs must demonstrate that "the class is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(1) . "[W]hile there is no fixed numerosity rule, generally less than twenty-one is inadequate, more than forty adequate, with numbers between varying according to other factors." Cox v. Am. Cast Iron Pipe Co., 784 F.2d 1546 , 1553 (11th Cir. 1986) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted). In this case, Goodman appears to concede that the numerosity requirement has been met. From 2006 through 2014, Goodman shipped a total of 540,581 copper evaporator coils into the State of Florida, and these coils were designed and manufactured consistently. (Doc. 76 at 17-18). This number does not reflect the number of potential class members who own or owned real property in Florida in which a Goodman product was installed, which would necessarily [*28] be a lower number. This number likewise does not reflect the number of consumers in Florida who actually experienced formicary corrosion-related leaks, which would further decrease the number. Nevertheless, it is clear from this figure that the numerosity requirement has been met, as the proposed classes would still likely be in the thousands.
b. Commonality 
Commonality requires that "there are questions of law or fact common to the class." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(2) . To satisfy commonality, Rule 23 "'does not require that all the questions of law and fact raised by the dispute be common,' or that the common questions of law or fact 'predominate' over individual issues." Vega, 564 F.3d at 1268 (quoting Cox, 784 F.2d at 1557 ). Individual differences concerning treatment or damages will not generally defeat a finding of commonality; it "may be established where there are allegations of common conduct or standardized conduct by the defendant directed toward members of the proposed class." Strube v. Am. Equity Inv. Life Ins. Co., 226 F.R.D. 688 , 695 (M.D. Fla. 2005) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted). The Supreme Court has explained that "[c]ommonality requires the plaintiff to demonstrate that the class members have suffered the same injury." Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338 , 349-50 , 131 S. Ct. 2541 , 180 L. Ed. 2d 374 (2011). The focus is not on the "raising of common questions—even in droves—but, rather the capacity of a classwide proceeding to generate common answers apt to drive the resolution of the litigation."  Id. at 350 (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).
Plaintiffs assert that commonality has been satisfied because there are several issues of law or fact that are common to the class. They allege that some common questions at issue in this case are whether (1) Goodman's copper evaporator coils have a propensity to develop formicary corrosion and prematurely fail; (2) Goodman had knowledge that its coils have a propensity to develop formicary corrosion and prematurely fail; and (3) Goodman's omission of this material fact was likely to deceive a consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances. (Doc. 76 at 19). They assert that "the ultimate question of liability is whether Goodman knowingly sold units that contained defective evaporator coils." (Doc. 107 at 13).
In response, Defendants argue that none of Plaintiffs' allegedly common questions is common. They assert that even if Plaintiffs could show that Goodman copper evaporator coils have a "propensity to develop formicary corrosion and prematurely fail," or that Goodman knew of such propensity, that still does not answer the question of whether and why any particular coil leaked. (Doc. 94 at 28). They also argue that individual questions related to exposure and reliance on Defendants' allegedly deceptive marketing materials are not common for purposes of Plaintiffs' FDUTPA claim.
As will be discussed in the predominance section below, whether Goodman's copper evaporator coils have a uniform defect is a common question, but it does not produce a common answer, which is the main focus of the commonality inquiry. Wal-Mart, 564 U.S. at 350 . However, whether Defendants had knowledge of an alleged defect [*29] is a common question that will produce a common answer. And in the absence of a requirement of reliance, the question of whether Defendants' omission of an alleged defect would likely deceive a consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances is also able to produce a common answer. "These common questions are sufficient to satisfy the low hurdle of Rule 23(a)(2) ." Williams v. Mohawk Indus., 568 F.3d 1350 , 1356 (11th Cir. 2009). Importantly, whether or not common questions of law or fact exist is a separate inquiry from whether common or individual questions of law or fact predominate the case. The Court holds that commonality has been satisfied in this case for both the damages class and the injunctive relief class for both causes of action. See Strube, 226 F.R.D. at 695 .
c. Typicality 
Typicality requires that "the claims or defenses of the representative parties are typical of the claims or defenses of the class." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(3) . Typicality is satisfied where the claims or defenses of the class representative and the class arise from the same event or pattern of practice and are based on the same legal theory. Kornberg v. Carnival Cruise Lines, Inc., 741 F.2d 1332 , 1337 (11th Cir. 1984). Importantly, "the class representative must have the same interest and suffer the same injury as the class members." Rosario-Guerrero v. Orange Blossom Harvesting, Inc., 265 F.R.D. 619 , 627 (M.D. Fla. 2010) (citing Busby v. JRHBW Realty, Inc., 513 F.3d 1314 , 1322 (11th Cir. 2008)). "The typicality requirement is generally met if the class representative and the class members received the same unlawful conduct, irrespective of whether the fact patterns that underlie each claim vary." Id . It is a "permissive" requirement, and "representative claims are 'typical' if they are reasonably co-extensive with those of absent class members; they need not be substantially identical." Alhassid v. Bank of Am., N.A., 307 F.R.D. 684 , 697 (S.D. Fla. 2015) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).
The details related to the named Plaintiffs in this class are recited supra, Part I.B.1-4. Defendants focus on the individual factual differences of each named Plaintiffs claims, but as noted, the primary focus is on the similarity of the named Plaintiffs' interest and injury to that of the class, as well as the similarity of Defendants' conduct received by the named Plaintiffs and the class.
i. Standing of PB Property 
Defendants assert that PB Property cannot be a class representative because it lacks standing. (Doc. 89 at 31). Defendants allege that PB Property did not purchase the Goodman products at issue, does not own the properties where those products are located, is not a party to the applicable warranties, and paid no replacement costs. Defendants cite to the deposition of Mr. Mansouri, the owner of PB Property, in support. (Doc. 89-4 at 70:23-75:19).
In response, Plaintiffs note that an agent "who acted as an agent during the course of a transaction involved in the litigation, may sue for damages suffered by the principal." Global Aerospace, Inc. v. Platinum Jet Mgmt., LLC, 488 F. App'x 338 , 340 (11th Cir. 2012) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted). Not only is Mr. Mansouri the owner of PB Property, he is also the principal of various entities that owned [*30] the properties in which the Goodman products were installed. (Doc. 107-6 at 24:8-11). It is also false that PB Property paid no replacement costs, as Mr. Mansouri testified that on at least one occasion, he paid for the repair costs related to a leaking evaporator coil. ( Id. at 66:10-24). The Court finds that PB Property has standing to sue in this case.
ii. Breach of Warranty 
Defendants argue that none of the named Plaintiffs' interests are typical of the interests of the class because breach of warranty claimants must show that the allege defect manifested and caused the injury, and the named Plaintiffs cannot prove manifestation and causation as to their individual claims. (Doc. 89 at 31). Defendants allege that they would have unique defenses as to each named Plaintiff, as there is no evidence showing that any of the named Plaintiffs' coils failed due to formicary corrosion. Accordingly, Defendants assert that the named Plaintiffs cannot be typical class representatives of any class members whose coils did in fact fail due to formicary corrosion. Defendants further argue that there can be no typical representative plaintiff with regards to manifestation of defect and causation in this case, because these issues inherently require individual inquiries and defenses.
By contrast, Plaintiffs focus their typicality argument on demonstrating that each named Plaintiff purchased a Goodman product, experienced leakage of refrigerant and other issues caused by problems with the copper evaporator coil, and incurred damages as a result of having to pay for labor and refrigerant relating to coil repairs and replacements. (Doc. 76 at 21). Thus, Plaintiffs argue that their claims are typical of the claims of the class, because they and all other class members own or owned Goodman products with defective copper evaporator coils and were subjected to the same unlawful conduct.
Both parties' arguments touch upon the merits of the Plaintiffs' claim for breach of express warranty; the Court is required to analyze the merits to the extent necessary to rule on the availability of class certification. The fundamental question when considering typicality is whether the named Plaintiffs have the same interest and suffered the same injury as the rest of the class. The underlying facts related to each plaintiff need not be identical; only the "essential characteristics" need to be the same. See Rosario-Guerrero, 265 F.R.D. at 627 . In this case, the named Plaintiffs all share a common interest—they all own or owned a Goodman product with a copper evaporator coil—with the rest of the class. Further, the named Plaintiffs all suffered a similar injury—they all experienced leakage of refrigerant from their Goodman product and incurred out-of-pocket expenses for labor to replace lost refrigerant and to repair and replace the copper evaporator coil—as the rest of the class. It is true that the named Plaintiffs will need to prove that the copper evaporator coils were uniformly defective and that this defect caused their injury, and that Defendants [*31] will assert unique affirmative defenses against each plaintiff based on unique underlying factual circumstances. Nevertheless, the Court finds that the named Plaintiffs' claims for breach of express warranty are sufficiently typical of the claims of the class.
iii. FDUTPA 
Defendants argue that the named Plaintiffs are not typical representatives for purposes of their FDUTPA claim. They assert that most of the named Plaintiffs never saw, let alone relied on, any statement by Goodman in deciding to purchase a Goodman product. (Doc. 89 at 33). Moreover, Defendants note that Plaintiffs certainly did not rely on the same material as one another and the numerous putative class members.
As has already been explained, a plaintiff need not demonstrate actual reliance on an alleged misrepresentation or omission to bring a claim under the FDUTPA. Plaintiffs allege that they are typical representatives of the class because they are not required to prove that they relied on any representation by Goodman or even that Goodman had knowledge of a deceptive practice. See, e.g., Gavron v. Weather Shield Mfg., Inc., 819 F. Supp. 2d 1297 , 1301-02 (S.D. Fla. 2011) (reviewing cases). Rather, Plaintiffs assert that "deception occurs if there is a representation, omission, or practice that is likely to mislead the consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances, to the consumer's detriment." PNR, Inc. v. Beacon Prop. Mgmt., Inc., 842 So. 2d 773 , 777 (Fla. 2003) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).
Plaintiffs are correct that they need not demonstrate subjective reliance or Defendants' knowledge of a deceptive practice. However, Defendants do have a point regarding the issue of exposure to the same allegedly deceptive materials for purposes of class certification. In FDUTPA cases, courts usually focus their analysis on the issue of reliance on an alleged misrepresentation and do not consider the issue of exposure to different representations. What can be synthesized from various cases analyzing the FDUTPA is that exposure to the same deceptive practice can play an important part of the class action analysis. See, e.g., James D. Hinson, 275 F.R.D. at 645 . The test asks what a reasonable consumer would do in the same circumstances; this requirement relates to Plaintiffs' ability to prove the element of deception on a classwide basis. See id . In Pop's Pancakes, Inc. v. NuCO2, Inc., 251 F.R.D. 677 (S.D. Fla. 2008), the district court explained that the plaintiffs did not satisfy typicality because
the representations made to them before receiving the property tax involve, and after receiving the invoice are different from other class members, and thus the fact that one of the named Plaintiffs may be able to prove its case, would not necessarily establish the elements necessary to prove the other class members' cases, specifically whether the property invoice was deceptive.
Id. at 683 . The court went on to say that "it is not the Plaintiffs' reliance that is the issue, but whether it was reasonable under the circumstances, which vary for each Plaintiff."  Id. at 686 . In other words, the representations made to each plaintiff differed; [*32] even when reviewing each representation by an objective standard, the issue remained that a representation made to one plaintiff could be found to be deceptive, while a different representation made to another plaintiff could be found not to be deceptive.

This issue is further underscored by reference to two Florida First District Court of Appeal decisions. In Powertel, the defendant had been selling brand name cell phones without disclosing the fact that the phones had been modified to render them inoperable with any other cellular service provider. Powertel, 776 So. 2d at 972-73 . The plaintiffs sought relief under the FDUTPA, alleging that this nondisclosure had reduced the value of the phone in each case.  Id. at 973 . On appeal, the First DCA held that a showing of individual reliance by a consumer is not a necessary element under the FDUTPA.  Id. at 974 . The court explained that the proposed class could be certified as a class action because "[a]ll of the claims shared one essential common feature; that is, the alleged [deceptive] practice reduced the value of the telephones."  Id. at 975 .
The First DCA clarified its holding in Powertel seven years later. In Egwuatu, the court considered whether class certification was appropriate as to a consumer's claim that the defendant violated the FDUTPA by charging a tax it was collecting from consumers when purchasing an oil change by deceptively labeling the tax as an "environmental fee." Egwuatu, 976 So. 2d at 51 . The court explained that "[t]he absence of the element of reliance . . . does not guarantee that a deceptive trade practice claim will be amenable to class litigation. There might be many other reasons why class certification would be inappropriate."  Id. at 53 . One such reason, which was upheld by the appellate court, was that "there would be many differences in the facts supporting the claims of the individual plaintiffs. This conclusion was based on the fact that the defendants have employed a variety of methods over the years to inform customers that the environmental fee was not a tax." Id . The different representations made to different plaintiffs over the years precluded class certification because individual inquiries would be necessary as to deception. Egwuatu is distinguishable from Powertel because Powertel involved all plaintiffs being exposed to the same deceptive practice.
This case is similar toEgwuatu in that each named Plaintiff was exposed to different representations, and each member of the proposed class would also have been exposed to different representations. For example, the named Plaintiffs were exposed to different representations made by third-party contractors or dealers, Plaintiff Jewell further reviewed representations made on Goodman's website, and Plaintiffs Mr. and Mrs. Wagner researched the Amana brand online. Different plaintiffs within the proposed class will have been exposed to different, varying statements alleged by Plaintiffs to constitute misrepresentations. Accordingly, none of the named Plaintiffs can be said to be a typical representative [*33] of the class for purposes of the misrepresentation component of the FDUTPA claim.
As to Plaintiffs' FDUTPA claim that Defendants omitted a material fact from its advertising to consumers, the named Plaintiffs do have interests and injuries typical to those of the class. This is because the alleged omission is the same—the alleged deceptive practice is the same. Plaintiffs assert that Defendants failed to disclose the fact that Goodman copper evaporator coils are defectively prone to develop formicary corrosion. Whether or not this omission would be likely to deceive a consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances is a question that applies equally to all class members, and the named Plaintiffs satisfy the typicality requirement for the purposes of this particular claim. See, e.g., Powertel, 776 So. 2d at 972-74 .
d. Adequacy 
Adequacy requires that "the representative parties will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(4) . This requirement asks "(1) whether there are any substantial conflicts of interest between the named representatives of the class and the class members; and (2) whether the representatives will adequately prosecute the action." Rosario-Guerrero, 265 F.R.D. at 628 . It "serves to uncover any conflict of interest that named parties may have with the class they represent," and it also "consider[s] the competency and any conflicts that the class counsel may have." Id . (citations omitted). In this instance, the named Plaintiffs can be said to adequately represent the class because they have interests in common with, and not antagonistic to, the interests of the class. Griffin v. Carlin, 755 F.2d 1516 , 1533 (11th Cir. 1985). In addition, Plaintiffs' attorneys are qualified and experienced in complex class action litigation. The Court finds that Plaintiffs have satisfied this requirement.
3. Rule 23(b)(3) Requirements 
Classification under Rule 23(b)(3) is appropriate when damages in the form of monetary relief is sought, "in which a class action would save time, effort, and money and would promote uniformity without sacrificing procedural fairness." Holmes v. Cont'l Can Co., 706 F.2d 1144 , 1156 (11th Cir. 1983). In addition to the requirements of Rule 23(a) , there are two additional requirements for certification under (b)(3) : "[1] Common questions [of law or fact] must predominate over any questions that affect individual parties, and [2] the class device must be superior to all other available methods for the fair and efficient adjudication of the dispute." Id . 
Plaintiffs must first establish that common questions of law or fact predominate over any individual, plaintiff-specific issues. "'It is not necessary that all questions of fact or law be common, but only that some questions are common and that they predominate over individual questions.'" James D. Hinson, 275 F.R.D. at 644 (quoting Klay v. Humana, Inc., 382 F.3d 1241 , 1254 (11th Cir. 2004)). "Common issues of fact and law predominate if they 'ha[ve] a direct impact on every class member's effort to establish liability and on every class member's entitlement to . . . monetary relief.'" Id . (quoting Williams v. Mohawk Indus., 568 F.3d 1350 , 1357 (11th Cir. 2009)). "'Where, after adjudication of the classwide issues, plaintiffs [*34] must still introduce a great deal of individualized proof or argue a number of individualized legal points to establish most or all of the elements of their individual claims, such claims are not suitable for class certification under Rule 23(b)(3) .'" Id (quoting Klay, 382 F.3d at 1255 ). The Eleventh Circuit has explained that "predominance requires a qualitative assessment, . . . and the relative importance of the common versus individual questions also matters." Electrolux, 817 F.3d 1225 , [817 F.3D 1225], 2016 WL 1085517 , at *5 (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).
In this case, Plaintiffs assert that common questions of fact or law predominate. They argue that Defendants' unlawful conduct is common to the class—whether the coils were defective and whether Goodman had knowledge of the defect—and predominates over any individual issue related to causation or damages. Oppositely, Goodman argues that individual issues related to causation and damages predominate over any common questions.
Upon a thorough review of the record, and considering the relative importance of the common versus individual questions, the Court finds that individual questions related to causation and damages predominate over any common questions related to Defendants' conduct for both the breach of express warranty and the FDUTPA claims. As to the breach of express warranty claim, Florida law requires manifestation of the defect, causation, and pre-suit notice. First, the Court finds that individual questions concerning liability, causation, and damages predominate over any common questions. "Despite Plaintiffs' repeated characterizations that this case involves a uniform defect that can be proven through common proof of causation, the record suggests otherwise." City of St. Petersburg v. Total Containment, Inc., 265 F.R.D. 630 , 646 (S.D. Fla. 2010). In Total Containment, the district court explained that predominance is lacking where the plaintiffs' ability to demonstrate causation by generalized proof is lacking. See  id. at 640-41 . Indeed, "generalized proof" of causation must be available "before common questions can be found to predominate. . . . [Generalized proof] is not well suited for those cases in which no one set of operative facts establishes liability and no single proximate cause equally applies to each potential class member."  Id. at 641 (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).
In Total Containment, the product at issue was manufactured and distributed by various entities over a 15-year period, and numerous models were produced.  Id. at 641 . In this case, Goodman manufactured the copper evaporator coils for all relevant years, and only one model was produced. The facts of this case are clearly less complex than those of Total Containment, yet this does not mean that generalized proof of causation is available in this case; there are significant hurdles that remain. Plaintiffs seek to prove a uniform defect with generalized proof, but there is simply a lack of evidence to support such a showing. See  id. at 640-41 . Some examples of individual questions related to causation might ask whether [*35] the coil failed due to environmental factors, normal wear and tear, improper installation, other types of corrosion, or misuse. See  id. at 641 ("In addition, each class member will likely have encountered different installation, maintenance, and environmental conditions.").
Even if Plaintiffs could produce evidence that Goodman's copper evaporator coils contain a common defect—the propensity to develop formicary corrosion and leak refrigerant—the question of whether and why a particular coil failed are individual questions that will be unique to each class member and would overwhelm the litigation. It is undisputed that copper evaporator coils can fail for a number of reasons, and air conditioning systems can leak refrigerant for a number of reasons. Without individual inquiry, there is no way to determine if a plaintiff's Goodman product experienced a leakage of refrigerant due to a failure in the evaporator coil, and if so, whether the leak was due to formicary corrosion. These individual questions of causation predominate. See, e.g., Total Containment, 265 F.R.D. at 640-41 ; Kia Motors, 985 So. 2d at 1140 .
Likewise, individual questions of fact predominate over common questions for purposes of Plaintiffs' FDUTPA claim. Plaintiffs must demonstrate that Defendants' misrepresentations and omissions would be likely to deceive a consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances, to the consumer's detriment. As to Plaintiffs' misrepresentations claim, the named Plaintiffs and other putative class members were not exposed to the same representations and statements. It would require individual inquiry to determine the various statements any particular plaintiff was exposed to, and then, whether each statement would be likely to deceive a consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances. This inquiry is "relevant to the element of deception," because the test asks whether the conduct "was likely to mislead a consumer acting reasonably in the circumstances." James D. Hinson, 275 F.R.D. at 645 . Individual circumstances in which each putative class member was subject to different representations could affect whether a reasonable consumer would have been misled by Defendants' conduct in the same circumstances. See id . 
Individual questions of fact likewise predominate over common questions as to Plaintiffs' FDUTPA omission claim. Plaintiffs allege that Defendants omitted material information related to the defective nature of Goodman's copper evaporator coils. In order to prove Defendants' liability for this claim, then, Plaintiffs must first demonstrate that the copper evaporator coils were indeed uniformly defective. "Plaintiffs have repeatedly characterized this case as involving a uniform defect that causes general harm." Total Containment, 265 F.R.D. at 637 . However, "generalized proof" necessary to establish the existence of a uniform defect is not available in this case, as explained above in the Court's discussion of Plaintiffs' breach of warranty claim. And if there is no generalized proof available to demonstrate the existence of a uniform defect, [*36] there can be no general evidence of a deceptive practice. This issue predominates over the common question of reliance (i.e., causation) by Plaintiffs and other putative class members.
As a final matter, "the individualized nature of determining putative class members' damages also contribute to a lack of predominance in this case."  Id. at 641 . The presence of individualized damages does not necessarily preclude a finding that common issues predominate, but "it certainly does not help."  Id. at 642 .
In sum, individual questions of fact predominate over any common questions for both causes of action for purposes of Plaintiffs' damages class.
4. Rule 23(b)(2) Requirements 
Class certification under Rule 23(b)(2) is appropriate where "the party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on grounds that apply generally to the class, so that final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief is appropriate respecting the class as a whole." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2) . "The very nature of a (b)(2) class is that it is homogeneous without any conflicting interests between the members of the class." Holmes, 706 F.2d at 1155 . "Monetary relief may be obtained in a Rule 23(b)(2) class action so long as the predominant relief sought is injunctive or declaratory." Murray v. Auslander, 244 F.3d 807 , 812 (11th Cir. 2001) (citing Allison v. Citgo Petroleum Corp., 151 F.3d 402 , 411 (5th Cir. 1998); Holmes, 706 F.2d at 1155 ). "'[M]onetary relief predominates in (b)(2) class actions unless it is incidental to requested injunctive or declaratory relief.'" Id . (quoting Allison, 151 F.3d at 415 (emphasis added)). "'Ideally, incidental damages should be only those to which class members automatically would be entitled once liability to the class (or subclass) as a whole is established. . . . Liability for incidental damages should not . . . entail complex individualized determinations.'" Id . (quoting Allison, 151 F.3d at 415 ). The question is whether plaintiffs seek damages as a "group remedy" or whether they seek damages based on individualized harm, which would "compel[] an inquiry into each class member's individual circumstances." Id . If damages depend more on the varying circumstances and merits of each class member's case, then the class's damages claims predominate over the class's claims for injunctive or declaratory relief. See id . 
In this case, Plaintiffs "request that the Court declare Goodman's air conditioners are defective and provide the necessary injunctive relief such that Class Members who experience future [coil] failures will be reimbursed by Goodman for the cost to replace and repair the defective coils." (Doc. 76 at 28). Defendants argue, among other things, that Plaintiffs are improperly seeking future individualized monetary payouts under the guise of injunctive relief. (Doc. 89 at 33-34).
The Court agrees with Defendants. The proposed injunctive relief class seems to be disguising a true request for future, individualized monetary payouts in the event that consumers who have purchased Goodman products experience coil failure and incur labor costs related to the issue. See Wal-Mart, 564 U.S. at 359-60 . While any injunctive relief would declare Goodman's copper evaporator coils "defective," only those class [*37] members whose coils manifested a defect and incurred damages in the future would be entitled to any concrete recovery. Thus, the monetary relief sought is not simply incidental to the injunctive or declaratory relief; it is the main relief. This is not permitted by Rule 23(b)(2) . See id . 
Furthermore, as noted above, FDUTPA claims are limited to actual damages, and "do not include consequential damages, such as repair damages." Kia Motors, 985 So. 2d at 1140 . The monetary damages sought by Plaintiffs for purposes of their FDUTPA claim are improper and unavailable.
5. Whether Plaintiffs' Damages Models are Correct 
Plaintiffs rely on an expert, Frank Bernatowicz, for their damages models. Defendants argue that his models do not satisfy Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, 133 S. Ct. 1426 , 185 L. Ed. 2d 515 (2013), because they are overinclusive and fail to measure only the harm attributable to the only purported defect, formicary corrosion. (Doc. 115 at 2). Comcast requires that, for a class to be certified, the damages model must measure, on a classwide basis, "only those damages attributable to [Plaintiffs'] theory [of liability]."  Id. at 1433 . "Calculations need not be exact, but the class-certification stage (as at trial), any model supporting a plaintiff's damages case must be consistent with its liability case." Id . (citations omitted).
Bernatowicz offers two damages models: one for out-of-pocket expenses, and one for future repair costs or diminution in value. However, neither model limits damages to those losses sustained due to formicary corrosion, which is Plaintiffs' exclusive theory of liability. There is an additional issue related to FDUTPA damages. That statute limits damages to "actual damages," which is defined as "[the] premium received [due to] the alleged misrepresentation." Randolph v. J.M. Smucker Co., 303 F.R.D. 679 , 698 (S.D. Fla. 2014). Neither damages model purports to measure any price premium received by the alleged misrepresentations or omissions.
Plaintiffs argue that their damages models are based on Goodman's own standardized repair cost schedules and thus sufficiently calculate damages as to class members who had to pay out-of-pocket repair costs. Plaintiffs allege that they were sold defective products, and the most reasonable model of damages is to compensate Plaintiffs and the class for the cost to repair the defective products.
An in depth analysis of Plaintiffs' proposed damages models is unnecessary, as Plaintiffs' proposed classes fail for other reasons. It is nevertheless worth noting that Plaintiffs' damages model must reflect damages incurred due to formicary corrosion-related issues only, because this is their theory of liability. Plaintiffs' damages models fail at the present time as to the FDUTPA claim because they do not take into account any price premium received by the alleged misrepresentations and omissions.
C. Defendants' Motion to Strike Plaintiffs' Trial Expert Disclosures (Doc. 122) 
Goodman's Motion to Strike Plaintiff's Trial Expert Disclosures will be denied as moot, as class certification has been denied.
IV. CONCLUSION 
For the reasons set forth above, it is hereby [*38] ORDERED:
1. Plaintiffs' "Motion for Class Certification" (Doc. 76, filed Mar. 2, 2015) is DENIED;
2. Defendants' "Motion to Exclude the Opinions of Paul J. Sikorsky" (Doc. 88, filed Apr. 30, 2015) is GRANTED;
3. Defendants' "Motion to Strike Plaintiffs' Trial Expert Disclosures" (Doc. 122, filed Oct. 26, 2015) is DENIED AS MOOT; and
4. 4. Defendants' "Motion to Strike the Supplemental Declaration of Paul J. Sikorsky in Further Support of Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification" (Doc. 127, filed Dec. 3, 2015) is DENIED AS MOOT.

DONE AND ORDERED at Jacksonville, Florida, this 11th day of May, 2016.
/s/ Harvey E. Schlesinger
HARVEY E. SCHLESINGER 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE

1
In the Court's Order on Defendants' Motion to Dismiss the FCCAC, the Court found that Plaintiffs fixed the deficiencies in PB Property's original complaint and stated this claim with sufficient particularity in the FCCAC. (Doc. 60 at 14-17).

fn 
2
Many of the original filings in this case are redacted versions that were later reified unredacted and under seal. When two documents are listed, the first is the original redacted filing, and the second is the unredacted sealed filing. All dates refer to the original filing date. Further, the Court may refer to certain confidential information contained in the unredacted sealed filings throughout this Order, yet it will cite to the original redacted filing for efficiency, consistency, and clarity. The page and paragraph numbers cited for any document are identical between the two versions.

fn 
3
Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification and Reply to Defendants' Response in opposition both substantively advance and argue formicary corrosion as the specific defect to support their theory of liability. For the first time, in footnote one of Plaintiffs' Sur-Sur-Reply (Doc. 116), Plaintiffs state that their theory of liability is "not so narrow," but they provide no explanation as to what this broader theory of liability may be. In any event, at the hearing on the motion, Plaintiffs clarified and reaffirmed that their theory of liability is exclusively based on the alleged defect of formicary corrosion.

fn 
4
Notably, in Plaintiffs' response to Defendants' motion to exclude the opinions of Sikorsky, Plaintiffs assert that the Court should not undertake a full Daubert analysis because merits discovery was still underway at the time Sikorsky submitted his declaration, and thus Sikorsky's opinions were incomplete based on incomplete discovery. (Doc. 101 at 8-9). Further, Plaintiffs' damages expert, Frank Bernatowicz ("Bernatowicz"), testified that his opinions were prepared for the purpose of class certification. (Doc. 122 at 4).
In this case, the parties did not bifurcate discovery; they undertook class certification discovery and merits discovery together. Defendants point out that Plaintiffs have sought no further discovery and have disclosed no additional testing, nor have they supplemented their disclosures based on any new discovery, since filing their Motion for Class Certification. (Doc. 122 at 3-4).

fn 
5
Sikorsky submitted a supplemental declaration on November 24, 2015, updating the warranty claims rate figures for returned copper evaporator coils in Florida for the years 2006 through 2014. (Doc. 125). This data had been provided to Plaintiffs during discovery, but Plaintiffs only discovered the more comprehensive data at a later date. After discovering the data, which discloses a higher warranty claims rate for each year than previously reported, Sikorsky promptly produced an updated supplement. Defendants filed a "Motion to Strike" Sikorsky's supplemental declaration on December 3, 2015, arguing that the supplement is untimely and prejudicial. (Doc. 127). In response, Plaintiffs argue that there is no prejudice to Defendants because the supplemental declaration simply updates and reinforces Sikorsky's original opinions; the new data does not contradict Sikorsky's prior statements. (Doc. 131).
The Court agrees with Plaintiffs that the effect of the supplemental declaration is overstated by Defendants. While it is true that the supplement is untimely, there is negligible prejudice to Defendants to allow the updated data into evidence, especially at this stage of the litigation. Sikorsky concluded that a warranty claims rate that exceeds one percent for any given year is evidence of a defect; the new percentages for each year do not change Sikorsky's opinions at all, but simply act to reinforce them.
Regardless, this issue is moot because the Court has found Sikorsky's opinion on warranty claims rates to be unreliable; the precise figures for each year are not material.
