UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA
  

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, Plaintiff, v. LUCVENS FRANCOIS, individually and d/b/a TAX RESOURCE CENTER, URBAN SIRE, LLC, and THE CITEDALE GROUP, INC., Defendant. 
  

CASE NO. 14-23130-CIV-ALTONAGA/O'SULLIVAN 
October 16, 2015, Filed October 16, 2015, Decided 
For United States of America, Plaintiff: Christopher Robert Moran, Richard Gerald Rose, LEAD ATTORNEYS, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, DC; Jose A. Olivera, U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Trial Section, Central Region, Washington, DC.
Lucvens Francois, also known as Luke Francois, doing business as Tax Resource Center, doing business as Urban Sire, LLC, doing business as The Citedale Group, Inc., Defendant, Pro se, Pompano Beach, FL. 
JOHN J. O'SULLIVAN, UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE.

JOHN J. O'SULLIVAN 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION
THIS CAUSE is before the Court following an evidentiary show cause hearing held before the undersigned on October 15, 2015. This matter was referred to the undersigned by the Honorable Cecilia M. Altonaga, United States District Court Judge for the Southern District of Florida, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 636(b) . The undersigned previously held a show cause hearing in this matter on September 16, 2015, and previously recommended that the United States' Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) (DE # 37, 7/8/15) be granted and that the Court strike the defendant Lucvens Francois' answer to the complaint and that a default be entered against Mr. Francois as a sanction for failing to comply with this Court's Orders. Having held another show cause hearing in this matter on October 15, 2015, and for the reasons stated on the record during the October 15, 2015, show cause hearing, the undersigned persists in his prior recommendation and respectfully RECOMMENDS that the United States' Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) (DE # 37, 7/8/15) be granted and that the Court strike defendant Lucvens Francois' answer to the complaint and that a default be entered against Mr. Francois as a sanction for failing to comply with this Court's Orders.
BACKGROUND
On March 12, 2015, the undersigned issued an Order in this matter (DE # 26, 3/12/15) in which the Court required the defendant to provide certain discovery responses to the government including copies of tax returns. On April 21, 2015, the undersigned issued an Order (DE # 29, 4/21/15) requiring electronic discovery of tax returns to be provided by the defendant to the plaintiff. On May 26, 2015, the undersigned issued an Order (DE # 32, 5/26/15) requiring the defendant to either provide the government with certain discovery responses, including tax returns, or submit a memorandum of law as to the applicability of the 5th Amendment privilege to this case. A memorandum of law was not submitted to the Court.
On July 8, 2015, the plaintiff filed United States' Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) (DE # 37, 7/8/15) seeking sanctions against Mr. Francois for his failure to comply with three discovery Orders: Order (DE# 26, 3/12/15), Order (DE# 29, 4/21/15) and Order (DE# 32, 5/26/15). Mr. Francois did not file a response to the plaintiff's motion and on August 11, 2015, the undersigned [*2] issued an Order and Notice of Hearing (DE# 55, 8/11/15) requiring Mr. Francois to file a written response to the plaintiff's motion. The Order (DE# 55) warned Mr. Francois that "[t]he failure to file a response may result in an Order that United States' Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) (DE # 37, 7/8/15) be granted in its entirety." See Order (DE# 55 at 1, 8/11/15). The Order (DE# 55) also set the sanctions motion for hearing on September 1, 2015 before the undersigned.
Mr. Francois failed to file a response to the sanctions motion and did not appear at the September 1, 2015 hearing. Following the September 1, 2015 hearing, the undersigned issued an Order and Notice of Hearing (DE# 60, 9/1/15). The Order (DE# 60) required that by September 8, 2015, Mr. Francois provide certain discovery documents to the plaintiff and further required Mr. Francois to:
file with this Court a memorandum addressing why the defendant should not be held in contempt of court for failure and refusal to abide by the Court's August 11, 2015, Order (DE # 55) in this case, the Court's March 12, 2015, Order (DE # 26) in this case, the Court's April 21, 2015, Order (DE # 29) in this case, and the Court's May 26, 2015, Order (DE # 32) in this case. The defendant shall also address in the memorandum why his answer to the complaint in this matter should not be stricken, and why a default judgment should not be entered against him.
Order (DE# 60 at 2, 9/1/15).

The Order (DE# 60) also set a show cause hearing before the undersigned on September 16, 2015. With respect to the September 16, 2015 show cause hearing, the Order (DE# 60) stated:
LUCVENS FRANCOIS, shall be present, in person, at the hearing and shall be prepared to discuss why he failed to comply with Orders of this Court, why his answer to the complaint in this matter should not be stricken, and why a default judgment should not be entered against him.
Id. at 2. The Order (DE# 60) warned Mr. Francois that:
the failure of the defendant to appear in person before the undersigned for the aforementioned hearing or the failure of the defendant to file the aforementioned memorandum, may result in a recommendation that the defendant be held in contempt and sanctions be imposed, including, but not limited to, the defendant's answer to the complaint in this matter being stricken, a default judgment be entered against the defendant, monetary fines being assessed against the defendant, and/or incarceration of the defendant.
Id. at 2-3.

On September 8, 2015, Mr. Francois filed a document entitled Constructive Notice of Conditional Acceptance (DE# 61, 9/9/15). The document states that Mr. Francois failed to appear at the September 1, 2015 hearing because the Court failed to properly notify him of the hearing. The undersigned notes that the Court's CM/ECF system indicates that the Order (DE# 55) setting the September 1, 2015 hearing was mailed to the address on record for Mr. Francois.
It is clear from the Constructive Notice of Conditional Acceptance (DE# 61 at 1, 9/9/15), that Mr. Francois did receive the September 1, 2015 Order (DE# 60) which required his appearance in Court on September 16, 2015. The September 1, 2015 Order (DE# 60) warned Mr. Francois [*3] that he could be subject to sanctions including the striking of his answer to the complaint and the entry of a default judgment against him if he failed to comply with the Order (DE# 60). See supra.
On September 16, 2015, the Court held a show cause hearing. The hearing was noticed for 9:00 AM. The Court waited until 9:22 AM and Mr. Francois failed to appear. At the hearing, the plaintiff represented to the Court that it had not received from Mr. Francois the discovery documents ordered to be produced in this Court's prior Orders. The undersigned issued a Report and Recommendation on September 16, 2015, (DE # 63) recommending that the United States' Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) (DE # 37, 7/8/15) be granted and that the Court strike defendant Lucvens Francois' answer to the complaint and that a default be entered against Mr. Francois as a sanction for failing to comply with this Court's Orders
On September 21, 2015, the defendant filed a Motion (DE # 64, 9/21/15) requesting the Court to reschedule the September 16, 2015, hearing because the defendant was in the hospital at the time of the September 16, 2015, hearing. On September 22, 2015, the undersigned issued an Order and Notice of Hearing (DE # 65, 9/22/15), setting a show cause hearing for October 6, 2015, to determine if the defendant should be held in contempt for failing to comply with this Court's Orders. The defendant appeared at the October 6, 2015 show cause hearing and convinced the Court that he was hospitalized at the time of the September 16, 2015, show cause hearing and the Court decided that sanctions for his failure to appear at that hearing were not appropriate. The undersigned determined that an evidentiary hearing was necessary to decide if the defendant should be held in contempt of Court or sanctioned for failing to comply with this Court's discovery Orders. On October 6, 2015, the undersigned issued an Order (DE # 67, 10/6/15) and set this matter for an evidentiary hearing on October 15, 2015.
The undersigned held an evidentiary hearing in this matter on October 15, 2015, and the defendant presented two witnesses, one of whom was his prior attorney in this matter, Rashad Taylor. The defendant also gave testimony at the October 15, 2015, hearing, and had a composite exhibit of copier machine service records admitted into evidence.
FACTS
The defendant called two witnesses to the stand during the evidentiary hearing. Those witnesses were Rashad Taylor, Esq. and Kevin Lewis. Mr. Taylor was the defendant's former attorney in this matter. The defendant also gave testimony at the evidentiary hearing.
Mr. Taylor testified that to his knowledge, the 2010 tax returns had been copied by the defendant for submission to the government, and that perhaps some of the 2011 tax returns had also been copied to give to the government. Mr. Taylor further testified that neither of the government attorneys with whom he had phone contact ever directly told him that the government did not want hard copies of the requested tax returns. Mr. Taylor testified that after the March 2015 hearing before the undersigned, [*4] he had a discussion with one of the government attorneys on the case and it was decided that electronic production of the tax returns was preferable. It was Mr. Taylor's impression that the government preferred to not receive the tax returns in hard copy. The tax returns were provided to the government in electronic format, but the government was unable to read the electronic medium on which the tax returns were provided. Mr. Lewis testified that he helped move a large number of boxes, and that he helped the defendant dispose of shredded documents.
The defendant testified that he had 12 boxes of documents for the government, and that he disposed of the boxes because the government did not want the volume of paper he wanted to deliver. The defendant also testified that he made so many copies that he had to have his copier serviced. Copies of the service bills reveal the following: (1) the first page is an invoice dated January 19, 2015, from Magnified Imaging Solutions, in the amount of $130.54 for toner for the copy machine; (2) the second page is an invoice dated February 4, 2015, from Magnified Imaging Solutions, in the amount of $331.70 for a service call; and (3) the third page is a work order from Magnified Imaging Solutions dated February 3, 2015, and appears to be a work order related to the February 4, 2015, invoice. It is the defendant's contention that he was prepared to give boxes of photocopied tax returns to the government, but that the government refused to accept the paper copies.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 37 grants a district court the authority to impose sanctions for the failure to make disclosures or cooperate in discovery. Rule 37 also allows a district court to dismiss an action if a party fails to obey an order to provide or permit discovery. Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(b)(2)(A)(v) . The dismissal of a claim or the entry of a default as a sanction for violating a discovery order is a drastic remedy which should only be employed where lesser sanctions would be insufficient. See Malautea v. Suzuki Motor Co., Ltd., 987 F.2d 1536 , 1542 (11th Cir. 1993) (stating that "the severe sanction of a dismissal or default judgment [under Rule 37 ] is appropriate only as a last resort, when less drastic sanctions would not ensure compliance with the court's orders.") (citing Navarro v. Cohan, 856 F.2d 141 , 142 (11th Cir. 1988)).
ANALYSIS
The plaintiff seeks the following sanctions against Mr. Francois for failing to comply with the Court's discovery Orders: that Mr. Francois' answer to the complaint be STRICKEN and that a DEFAULT be entered against him. As noted above, the dismissal of a claim or the entry of a default as a sanction for violating a discovery order is a drastic remedy which should only be employed where lesser sanctions would be insufficient. See Malautea, 987 F.2d at 1542 (citing Navarro, 856 F.2d at 142 ). In Phipps v. Blakeney, 8 F.3d 788 , 790 (11th Cir.1993), the Eleventh Circuit stated that "[d]ismissal with prejudice is the most severe Rule 37 sanction," but it "may be appropriate when a plaintiff's recalcitrance is due to wilfulness, bad faith or fault."
The defendant claims that he was prepared to give boxes of photocopied tax returns to the government, but that [*5] the government refused to accept the paper copies. The evidence presented at the October 15, 2015, evidentiary hearing demonstrated that the photocopying of tax returns by the defendant, and the servicing of the photocopy machine with respect to the large amount of copying was done prior to the undersigned's Order dated March 12, 2015, (DE # 26). Moreover, Mr. Taylor, the defendant's former attorney in this matter, testified that the government attorneys never directly told him that they would not accept hard copies of the subject tax returns.
There has been no action by the defendant subsequent to the date of the first discovery hearing Order to comply with this Court's three discovery Orders.
RECOMMENDATION
In accordance with the foregoing, the undersigned respectfully persists in his recommendation that the United States' Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) (DE # 37, 7/8/15) be GRANTED and that the Court strike defendant LUCVENS FRANCOIS' answer to the complaint and that a default be entered against this defendant as a sanction for failing to comply with this Court's Orders.
The parties have fourteen (14) days from the date of receipt of this Report and Recommendation within which to serve and file written objections, if any, with the Honorable Cecilia M. Altonaga, United States District Court Judge. Failure to file objections timely shall bar the parties from attacking on appeal the factual findings contained herein. See LoConte v. Dugger, 847 F. 2d 745 (11th Cir. 1988), cert. denied, 488 U.S. 958 , 109 S. Ct. 397 , 102 L. Ed. 2d 386 (1988); RTC v. Hallmark Builders, Inc., 996 F. 2d 1144 , 1149 (11th Cir. 1993).
RESPECTFULLY SUBMITTED at the United States Courthouse, Miami, Florida this 16th day of October, 2015.
/s/ John J. O'Sullivan 
JOHN J. O'SULLIVAN 
UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE

         General Information

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA
  

FRED DEVRIES, et al., individually and on behalf of others similarly situated, Plaintiffs, v. MORGAN STANLEY & CO. LLC, f/k/a Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc., etc. et al., Defendants. 
  

Case No. 12-81223-CIV-MARRA/MATTHEWMAN 
October 30, 2015, Filed October 30, 2015, Decided 
For Fred Devries, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, Michael Aversano, Ruby Teich, Scott Belshaw, Kimberly Munsell, Craig Segelke, Kent Jasperse, Plaintiffs: Fran L. Rudich, Jason Conway, Jeffrey A. Klafter, Kurt Olsen, Rachel Aghassi, Seth R. Lesser, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Klafter, Olsen & Lesser, LLP, Rye Brook, NY; Gregg I. Shavitz, Susan Hilary Stern, LEAD ATTORNEYS, Paolo Chagas Meireles, Shavitz Law Group, Boca Raton, FL; Michael John Palitz, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Shavitz Law Group, LLP, Boca Raton, FL.
For Andrew Keller, Luis Lara, Bernard Dzata, Peter Hannah, Anthony Petruzzi, Ali Rahman, George D. Peterson, George D. Peterson, Jessica Mireya Amparo, Peter John Babbles, Peter Baldeo, Michael Banjany, James Michael Barrons, Jesse Adventure Bean, Peter John Beattie, Trevor Sloan Campbell, Michael Thomas Casey, Jeffrey Alan Chase, Travis W Conlon, Shaun Michael Dalton, Alah Daoudi, Ryan K Dix, Michael A Duke, David W Edwards, Eric Daniel Eisenberg, Amil Esmailpour, Adam M Foldes, April Elizabeth Acuna, Daniel Lee Adams-Arman, Tunc Akin, Scott David Allore, Kristin Altimari, Vladimir Babiuc, Scott Robert Belshaw, Diana Michelle Bowar, Michael Burns, Mark Allen Cady, Ken Calhoun, Kathleen Anne Canape-Fatta, George Nicholas Carranza, Colin D Cissne, Andrea Elizabeth Coladarci, John Eric Dewey, Cynthia Gardner, Robert Boris Geller, Catherine Marie Greenspan, Paul Robert Gross, Aaron William Hollister, William Kendric Jenne II, Ashley Nicole Knight, Jason Kramer, Timothy Lewis Lambour, Christopher C Lamela, Emilio Joseph LaPietra, Ronald Raymond Litton, Lewis Joseph Lucarine, Phillip Keven Maloncon, William John McFadden, Jim Murtaza, Frank C Napolitano, Matthew Patrick Palumbo, Kelvin John Pettaway, Gerard Martin Renk, Robert Scott Schwartzberg, Steven Schwendiman, James Ryan FL.
For Rafael Santiago, Mark Malter, Adam Schwartz, Plaintiffs: Fran L. Rudich, Kurt Olsen, Seth R. Lesser, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Klafter, Olsen & Lesser, [*3] LLP, Rye Brook, NY; Gregg I. Shavitz, LEAD ATTORNEY, Paolo Chagas Meireles, Susan Hilary Stern, Shavitz Law Group, Boca Raton, FL; Michael John Palitz, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Shavitz Law Group, LLP, Boca Raton, FL.
WILLIAM MATTHEWMAN, United States Magistrate Judge.

WILLIAM MATTHEWMAN 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION ON DEFENDANT'S MOTION TO STRIKE PLAINTIFFS' NOTICES OF WITHDRAWAL OF DISCOVERY OPT-IN PLAINTIFFS SARA MOTIEY AND AGNES APONTE IDE 4211
THIS CAUSE is before the Court upon Defendants, Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, et al.'s ("Defendants") Motion to Strike Plaintiffs' Notices of Withdrawal of Discovery Opt-In Plaintiffs Sara Motiey and Agnes Aponte ("Motion") [DE 421]. This matter was referred to the undersigned by United States District Judge Kenneth A. Marra. See DE 434. Plaintiffs, Fred Devries, et al. ("Plaintiffs") have filed a Response [DE 453], and Defendants have filed a Reply [DE 459]. For the reasons that follow, this Court RECOMMENDS that the District Court GRANT Defendants' Motion.
I. BACKGROUND 
The relevant facts of the case are as follows. Plaintiff Devries filed the Complaint [DE 1] in this action on August 8, 2012 as a collective action pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act ("FLSA"). Accordingly, this case is now more than three years old.
In its Second Amended Scheduling Order [DE 144], the Court set the cut-off date for Fact Discovery for December 15, 2014. [DE 144, para. A]. The cut-off date for Representative Discovery was also initially set for December 15, 2014. [DE 144, para. B]. However, the Representative Discovery cut-off date was extended to February 28, 2015 [DE 178], then to April 14, 2015 [DE 215], then to June 12, 2015 [DE 241, para. 1], then to July 23, 2015 for four additional Discovery Opt-Ins [DE 302], and then to August 28, 2015 as to Discovery Opt-In Sara Motiey [DE 400].
The discovery process has been unnecessarily slow, protracted, litigious and expensive. From just January 15, 2015 through the date of this Report and Recommendation, a period of approximately ten months, the Court has held at least thirteen discovery hearings [DE 200, 217, 225, 230, 243, 253, 261, 267, 280, 289, 300, 311, 324], Myriad discovery motions and responses have been filed and numerous orders entered. Fact and Representative Discovery is now closed.
There are now numerous substantive motions pending before the Court. In light of the voluminous substantive motions now pending in this case, the Court recently removed the case from the trial calendar. [DE468].
On August 28, 2015, Plaintiffs filed Plaintiffs' Notice of Withdrawal of Opt-In Plaintiff to withdraw Motiey's Consent to Join in the case. See DE 407. On September 4, 2015, Plaintiffs filed Plaintiffs' Notice of Withdrawal of Opt-In Plaintiff to withdraw Agnes Aponte's Consent to Join in the case.1 See DE 416.
Defendants filed this Motion claiming that the Notices of Withdrawal were improper, unstipulated notices of dismissal "designed to exclude pertinent evidence and continue 'having the Court see only what Plaintiffs want it to see.'" [DE 421, p. 1]. Defendants assert that Motiey recorded, and was paid for, 101 overtime hours of work during her time as [*4] a Financial Advisor Associate ("FAA") and that her employment circumstances are pertinent to key disputed issues in the case. Id. Because significant resources have been spent on ensuring Motiey's participation in discovery, Defendants argue that it would be highly prejudicial and unjust if she were permitted to unilaterally withdraw her consent. [DE 421, p. 2]. As for Aponte, Defendants claim that Plaintiffs' attempt to unilaterally dismiss her from the case is an attempt to exclude yet another Discovery Opt-In Plaintiff who implicates individualized issues precluding class or collective treatment of this case. Id. 
Defendants argue that, pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(a) , a plaintiff may not unilaterally dismiss their claims without a court order. [DE 421, pp. 8-9]. Therefore, Defendants claim that, as Opt-In Plaintiffs, Motiey and Aponte are considered party plaintiffs and can only dismiss their claims by filing a stipulation of dismissal signed by all parties who have appeared. [DE 421, p. 9], Accordingly, Defendants ask that the Court strike the Notices of Withdrawal, reaffirm that Motiey must appear for her deposition and respond to discovery requests, and order monetary and other sanctions against Motiey if she fails to cooperate. [DE 421, pp. 9-10]. Defendants also request that if Motiey is dismissed, Defendants should be granted leave to take her deposition as a third party because she has information relevant to the issues in this case. [DE 421, p. 11].
In response, Plaintiffs assert that the Court previously instructed how Discovery Opt-In Plaintiffs were to be selected and replaced in this matter. [DE 453, p. 2]. Plaintiffs allege that Defendants only take issue with the withdrawal and replacement process now because they "needed a vehicle to file additional pages in opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for Final FLSA and Class Certification." [DE 453, p. 3]. Plaintiffs also claim that Defendants have been aware that Motiey would be non-responsive since at least June 30, 2015. [DE 453, p. 5]. Plaintiffs argue that Motiey would likely have been dismissed from the case by the Court anyways, like the other twenty-six non-responsive Discovery Opt-Ins, for failing to participate in discovery. Id. Next, Plaintiffs allege that Defendants fail to identify any basis to force Aponte to continue to be a part of this case. Plaintiffs assert that Aponte has requested to withdraw from this case and that Defendants already have Aponte's deposition to use as they wish. [DE 453, p. 6]. Finally, Plaintiffs assert that prior to Motiey and Aponte's Notices of Withdrawal, two Opt-Ins and four Discovery Opt-Ins voluntarily withdrew from the case by filing Notices of Withdrawal without argument from Defendants. [DE 453, p. 7]. Plaintiffs state that this procedure was established in the Court's Second Amended Scheduling Order, which said "[a] discovery opt-in who fails or refuses to participate in discovery or deposition will be replaced by the same process by which they were selected." Id. 
In their reply, Defendants contend that Plaintiffs admit in their Response that the Notices of Withdrawal [*5] were unilateral and not stipulated. [DE 457, p. 1 ]. Defendants assert that Rule 41 (a) and the case law are clear that opt-in plaintiffs cannot unilaterally dismiss their claims by filing notices of withdrawal. [DE 459, p. 2]. According to Defendants, the cases cited by Plaintiffs in their Response involved either defendants who agreed that the opt-ins could be dismissed—or showed no indication that they objected to the dismissal—or opt-in plaintiffs who sought leave of court before dismissing their claims. [DE 459, p. 3]. Next, Defendants claim that regardless of how the parties handled previous non-responsive Discovery Opt-ins, that process is inapplicable now because discovery is closed. [DE 459, p. 5]. Moreover, Defendants point out that Motiey was specifically court-ordered to respond to discovery and attend her deposition, which she failed to do. Id. Unlike previously dismissed Discovery Opt-ins, Defendants did not agree to dismiss Motiey or Aponte. Id. Also, Defendants emphasize that Aponte is not a non-responsive Discovery Opt-In because she responded to discovery and attended her deposition, therefore the process for non-responsive Discovery Opt-Ins is irrelevant to her. [DE 459, p. 6].
II. DISCUSSION 
The Court has reviewed Defendants' Motion [DE 421], Plaintiffs' Response [DE 453], and Defendants' Reply [DE 459]. The Court finds that the Defendants' Motion to Strike should be granted for the following reasons.
First, there is no clear authority that allows Plaintiffs to unilaterally withdraw Discovery Opt-in Plaintiffs Motiey and Aponte from this case without Defendants' consent or Court approval. Conversely, Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(a) is clear to the effect that, after an answer has been filed, plaintiffs may only dismiss their claims by stipulation or court order. Fed. R. Civ. P. 41(a)(1)(A) ; Reyes v. Texas EZPAWN, L.P., Case No. V-03-128, [2006 BL 122419], 2006 WL 3513936 , *1 (S.D. Tex. Dec. 6, 2006) ("Contrary to Plaintiffs belief, simply withdrawing the consent forms of opt-in plaintiffs does not automatically dismiss their claims without an order of this Court."). The Eleventh Circuit has held that "by referring to them as 'party plaintiff[s]' Congress indicated that opt-in plaintiffs should have the same status in relation to the claims of the lawsuit as do the named plaintiffs." Prickett v. DeKalb Cnty., 349 F.3d 1294 , 1297 (11th Cir. 2003). Thus, opt-in plaintiffs are party plaintiffs and are required to comply with Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41 to withdraw from a case.
Here, Plaintiffs' counsel contacted Defendants' counsel on August 26, 2015, and asked if Defendants would join in a stipulated order dismissing Motiey from the case because she wanted to be withdrawn from the matter. [DE 421-2, Ex. B]. This was an implicit admission by Plaintiffs' counsel that the consent of Defendants' counsel was required to effectuate a dismissal of Motiey. Defendants' counsel did not agree to the stipulated order. Id. Plaintiffs did not file a motion seeking a court order dismissing Motiey. Because Plaintiffs had neither the consent of the Defendants nor the approval of the Court, their two Notices of Withdrawal of Motiey and Aponte are without legal support and should be stricken. See Butler v. DirectSat USA, [*6] LLC, 800 F.Supp.2d 662 , 666 (D. Md. 2011) (the court agreed that an opt-in plaintiff could not withdraw without court approval or a joint stipulation because an answer had already been filed in the case). Plaintiffs cannot simply unilaterally decide that Discovery Opt-Ins Motiey and Aponte are "not members of the collective" [see DE 453, p. 10, n. 10] by the filing of an unauthorized Notice of Withdrawal. Because Defendants do not stipulate to withdrawal of Motiey and Aponte, and because this Court did not authorize such dismissal, both Discovery Opt-Ins should remain in the case at this time.
Second, the Court rejects Plaintiffs' argument that, at this late date, after discovery has closed, the Defendants should be forced to select two new Discovery Opt-In Plaintiffs and incur the additional, significant expense of compiling and producing additional electronic discovery as to the two new Opt-Ins and proceeding with written discovery and depositions as to two new Opt-Ins. Plaintiffs make the argument that this is how the case has progressed to date and that the situation involving Motiey and Aponte is no different from prior Opt-Ins who were removed from the case and replaced. [DE 453, pp. 7-8]. However, Plaintiffs ignore the fact that discovery is now closed. Additionally, Plaintiffs ignore the fact that Defendants consented, either expressly or impliedly, to replacement of prior Discovery Opt-Ins and do not consent to replacement of Motiey and Aponte. Plaintiffs also ignore that Motiey was previously ordered by this Court to attend her deposition and respond to discovery [DE 400] and that she has failed to comply.
Third, the Court is concerned that Plaintiffs' attempts to withdraw Discovery Opt-Ins Motiey and Aponte may be designed, at least in part, to prevent the Court from considering the testimony of those two Opt-Ins in regards to the pending substantive motions. The Court is troubled by Plaintiffs' statement that "they do not dispute" that Defendants can use Aponte's testimony (and therefore Aponte should not be forced to litigate her claim against her wishes) [DE 453, p. 6], in light of Plaintiffs' argument contained in the final footnote of Plaintiffs' Response, which states in part as follows: "More importantly, it should be noted that on a motion for decertification, the Court should not be concerned with the experience of Opt-ins who are not members of the collective.. .Accordingly, because neither Motiey nor Aponte are members of the collective, discovery as to them is not relevant and not probative of whether the collective is similarly situated. Notwithstanding this, and as stated above, Plaintiffs agree that Aponte's deposition testimony is already part of the record and may be cited by the parties." [DE 453, p. 10, n. 10]. This seems to be a disingenuous argument by Plaintiffs, which in effect suggests that once Discovery Opt-ins Motiey and Aponte are unilaterally withdrawn from the case, they or their "experience" are not to be considered by the Court regarding the pending substantive motions, but the Defendants can meaninglessly cite to the testimony [*7] or experience of those two Discovery Opt-ins.
The Court rejects Plaintiffs' position in this regard. Plaintiffs cannot unilaterally withdraw Discovery Opt-ins Motiey and Aponte from this case, over Defendants' objection and without court approval, in violation of Rule 41(a) , and then profit from such unauthorized action by arguing that because of the withdrawals, Motiey and Aponte are no longer members of the collective action and their "experience," testimony, or evidence is no longer relevant or probative as to whether the collective is similarly situated. Whether or not the testimony, evidence, or experience of either Motiey or Aponte is relevant to the pending motions or other issues in this case is for the Court to decide at an appropriate time. Plaintiffs cannot unilaterally dictate what evidence is, or is not, relevant and probative in this case.
Accordingly, as to Motiey, Plaintiffs' Notice of Withdrawal [DE 407] should be stricken. Further, the Court's prior Order [DE 400] dated August 13, 2015 ordered Motiey to respond to written discovery requests and attend her deposition by August 28,2015. That Order also advised Motiey that if she failed to comply with the Order, her claim may be dismissed with prejudice and additional sanctions imposed against her. Motiey should be ordered once again to sit for her deposition and answer interrogatories within a reasonable period of time to be set by the Court. If Motiey fails or refuses to do so, the case against her should be dismissed with prejudice. Further, in the event of such noncompliance, because a dismissal with prejudice of Motiey would not completely remedy the prejudice suffered by Defendants due to her noncompliance and withholding of potential favorable testimony, Defendants should also be entitled to (1) an inference that Motiey's testimony would have been favorable to Defendants; (2) a finding that she recorded and was paid for 101 hours of overtime work as argued by Defendants; (3) admission of documents establishing that she recorded and was paid for 101 hours of overtime work as argued by Defendants; and (4) additional sanctions as may be deemed appropriate by the Court.
As to Aponte, Plaintiffs' Notice of Withdrawal [DE 416] should be stricken. Aponte is not a Discovery Opt-In who refused to respond to discovery. She responded to written discovery and testified at her deposition. Therefore, her situation is somewhat different from that of Motiey. Simply because Aponte has made a request to be withdrawn from this case at this late date, after she has sat for her deposition and provided testimony and evidence, does not mean that she must be allowed to withdraw. The Court finds that Defendants would be prejudiced if Aponte was permitted to withdraw as they would then face an argument from Plaintiffs that her testimony and evidence is irrelevant because she would arguably no longer be a member of the collective. Defendants would also be prejudiced in having to go through the expensive and lengthy process of replacing her and engaging in discovery [*8] as to a new Opt-In. Defendants argue that Aponte's testimony at her deposition was untruthful and helpful to Defendants' position in this lawsuit. The Court does not need to make any credibility determination as to Aponte's testimony for purposes of this Motion. Because Aponte should remain in this case as a Discovery Opt-In Plaintiff, the parties should be permitted to make use of her testimony in any appropriate manner and in regards to any pending motion or at trial.
III. CONCLUSION 
In light of the foregoing, this Court RECOMMENDS that the District Court GRANT Defendant's Motion to Strike Plaintiffs' Notices of Withdrawal of Discovery Opt-In Plaintiffs Sara Motiey and Agnes Aponte [DE 421]. The Court also RECOMMENDS that the District Court STRIKE Plaintiffs' Notice of Withdrawal of Opt-In Plaintiff [DE 407] for Sara Motiey and Plaintiffs Notice of Withdrawal of Opt-In Plaintiff [DE 416] for Agnes Aponte. The Court further RECOMMENDS that Discovery Opt-In Sara Motiey be ordered to attend her deposition and respond to discovery requests within a reasonable time as set by the Court. Moreover, if Sara Motiey refuses to attend her deposition and/or respond to discovery requests, the undersigned RECOMMENDS that the Court dismiss her case with prejudice and further, that Defendants should be entitled to (1) an inference that Motiey's testimony would have been favorable to Defendants; (2) a finding that she recorded and was paid for 101 hours of overtime work as argued by Defendants; (3) admission of documents establishing that she recorded and was paid for 101 hours of overtime work as argued by Defendants; and (4) any additional sanctions as deemed appropriate by the Court.
NOTICE OF RIGHT TO OBJECT
A party shall file written objections, if any, to this Report and Recommendation with United States District Judge Kenneth A. Marra within fourteen (14) days of being served with a copy of this Report and Recommendation. See 28 U.S.C. § 636(b)(1)(C) .
RESPECTFULLY SUBMITTED in Chambers at West Palm Beach, Palm Beach County, Florida, this 30th day of October 2015.
/s/ William Matthewman
WILLIAM MATTHEWMAN
United States Magistrate Judge

Majority Opinion > 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA
  

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, Plaintiff, v. LUCVENS FRANCOIS, Defendant. 
  

CASE NO. 14-23130-CIV-ALTONAGA/O'Sullivan 
November 5, 2015, Filed November 5, 2015, Decided 
For United States of America, Plaintiff: Christopher Robert Moran, Richard Gerald Rose, LEAD ATTORNEYS, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, DC; Jose A. Olivera, U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Trial Section, Central Region, Washington, DC.
Lucvens Francois, also known as Luke Francois, doing business as Tax Resource Center, doing business as Urban Sire, LLC, doing business as The Citedale Group, Inc., Defendant, Pro se, Pompano Beach, FL. 
CECILIA M. ALTONAGA, UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE.

CECILIA M. ALTONAGA 
ORDER
On July 8, 2015, Plaintiff, United States of America ("Plaintiff" or "the Government") filed a Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) ("Motion") [ECF No. 37]. The Court referred the Motion to Magistrate Judge John J. O'Sullivan for a report and recommendation. (See Order [ECF No. 42]). On September 16, 2015, Judge O'Sullivan entered a Report and Recommendation ("First Report") [ECF No. 63]. In the Report, Judge O'Sullivan recommended the Court grant the Motion; strike Defendant, Lucvens Francois's ("Francois['s]") Answer to the Complaint; and enter a default against Francois. (See  id. 5). Judge O'Sullivan found these sanctions warranted due to Francois's failure to comply with five of the Court's Orders and failure to appear at two duly noticed hearings. (See  id. 4).
On September 21, 2015, Francois filed a Motion ("Defendant's Motion") [ECF No. 64], asking Judge O'Sullivan to reschedule one of the duly noticed hearings, and advising he had been unable to attend due to medical reasons. (See  id. 1). Magistrate Judge O'Sullivan construed Defendant's Motion as a request to reconsider the First Report and set the matter for a show cause hearing on October 6, 2015, allowing Francois the opportunity to discuss why sanctions should not be imposed. (See Order . . . [ECF No. 65] 1-2). Francois appeared at the October 6, 2015 hearing, following which Judge O'Sullivan set an evidentiary hearing for October 15, 2015, allowing Francois the opportunity to present witnesses and show cause why sanctions should not be imposed. (See Order . . . [ECF No. 67] 1-2).
Following the October 15, 2015 evidentiary hearing, Judge O'Sullivan entered a new Report and Recommendation ("Second Report") [ECF No. 70] on October 16, 2015. In the Second Report, Judge O'Sullivan persists in his original recommendation the Court grant the Motion; strike Francois's Answer to the Complaint; and enter a default against Francois. (See  id. 1). On October 30, 2015, Francois filed an Objection . . . ("Objections") [ECF No. 71]. When a magistrate judge's "disposition" has properly been objected to, district courts must review the disposition de novo. Fed. R. Civ. P. 72(b)(3) .
I. BACKGROUND 
On March 12, 2015, Judge O'Sullivan issued an Order ("First Discovery Order") [ECF No. 26] requiring Francois to provide certain discovery responses to the Government, including copies of tax returns. (See Second Report 2). On April 21, 2015, Judge O'Sullivan issued another Order ("Second Discovery Order") [ECF No. 29] requiring Francois [*2] to provide electronic discovery of tax returns to the Government. (See Second Report 2). Further, on May 26, 2015, Judge O'Sullivan issued a third Order ("Third Discovery Order") [ECF No. 32], requiring Francois to either provide the Government with certain discovery responses, including tax returns, or submit a memorandum of law as to the applicability of the Fifth Amendment privilege to the case. (See Second Report 2). No memorandum of law was submitted. (See id.).
On July 8, 2015, Plaintiff filed the instant Motion seeking sanctions against Francois for his failure to comply with the aforementioned three discovery Orders. (See id.). Francois did not respond to the Motion, and on August 11, 2015, Judge O'Sullivan issued an Order and Notice of Hearing ("First Order and Notice of Hearing") [ECF No. 55] requiring Francois to file a written response, warning "[t]he failure to file a response may result in an Order that United States' Motion for Sanctions Pursuant to Rule 37(b) (DE # 37, 7/8/15) be granted in its entirety;" and setting the sanctions motion for a hearing on September 1, 2015. (Second Report 2 (quoting First Order and Notice of Hearing 1)).
Francois failed to respond to the Motion and did not appear at the September 1, 2015 hearing. (See id.). Following the September 1, 2015 hearing, Judge O'Sullivan issued another Order and Notice of Hearing ("Second Order and Notice of Hearing") [ECF No. 60], requiring Francois to provide certain discovery documents to Plaintiff by September 8, 2015; file a memorandum with the Court addressing why he should not be held in contempt for failure to comply with the Court's Orders; and appear at a show cause hearing on September 16, 2015 to discuss his failure to comply. (See Second Report 2-3). The Second Order and Notice of Hearing warned Francois that failure to appear at the hearing could result in a recommendation that he be held in contempt and sanctions be imposed. (See  id. 3).
On September 8, 2015, Francois filed a Constructive Notice of Conditional Acceptance ("Notice") [ECF No. 61], explaining he failed to appear at the September 1, 2015 hearing because the Court failed to properly notify him of the hearing. (See Second Report 3). Judge O'Sullivan notes the Court's CM/ECF system indicates the First Order and Notice of Hearing was mailed to Francois's address of record. (See id.). Further, Francois's Notice indicates he received the Second Order and Notice of Hearing requiring him to appear at the September 16, 2015 hearing. (See  id. 4).
Nonetheless, as stated, Francois failed to appear at the September 16, 2015 hearing. (See id.). Consequently, Judge O'Sullivan issued the First Report, recommending the Court grant the Motion and impose sanctions against Francois. (See id.). As noted, when Francois moved Judge O'Sullivan to reconsider his First Report, Judge O'Sullivan set a show cause hearing for October 6, 2015. (See id.). At the October 6, 2015 hearing, Francois appeared and convinced Judge O'Sullivan he had been hospitalized at the time of the September 16, 2015 hearing. (See id.). The Magistrate Judge thus decided against imposing sanctions for Francois's failure to appear [*3] at that hearing, and set an evidentiary hearing for October 15, 2015 to determine if Francois should be held in contempt or sanctioned for failing to comply with the Court's discovery Orders. (See  id. 4-5).
At the evidentiary hearing of October 15, 2015, Francois presented two witnesses, Rashad Taylor, Esq. ("Taylor") and Kevin Lewis ("Lewis"). (See  id. 5). Taylor is Francois's former attorney in this matter. (See id.). Taylor testified that, to his knowledge, Francois had copied the 2010 tax returns, and possibly some of the 2011 tax returns, to submit to Plaintiff. (See id.). He further testified that after a March 2015 hearing before Judge O'Sullivan, Taylor and one of the Government attorneys decided electronic production of the tax returns was preferable, although neither of the Government attorneys directly told him the Government did not want hard copies of the requested tax returns. (See id.). Taylor was under the impression the Government preferred not to receive the tax returns in hard copy. (See id.). Thus, the tax returns were provided to the Government in electronic format; however, the Government was unable to read the electronic medium on which the returns were provided. (See id.).
Presumably after providing the tax returns in electronic format to the Government, Francois disposed of the hard copies. (See  id. 6). Lewis testified he helped Francois dispose of the shredded documents. (See  id. 5-6). Francois testified he disposed of the documents because the Government did not want the volume of paper he wanted to deliver. (See  id. 6). Francois also testified he made so many copies he had to have his copier serviced. (See id.). Copies of Francois's service bills include: (1) an invoice dated January 19, 2015 for copy machine toner; (2) an invoice dated February 4, 2015 for a service call; and (3) a work order dated February 3, 2015 related to the February 4, 2015 invoice. (See id.).
II. ANALYSIS 
In his Second Report, Judge O'Sullivan finds Francois's evidence presented at the October 15, 2015 evidentiary hearing fails to persuade sanctions are inappropriate. (See  id. 7). Predominantly, Francois's evidence demonstrated he copied the tax returns and had the copier serviced before Judge O'Sullivan entered any of the discovery Orders at issue.1 (See id.). That is, Francois took no action subsequent to the date of the First Discovery Order to comply with the Court's three discovery Orders. (See id.). Moreover, Taylor testified the Government attorneys never directly told him they would not accept hard copies of the tax returns. (See id.). Consequently, Judge O'Sullivan persists in his original recommendation the sanctions sought by Plaintiff are warranted. (See id.).
Francois's Objections to Judge O'Sullivan's Second Report are brief and cursory. (See generally Objections). First, Francois simply states Taylor testified at the evidentiary hearing the Government "implied" it did not want hard copies of the tax returns, at which point Francois destroyed the copies and mailed an external hard drive with electronic copies to the Government. (See  id. 1). Second, Francois states he followed the "exact instructions" [*4] Taylor and/or Plaintiff gave him. ( Id.). Neither of these objections addresses or explains the fact Francois took no action subsequent to the date of the First Discovery Order to comply with the Court's three Orders. It is this fact that forms the crux of Judge O'Sullivan's conclusion sanctions are warranted.
Finally, Francois concludes his Objections by attempting to move to dismiss this case, stating "[I] move the court to dismiss all charges since all the concerns of the United States are being addressed in the criminal case." ( Id. (alteration added)). This addition to Francois's Objections does not constitute a proper motion to dismiss. The Local Rules require a motion to dismiss to "incorporate a memorandum of law citing supporting authorities," which Francois has failed to include. S.D. FLA. L.R. 7.1(a)(1) . Consequently, all three of Francois's objections are without merit.
III. CONCLUSION 
The undersigned has conducted a de novo review of the record, the parties' filings, and the Second Report with respect to Francois's Objections, and has otherwise reviewed the Second Report to assure herself there is no clear error. In the light of that review, the undersigned agrees with the analysis and recommendations stated in Judge O'Sullivan's Second Report, and adopts Judge O'Sullivan's conclusion the Motion should be granted, and Francois's Answer stricken as a sanction pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 37(b) .
Regarding entering default against Francois, Plaintiff is required to file a motion for default final judgment, as required by Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 55(b) , because Plaintiff seeks injunctive relief, instead of damages in the form of "a sum certain or a sum that can be made certain by computation." Fed. R. Civ. P. 55(b) ; see also United States v. Sellers, No. 5:11-CV-326-RS-CJK, [2013 BL 397299], 2013 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 76730 , 2013 WL 3746102 , at *3 (N.D. Fla. Apr. 30, 2013)report and recommendation approved, No. 5:11-CV-326-RS-CJK, [2013 BL 143693], 2013 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 76747 , 2013 WL 2403671 (N.D. Fla. May 31, 2013) (noting a court may issue default judgment where a party fails to obey a discovery order in a civil case; however, where the plaintiff's claim against defendant is not for a sum certain or for a sum that can be made certain by computation, "the party must apply to the court for a default judgment" (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 55(b) )). Plaintiff's Motion cannot be construed as a motion for default judgment because, while it requests the Court enter default judgment as a sanction, it focuses solely on the sanctions standard of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 37(b) , rather than addressing Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 55 ; and does not comply with the requirements for a motion for default judgment contained in the Local Rules. See generally Mot; see also S.D. FLA. L.R. 7.1 (a)(2) .
Accordingly, it is
ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that the First Report [ECF No. 63] and the Second Report [ECF No. 70] are AFFIRMED AND ADOPTED as follows:
1. The United States of America's Motion [ECF No. 37] is GRANTED.
2. Lucven Francois's Answer [ECF No. 15] is STRICKEN.
3. Plaintiff, United States of America shall file a motion for default final judgment by November 16, 2015.
a. The motion for default final judgment shall be accompanied by a proposed order and proposed final judgment. (See Local Rule 7.1(a)(2) .). Pursuant to the CM/ECF Administrative Procedures, the proposed orders shall be submitted [*5] to the Court by e-mail in Word format at altonaga@flsd.uscourts.gov . Plaintiff shall send a copy of the motion to Defendant's counsel, or to Defendant if he does not have counsel. In the certificate of service, Plaintiff shall indicate that notice was sent and the addresses where notice was sent.
b. If Defendant fails to respond to the motion for default final judgment within the time permitted by the Rules, default final judgment may be entered, which, simply put, means that Plaintiff may be able to obtain relief against Defendant.

DONE AND ORDERED in Miami, Florida, this 5th day of November, 2015.
/s/ Cecilia M. Altonaga 
CECILIA M. ALTONAGA 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 

  
fn 
1
Again, the First Discovery Order is dated March 12, 2015. (See Second Report 2). Francois's invoices are all from January and February 2015. (See  id. 6).
